TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, the Loans Bill is an element of the annual Budget which authorises the Government of the day to raise certain revenues during the financial period to which the Bill refers. The Loans Bill 1985 sought to extend the borrowing authority available as it was drafted as standing rather than annual legislation. The Opposition parties, with the Australian Democrats, were successful in moving in the Senate an amendment to the 1985 Bill which restored the legislation to an annual basis. The 1986 Loans Bill again sought to extend borrowing authority. There must be a lot of loans going on around here, Madam Speaker.
—Yes, perhaps the level of conversation could be reduced. Those who wish to keep talking might like to leave the chamber.

—The Loans Bill 1986 sought to extend the borrowing authority in exactly the same manner as in 1985, and again an Opposition amendment restored the legislation to its annual basis. The Loans Bill 1987 seeks to extend the existing borrowing authority by the inclusion of a supply clause. The borrowing authority under the annual Loan Act ceases to be available on 30 June, and further authority is not available until the next Loan Bill is passed, usually a process carried out in the Budget sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Borrowing authority under the proposed change would be extended into the following financial year by the amount included in the Supply Bill (No. 1) for defence purposes, that Bill having been passed before the end of the financial year. Since the amount included in the Supply Bill (No. 1) for defence purposes is invariably very large, being roughly five-twelfths of the annual defence vote, that amount of the authority would almost certainly exceed the amount which otherwise the Government would need to seek by way of a Loans Bill at some point during the financial year. If so, the Government would thus in practical terms achieve the freedom from security under the procedures associated with the Loans Bill which it sought to achieve on a statutory basis in 1985.

This Bill, therefore, is an attempt to take away from the Parliament its annual scrutiny of loan raisings and really pre-empts the Parliament in another area of scrutiny, the scrutiny of Government legislation, and because of that the Opposition will be moving an amendment to restore this Bill to the context of the 1985 and 1986 legislation.

I have discussed the effect of the Loans Bill, but I wish to use a few moments to cast a few reflections on the Budget itself. There is no doubt that the deficit is continuing to grow and that the elements associated with it are causing concern to the citizens of Australia. The Loans Bill itself authorises the Government of the day to raise short term funding to cover the deficit that occurs in the current tradings of Government operations. In other words, current expenditures by government go on on a day to day basis but income flows to government are seasonal in that at certain times of the year large amounts are received. For example, pay as you earn tax comes in on a regular basis, but corporate tax, provisional tax and certain sales taxes come in at different periods throughout the year. To even out the cash flow, borrowings must be undertaken.

It is interesting to note within the Budget Papers that the amount of interest that has been paid in this time shows that in the last four to five years the Government has incurred an increased debt and is adding to that debt every year to the extent that in 1980-81 total public debt interest was $2.5 billion. In the year just concluded-1986-87-that debt had risen to just short of $8 billion, a massive increase over that period. This increase in the interest payment on debt is reflected not only in the amount of money that has been continually added to in the national debt sense but also in the high levels of interest rates that have been paid by the Government during that period. As a consequence, it is worth looking at the way in which the Government has attempted to fund this over that period. Let me quote from Budget Paper No. 1:
The 1986-87 Commonwealth budget deficit was $2716m, which was more than accounted for by a foreign currency requirement of $3214m.

This quite clearly indicates that the Government had a substantial amount to pay for on the foreign account. When we look at items that are to be paid for we see that there is a considerable element of defence spending.

The way in which the financing of the Commonwealth Budget deficit was handled is interesting. I referred the other day to net overseas borrowings in relation to the comments made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about redemption of debt. That was a misleading comment, which is borne out by these Budget Papers. He said that this year the Commonwealth would attempt to repay $1 billion worth of overseas debt and $1 billion worth of domestic debt. Budget Paper No. 1 indicates that every year there are movements both ways. While the figures used are net figures, it is an indication of the size of movements that occur. Therefore, the statement made by the Treasurer in the Budget Speech was highly misleading.

Let me refer to this particular section in Budget Paper No. 1. It shows, under the heading `Net overseas borrowings', that there were net Treasury bond subscriptions of some $627m. This was made up of gross Treasury bond subscriptions of $3.4 billion, less maturing bonds of $2.7 billion. This is the order of transactions that occur every day in relation to movements within the Reserve Bank of Australia and they show the falsity of the Treasurer's claim. We see in relation to domestic transactions that in that year the Government was forced to pay an amount of $700m to meet redemptions that fell due in that period. I do not have with me the redemptions that are likely to fall due in the current year, but if overseas borrowings continue at the rate itemised on page 359 of Budget Paper No. 1 it is quite clear that in the current period there would be a number of redemptions and loan raisings to continue to fund the level of debt we currently have. As we are still running a balance of payments deficit and as we are still projecting a domestic Budget deficit of $27m, when in reality we depend so much on the outcome of asset sales and certain collections from the Reserve Bank in future years, it is inevitable that borrowings will continue. Because of that, we have to look at the source of some of these borrowings and the way in which they are handled.

Having pointed to those movements and, therefore, to the rather ridiculous claim about the retirement of debt that was made in the Budget Speech, let me just briefly go to another sector which I think has been overlooked in relation to the Budget itself. Despite all the claims about the high level of taxation-the extra $5 1/2 billion in this Budget to make it nearly balance-let us also look at the question of government spending. We heard quite recently from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, on this subject. He indicated his concerns in relation to government spending and its approach to this Budget. He underlined and pointed out to the public that it was not a really drastic attempt to look at ongoing government spending. He could easily identify 200-odd projects which had no real significance, except to the economy, and which were gross extravagances. That is an indication to me that the expenditure side of the Budget was not appropriately addressed.

At the same time, the Budget was greeted with an avalanche of income. Where did it come from-the extra $5 1/2 billion that is outlined in the Budget Papers that bring forward the result that has occurred? In the main it has come from the private sector-the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers. The increase in their contributions is projected to be in excess of the projected inflation rate. If the inflation rate is 7 per cent and their contributions are projected to be more than that, quite clearly Australians are paying more tax in the current year and more people will pay higher rates of tax as a consequence of those inflationary moves. Up to a million people in Australia could be paying higher rates of tax in the current period as a result of this Budget. In the Budget Papers corporate tax is projected to be 14 per cent higher than in the previous year. It is little wonder that the Government has not addressed itself to the spending cuts that are necessary, as Senator Walsh indicated, when the avalanche of money continues.

Those are the elements which I think are important to take into account when we address the Loans Bill. The Loans Bill facilitates the Government's program on a daily basis. Australians facilitate the Government's program on a daily basis by paying tax at the required rates, which everyone knows are now too high. When we hear the comments that are being made about this Budget, it is quite ludicrous to think otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill 1987 which we are debating authorises the Government to borrow, for, even though the Budget has a negligible deficit of $27m, it is necessary for the Government to borrow to cover outlays from the Loan Fund. This Bill seeks authority to borrow $1.2 billion. Most of the business community and the financial markets have been advocating a lower deficit for years and the Government has responded remarkably quickly. The deficit is down from 4.1 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1983-84 to zero only four years later. This has been achieved by searingly difficult cuts to outlays which have reduced expenditure from over 29 per cent of GDP to under 27 per cent. Some broadening of the tax base by entirely appropriate and fair taxing of income which previously was exempted has accounted for the remainder of the reduction in the deficit. As a result, the requirement to borrow in this Budget is tiny. The reception of this balanced Budget has been euphoric. The expectations of the business community and financial markets have been entirely satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some general comments about the Loans Bill. The Loans Bill is the most idiosyncratic of Budget measures. The idiosyncrasies go back to just after the war, and were introduced by the Chifley Government. So the critical comments I am about to make relate to well-established tradition. The Loans Bill authorises borrowing for defence purposes. On the face of it, this is extremely odd. Why not seek borrowing for investment, as is normal in businesses and households? The reason, apparently, is that by seeking to borrow to finance defence the Commonwealth is able to avoid seeking Loan Council approval for its borrowing. Defence expenditure is exempted from Loan Council coverage, so the quirky little subterfuge of stating that borrowing is for defence purposes allows the Commonwealth to avoid seeking Loan Council agreement. This is a devious arrangement in which every government since the war has been involved. It should cease in the interests of clear presentation of the Government's accounts. More important though is the confusion of current and capital outlays which this subterfuge enables.

Until the Second World War, current expenditure was charged to the Consolidated Revenue Fund and capital outlays to the Loan Fund. This convention showed clearly the difference between current outlays and revenue. That was the deficit or surplus which mattered. Borrowing, on the other hand, was properly used to finance investment and, provided the rate of return and other goals of that investment were being achieved, the borrowing was justified. However, the Curtin Government started to disguise its budgetary situation by breaking this convention and charging capital expenditure to Consolidated Revenue. Governments since then have maintained the same practice. This deceptive accounting was much criticised in the immediate post-war period but has been standard practice since then. It was apparently introduced to obscure the extent of the Budget surpluses which were occurring immediately after the war. This obfuscation is one of the reasons for the extraordinarily low level of public debt in Australia.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the previous speaker, seems to misunderstand the Australian situation. This convention has allowed the Commonwealth to be a net saver in every year since the late 1940s; that is, in every year for the last 40 years, total revenue has exceeded current outlays. In every year, part of the funding for investment has come from current receipts. Only a portion of investable funds have had to be borrowed. That is the reason why Australia has one of the lowest levels of public debt of any Western country. A recent study by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development showed that, of 20 industrialised market countries, only Finland has a lower proportion of public debt to GDP than Australia. This study compared gross public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product in 20 countries in 1983. In Australia, public debt was about 25 per cent of GDP; that is, excluding the debts of public authorities which are excluded in most other Western countries. In the United States of America, the equivalent figure was 44 per cent. The figure was 25 per cent in Australia and 44 per cent in the United States. In Japan the figure was 67 per cent and in Britain it was 54 per cent. Australia has far less debt than that all of those countries. In fact, the average for all 20 countries was 50 per cent. So the proportion of public debt to GDP in Australia was half that of other Western countries. This shows how cautious Australian governments have been throughout the post-war period.

Another important comparison is the decline in public debt in Australia. The level of public debt now is about the same as at the end of the 1960s-20 years ago-and is far below the level as at the beginning of the 1950s. It is true that public debt has been increasing slowly for the last 10 years, but this increase has now stopped-that is obvious when we have a balanced Budget-and the proportion of debt to national income is now lower, as I have said, than it was 20 years ago. These facts totally obliterate the alarmism of the Opposition that public debt is too high. Of course, it would be nice if there was no public debt, because we would have no interest to pay on it, but all organisations have to borrow in order to invest. Governments are no different. Families have to borrow in order to buy houses; businesses have to borrow in order to build and to buy equipment; and governments have to borrow in order to build their infrastructure.

Investment is the central necessary condition for economic growth and development. Governments provide the skeleton of transport and communications infrastructure, water and sewerage, ports and airports, which is essential for economic expansion. Like businesses, it is entirely responsible for governments to borrow in order to finance productive investment. The alarmism that is being propagated by the Opposition about government borrowing is not only unnecessary but also is entirely misguided for not only do we have relatively little public debt but also pressure to reduce debt further could retard investment, slowing future economic growth.

One of the reasons which is sometimes given for reducing government borrowing is the suggestion that it might crowd out private borrowing. The most common version of the argument is that public borrowing competes for scarce supplies of savings and so forces up interest rates, and higher interest rates then deter private investors. However, experience shows that even if this effect operates at all, its impact is very weak and because in recent Australian history there has been no correlation between the levels of public borrowing and interest rates. A recent paper by Professor John Neville of the Economics Faculty of the University of New South Wales shows that if there is any relationship between the levels of public borrowing and interest rates, it is clearly not a simple or direct one. Interest rates have decreased as public sector borrowing has increased more often than not in recent years, and the reverse is also true-that is, as public sector borrowing has gone down in the last few years, interest rates have gone up.

It may seem difficult to argue this case this week, because following the balanced Budget which was introduced last week, banks immediately reduced home loan interest rates, but the fact of the matter is that banks were planning to do so before the Budget was announced and the reason was that the general level of interest rates was falling, and that was happening because interest rates in Australia are principally determined by interest rates overseas and by the expected change in the value of the Australian dollar on foreign exchange markets. At present, the Australian dollar is rising and the Reserve Bank of Australia is undoubtedly relaxing monetary policy so as to allow interest rates to fall and constrain the exchange rate from rising further. The expectation of further falls in the Australian rate of inflation also supports a further fall in interest rates.

It is true, however, that many people in financial markets believe that reducing public borrowing will contribute to reducing interest rates. Their expectations are obviously important in determining what they do. Given this importance of market expectations, it is clear that every effort should be made to avoid misconceptions by key market players. One very important step which could be taken to reduce the risk of misunderstanding would be to reintroduce capital budgeting.

There is a strong case for separating current outlays from investment. It is obviously reasonable for the public sector to borrow in order to invest, as I have already argued. When assets have a long life and a potential to yield a return over that life, it is reasonable and often convenient to pay for them over time. It is also usual to repay loans for short-lived items such as cars or equipment at a faster rate than long-lived items such as buildings or infrastructure. It is worth recalling that over 75 per cent of public sector non-residential investment is tied up in infrastructure. This contrasts with about 45 per cent of private non-residential investment, which is tied up in infrastructure, including buildings.

Excluding equipment, the Bureau of Statistics figures show that public investment in infrastructure is almost twice as large as private investment. If both sectors were to finance their long-lived assets by long term borrowings, we would therefore expect that public sector borrowings would be around twice as large as private borrowings. However, a considerable proportion of public investment is financed from current revenue. The extent to which the public sector covers its outlay with revenue is one of the best-kept secrets in Australian public life. Few Australians are aware of it, and our integration into world financial markets exposes us to the influence of market participants whose knowledge of Australian public finance is slight.

In view of the importance of market expectation, it is vital that the scope for misunderstanding in the market is minimised. Budget deficits are commonly regarded overseas as current expenditures in excess of current revenue. Defined in this way, there has been no Commonwealth Budget deficit in Australia since 1949-50. Current revenue has exceeded current expenditure in every year. The Commonwealth Budget deficit during that time comprised a mixture of capital and current expenditure exceeding our total current revenue. This distinction is certainly not understood in financial markets outside Australia and is probably not understood to any extent within the country. It is important, however, because market participants who believe that Commonwealth Budget deficits signify profligate spending may adversely affect general market expectations.

All Australian States, all commercial enterprises and many industrialised nations distinguish between capital and current spending in their accounts. The Australian Government did so until the 1940s, as I described at the beginning of these comments. The practice was stopped in the 1940s, as a means of disguising Budget surpluses. Governments used the device to bring down Budgets which were more restrictive than they appeared. The present practice of setting capital expenditure against current revenue normally produces a government deficit that will not appear as such under conventional accounting practice. At a time when Australia is especially vulnerable to market perceptions it seems unwise to deliberately present our performance in a poor light. Therefore, there would be great value in separating capital from current expenditure in the Commonwealth Budget so as to present the real budgetary situation as clearly as possible and so avoid potential damage to Australia's interests in the capital markets. A stricter separation of capital and current expenditure in the Commonwealth Budget would reduce the excessive weight currently placed by financial markets on a misunderstood deficit.

Within the Australian Public Service at present there is a strong argument for the virtues of transparency in the public accounting of public authorities. A stricter separation of capital and current expenditure in the Budget would be a simple and cheap move towards transparency in budgeting practice. I hope that serious consideration will be given to this proposal. It is not new. Other commentators have suggested the same change. Given the Government's success, it is an appropriate time for considering this reform in the way the Budget is presented. By clarifying Australia's public finance situation this change could contribute to improving the climate for both private and public investment and therefore for the growth prospects of the whole nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in making his comments for the Opposition in the second reading debate has misconceived the purpose of the Loans Bill. I ask the House to remember that it is a machinery financing measure which has been used by successive governments since 1911. The inclusion of a supply clause this year in the Bill simply enables continuity of its provisions until the next annual Bill is passed in the Budget sittings in 1988. The supply provisions in the 1988-89 Supply Bill (No. 1) for defence purposes will be subsumed by the amount included in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89, that latter amount being the limit of authority allowed under the non-supply provisions of Part II of the Loans Bill of 1987. This provision has been included in the Loans Act for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has expressed concern that its ability to scrutinise borrowings by the Government will be inhibited. The Bill will not detract from the Parliament's ability to debate the Budget or the associated deficit measures. The deficit and borrowing requirements are announced in the Budget Speech and Papers. These are debated at length by the Parliament. So if one looks at this in toto, all the material is available that is needed for the Opposition or any member of this Parliament to make an informed contribution to the considerations that need to be made in these Bills if they are seen as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to thank the electors of Hunter who, at the Federal election on 11 July, returned me for a second term to this proud office. I would like particularly to thank all those who worked so hard to return me to this place.

One of the reasons for my success in the election was the generous attention that this Government has given to the Hunter electorate. I am delighted today to announce that under the local government funding arrangements a total of $14 1/2m has been allocated to councils in the Hunter Valley for the year 1987-88. These allocations represent an increase on the 1986-87 figures and are an indication of the Federal Government's commitment to local government. But let me tell honourable members opposite that the days of governing through largesse and patronage are gone. What is required of good government today is sound economic management and that is what we are able to give.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get old Bob Menzies back; that is what we need.
-Order! The honourable member for Gwydir shall not interject and he almost certainly should not interject from out of his place.

—I love it when the honourable member for Gwydir interjects because it shows his paucity of views. It is a pleasure to hear from him. Menzies had his lucky run. He used the communist bogy and our terms of trade were running quite favourably. But then the conservatives fell from grace. During the Whitlam period we had our economic problems. I will not say that Whitlam was the greatest economist of all time but he did some very good things. He opened the way for local government to get Federal money and he brought back our boys from Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite have just shown that even in the good times they had no economic competence at all and this country was in one hell of a mess. After it had gone through one of the greatest crises in its history we brought it back from the brink of disaster. Quite frankly, this country would have gone down the gurgler had we not won the election in 1983. Honourable members opposite know that, the electorate knows that and come the next election, honourable members opposite will be staring defeat in the face. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget reflects clearly the Government's lack of any sense of direction in economic strategy. This has been true of this Government throughout its entire period of office. It was first elected by default on the back of the 1982-83 recession and the severe drought still in being at the time. The Government's alleged economic success in its first 18 months to two years of office was very much built upon the benefits of the wages freeze implemented by the last Liberal Government and the fortuitous breaking of the drought shortly after it came into office. Good luck, rather than good sense, helped the Government in those initial stages of coming to office.

SPEECH.PARA: This absence of any strategic direction on the part of the Government has continued right up to the present. Even the Government's campaign for the last Federal election on 11 July set no clear objectives and provided no vision for the future. The election was again won by default rather than on any blueprint on where to take Australia in the years to come.

As always, the Government has built this Budget on imagery rather than reality. It is little wonder that Labor's Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has quite properly said that the Budget has been oversold. The Budget Speech is built upon the sand; it is built upon several false assumptions for which the Government will eventually have to pay. In the Budget the Government has also done a complete turnaround on some previously stated positions. A classic illustration is the gross hypocrisy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 180 degree turn he has managed to execute in relation to negative gearing. The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, uttered these profound words:

Since we have restored the integrity of the tax system by subjecting capital gains to tax, we are now in a position to permit the restoration of deductions against taxable income without exposing the revenue to the threat which existed before July 1985.
The full interest costs of owning and maintaining rental property will now be deductible against income from any source.
Tonight's decision restores the symmetry between investment in property and other assets such as shares or farms.
It will enhance the attractiveness of investment in both commercial and residential rental property and have a beneficial effect on the supply of residential accommodation in particular.

These finely tuned words of the Treasurer are in marked contrast to his early description of negative gearing as an `outrageous rort' and his accompanying attack upon many legitimate businesses and individuals who had properly regarded it as a reasonable tax deduction.

The shifting sands upon which the Budget is built are no more amply demonstrated than in the Treasurer's carefully marketed version of the deficit for 1987-88. The Treasurer, in his opening remarks to Australia's current Budget, said:
Madam Speaker, the Budget for 1987-88 is in balance.
The deficit has been cut to just on zero, a mere $27 million.

The Treasurer's words are an appalling corruption of reality. For the first time in our history the proceeds of assets sales, estimated to be just over $1 billion, are included as a major item in reducing the deficit. No matter what defences the Treasurer may mount to excuse the inclusion of asset sales in this manner, he knows perfectly well that it is contrary to all normal accounting practice to use the sale of a capital item as an offset against recurrent expenditure. Only the current Treasurer, with his scant regard for financial integrity, would allow the Commonwealth to stoop to this new form of creative accounting.

It is also abundantly obvious that the transfer of extraordinary profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia is the other major factor contributing to the artificial reduction of the deficit. It is anticipated that Reserve Bank profits for the coming year will total $2.7 billion, plus a further $0.2 billion from the profits of the Royal Australian Mint. When the extraordinary element of the profit transfer from the Reserve Bank and the Mint is added to the total expected from the sale of assets, the underlying deficit is really about $2.5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.

—It is; it is quite alarming. The House should also be disturbed to note that the similar profits made by the Reserve Bank over the past financial year stem, in large measure, from its speculative role in shoring up the Australian dollar. Are we to assume then that in the coming year the Government again intends to make a killing on Reserve Bank profits by creating another crisis of confidence in the Australian dollar? At worst this is a most irresponsible manner in which to conduct a nation's monetary affairs and at best demonstrates a very blinkered view of economic responsibility. As in so many other aspects of its economic management the Government's presentation of the deficit is more a matter of public relations than of the normally rigid strictures of public finance.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to turn away from this Government's slick presentation of this highly suspect Budget to the very serious questions that arise from consideration of the major underlying economic indicators for Australia. It is the terrible direction in which these indicators are heading that has so rightly worried Senator Walsh and caused him to speak of possible involvement by the International Monetary Fund in Australia's financial affairs. Other serious commentators have also given tongue to their concern about these indicators, and we in this House would be neglectful of our duty if we did not share that same concern.

I turn now to examine the alarming state of several of those indicators. I consider first the fact that the Australian dollar has lost approximately one-third of its value since this Government was elected to office on 5 March 1983. No matter what language this loss of value in our dollar is dressed up in, including the short term benefit to exports, the fact remains that the value accorded by the international community to a nation's currency is a reflection of how it values the credibility and strength of that nation's economy. The fact that the Australian dollar has fallen from 95c against the United States dollar on the last day in office of the Fraser Liberal Government, to its record low of 59.8c on 31 July 1986, then to the present figure of just over 73c, gives little cause for celebration by Australians. It has always been an economic truism that a weak currency reflects a weak economy, and the Treasurer has never been able to provide any significantly compelling arguments that would alter that damning judgment. In fact, his common argument that the fall is only because the Australian dollar has been floated only reinforces the point that I have made.

The fundamental weakness of the Australian economy is at its most transparent in the consistent failure of the Labor Government's fiscal policy to control inflation. Our inflation rate continues at a level well above that of other Western nations and that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average. In 1984-85 Australia's inflation rate was running at 5.8 per cent. Yet in marked contrast in the United Kingdom it was 5.5 per cent, the United States 3.9 per cent, Canada 3.8 per cent and West Germany 2.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes the gloss off this Budget.

—It most certainly does, and shows it for what it is. The OECD average rate was only 4.7 per cent. By 1985-86 the discrepancy had become even more noticeable. Our inflation rate was 8.4 per cent, while in the United Kingdom it was 4.9 per cent, the United States 2.9 per cent, Canada 4 per cent and in West Germany, an extraordinarily low 1.1 per cent. For 1985-86 the OECD average rate was 3.6 per cent. As we moved to 1986-87 Australia's inflation rate had climbed to 9.3 per cent, while in the United Kingdom it was 3.6 per cent, the United States 2.2 per cent, Canada 4.3 per cent and West Germany minus 0.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget Papers for the coming year forecast an increase in the consumer price index of 7 per cent. However, no realistic justification is given for this optimistic outlook on events yet to come. The mere fact that in those same Budget Papers average weekly earnings are expected to increase by 6.5 per cent, well above the rates of our competitors in world markets, must alone raise heavy doubts as to the estimated inflation rate for 1987-88. Yet again the Government's concern with imagery blinds it to the realities of the market-place.

In similar vein the Government has optimistically predicted that investment in plant and equipment will increase by 3 per cent in real terms in the coming financial year. It yet again offers little detailed argument to support this hopeful outlook. In this context it must be recalled that investment has in fact declined significantly in the last two financial years, taxes remain high, the Government's wages policy is not designed to put us in a competitive position, and this Government has never provided any significant incentive to investment in plant and equipment. It seems that this Government has always regarded incentives for investment in plant and equipment in the same slanted way in which the Treasurer has previously regarded negative gearing, that is, all such incentives are rorts. The false assumptions upon which the Budget is based again show up in relation to the productivity estimate. Last year productivity, like investment, fell. Yet somehow the Government produces a positive estimate which is not sustainable in argument.

Undoubtedly one of the most disturbing underlying indicators in Australia's economic situation is the state of our balance of payments. Both components, the balance of trade and the balance on current account, have declined dramatically since this Government was elected. The balance of trade has, for instance, fallen from a surplus of $185m in 1983-84 to a $1.9 billion deficit in 1986-87. Under Labor, the balance on current account has doubled to gargantuan proportions. In 1983-84 the deficit for the balance on current account was $7.3 billion and by 1986-87 the deficit had shot up to $13.6 billion. It is these figures and their uncertain future in 1987-88 that have so troubled Senator Walsh. As he clearly understands, this appalling situation reflects Australia's acutely non-competitive position in world trading. This arises directly from the profligate spending of the Government, most especially in its first two years of office, and the excessive wage increases it has encouraged its mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions to seek.

If the irresponsible economic policies have put our competitive position to shame, it is nothing to the extent that they have eroded our national sovereignty by putting us in hock to the international community. In June 1983, the year the Liberal Party lost government, Australia's total gross debt was $35 billion, or 21 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). Interest payments to service that debt totalled $2.75 billion. At the end of March 1987 Australia's total gross debt had grown to a mammoth $109 billion, a huge 42.7 per cent of our gross domestic product. The interest payments we were paying to service this millstone around our neck totalled $8.2 billion. Today it is estimated that our foreign debt bill comes to a staggering $113 billion and is growing at the crazy rate of $1 billion a month.

It can therefore be seen that after nearly five years of this big spending, big taxing Labor government, our foreign debt has grown by nearly $80 billion and our level of debt as a percentage of gross domestic product has increased by nearly one further quarter of GDP. The result is that we now pay $5.5 billion more in interest on debt than we did in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's money down the drain.

—It most certainly is, and it cannot be recovered, except by a Liberal Government. The seriousness of our foreign debt problem was highlighted in the latter half of 1986 when, on 10 December, Moody's Investor Services took away Australia's AAA credit rating and on 3 December Standard and Poor's did likewise. Australia had only ever had a AAA rating, and in losing this we joined the ignominious club of only three other nations ever to lose a AAA credit rating.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is like a shining glasshouse, having a superficial beauty but insulated from the tempest rising outside. Its artificial assumptions, like plates of immaculate but fragile glass, will shatter as the storm pressure rises. One cannot run permissive fiscal, monetary and wages policies, as this Government has done since first elected, while that absolute measurement of a nation's well-being, its competitive position in the world, continues drastically to deteriorate. One cannot take charge of one's own destiny to resolve these problems, economically or politically, while failing to tackle vigorously the foreign debt bill that is systematically eroding one's national sovereignty. In this Budget the Government has again pursued rhetoric over reality, and all Australians will ultimately pay for that cowardly choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government's Appropriation Bills, or what honourable members opposite, prior to the July election, referred to as the horror Budget. While it is generally agreed that, in politics, people have short memories, I feel that the history of this Budget is worth recalling for several reasons. From the outset of the last Federal election campaign, the Opposition's advertising managers were anxious to repeat their tactic in the 1984 election of scaring the people into voting for the conservative parties. Honourable members opposite surely must remember, to their constant shame, the underhand trick of causing undue anxiety in the minds of pensioners over the assets test. In exactly the same way, the rumour mongering began the day the election was called. The question was asked subtly by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), `What is the Government trying to hide? Why an election before the Budget?'. But of course he was only too happy to answer that question: the Government wanted to hand down a horror Budget with extra taxes, greater government spending and every other unpalatable nasty one could think of.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Tuesday night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) handed down this so-called horror Budget and from that Budget we can tell a lot about the credibility and quality of both the Government and the Opposition. Last Tuesday, this Government balanced the nation's Budget effectively for the first time in 17 years. We did it without any increase in taxes and without any undue hardship or difficulty to any segment of the community. Following this amazing effort, what was the reaction of those opposite? They claimed, `not enough cuts', `an easy Budget', `a soft Budget', and `a missed opportunity'. Certainly, the Government appears unable to win by those standards. When there is no election we cannot be trusted because we will be too hard. When we honour our promises we are accused of going soft and being complacent. Fortunately, however, the double standards of the Opposition were recognised from the outset by the voters of this country. That is why we are here again in greater numbers occupying the treasury bench.

Perhaps the most revealing criticism is the charge that last Tuesday night we missed an opportunity. What opportunity was that? Obviously a Budget three years before the next election will not require the same thought as one put before the poll-at least that is how the Liberal and National parties would think. That is the type of tactic-the `election Budget'-that has given politics and politicians a bad name. The electorate has become used to the pre-election sweeteners. For the rest of the time the parties were committed to Budget cuts and stringent measures. It is true that in the last few years the circumstances have warranted a great deal of economic belt tightening. That is not an exercise which any government, let alone a Labor government, likes to do. It is certainly not electorally popular and one wins no extra votes from it. Nonetheless, it is an important exercise and one that must be engaged in properly if the long term interests of the nation are to be served.

We have made those difficult decisions in the past. We have angered some of our traditional supporters in doing so, but we have done it because to have done any less would have been to sell our future short. But what is the Opposition's response? More cuts, more savings, more hardship. In the Labor Government's view, that response is simply not good enough. We fought the election campaign on the basis that, by our hard work and sacrifice, we had turned the corner and that, while times were still difficult, we were through the worst of it. Despite the fact that we face no election, it is not the aim of this Government to bring down a harsh Budget just for the sake of it. By this Budget, the Government is showing its confidence in its pre-election forecast that the economy is clawing its way back. So much so, in fact, that we can start to address responsibly some of the areas of the social wage which the times have prevented us from doing. We have always vowed to the people that we would restore government initiatives in social services when we were able to do so in an economically responsible way. We are now in the position to do so.

This Budget heralds the fulfillment of one of our election promises, namely the elimination of child poverty by 1990. At a time when our opponents are saying to cut harder, cut deeper, this Government is committed to living up to our moral as well as our economic responsibilities. From Christmas this year, half a million families will be better off, the benefits going to assist over one million children. Assistance will be in the form of cash payments, income tested, of $22 a week for each child, with $28 a week going to help subsidise the higher costs of providing for 13- 14- and 15-year-olds. There is also $15 a week rent assistance for low income families renting privately. Let us contrast this with what the Opposition had promised prior to the election. In the fine print of the `fistful of dollars' policy, we quickly found that the big winners were the rich. In addition to eliminating the taxes on capital gains and fringe benefits, it was those on higher incomes who had the most to gain from a Liberal win. The vast majority gained little. Certainly, there was not much appeal in such a grab bag of tax lurks to the people of my electorate of Banks. The Labor way is to give back money to those most in need of it; certainly there can be none more needing of it than children, living on or below the poverty line, and their families.

I would now like to take up one of the arguments of the Leader of the Opposition. His claim is that somehow the figures are rubbery, that there is something dishonest in their presentation, that, in fact, the Budget is not balanced. He suggests a number of reasons for this. Firstly, he argues that more taxation has a great part to play in the balance of this Budget. This is true, but what he fails to do is to convince us that the new tax measures are wrong. I remember the Treasurer being bombarded with abuse by members opposite about the fringe benefits tax, or what they termed the `farewell Bob tax'. The public, we were told, would not wear it; they would see the tax as a fine on incentive and would reject the Government outright for it. We were told that capital gains tax was another disincentive to hard work and gaining higher income. Well, they were wrong, hopelessly wrong, as is proven by our presence here today. The people of Australia have looked at our offerings in tax reform and have agreed that we were right. If our tax take is higher, it is only because we are rightfully assessing as income money which for years had been ignored. Why should free lunches, free cars, lower interest loans and the like be ignored? They are benefits which ordinary workers have to buy with hard earned cash. Now, at last, they are being assessed and taxed like any other income.

The same goes for capital gains. Money derived from shares or property sales is money just the same. It buys goods and services just as easily as money earned through work. Why then should it not be taxed as well? It simply does not make sense to argue that the figures are rubbery, that there is a dishonesty in having collected so much tax. If there is a dishonesty anywhere, it is with the people opposite who for years ignored the problem of leaving the average worker to shoulder more and more of the tax burden. A reasonable and just tax base has been re-established, and so government receipts are now properly in order.

Secondly, the Opposition, in one of its more memorable exercises in double standards, insists that government assets sales cannot be counted towards reducing the deficit. This is in spite of every rule of accounting procedures, and indeed against the practices of members of the Opposition themselves. When the Government, any government, buys an asset, it is written off on the ledger as a cost to revenue-money had to be acquired somewhere to acquire the asset. It follows logically, as night follows day, as the shadow Treasurer was once fond of saying, that any sale of an asset should be written up as a corresponding increase in revenue. Certainly, this is the procedure adopted in all other nations when drawing up Budgets, whether they be for householders or nations. It was most definitely the procedure the Leader of the Opposition used in every Budget he ever brought down. Even more importantly, it is the procedure he would no doubt follow if he were ever to become Prime Minister. The Opposition has often openly advocated the sale of government held assets, ostensibly to improve productivity, but also to reduce the deficit. I have not seen the Leader of the Opposition criticise the accounting methods of Mrs Thatcher. It seems that when a conservative leader engages in such practices, it is a noble effort to improve competition. When his opponents do it, they are engaging in a vain short term attempt to aid the economy. Which story is true?

Finally, the Opposition would argue that Reserve Bank profits made during fluctuations of the Australian dollar cannot be credited. These profits will not be repeated, it is suggested, and so therefore cannot be put on the positive side of the scale. How can this be when so much of all economic decision-making is based upon considerations and factors with only short term effect? Certainly we would not be hoping for a return to the wild daily fluctuations of the dollar which gave rise to the profits. Yet, nonetheless, those circumstances arose, and one fortunate by-product was a surplus for the Reserve Bank.

We deal in other short and long run situations which create the need for immediate answers. At the moment, we are dealing with a decline in our terms of trade that has seen $96m slashed from our national income. We have made substantial cuts in many areas of government spending to accommodate that problem. Some of those cuts have been difficult to make, like the six weeks delay in pension rises. They have been necessary, however, for the economy's good and so we have initiated them, even if only in the short term. But the savings in expenditure for that time are no less real than the profits we are now in receipt of from the Reserve Bank.

In the coming year, this Government will deal with an entirely new set of problems. No doubt there will be difficulties and boons which we could not have foreseen, but in our usual professional way we will deal with them. One thing remains certain: the Leader of the Opposition claimed two years ago that the times would suit him. The world and Australia's trade difficulties should have made the last election an easy one for the Opposition. Yet the people of Australia resoundingly rejected its policies of hardship and despair, shabbily masked by a grab bag of so-called tax incentives.

Now the times will suit us. Labor has seen us through the bad times. Labor will see this nation through to the good times again. But the future we look to is one of equal opportunity for all classes, with all sections of the community benefiting from the nation's prosperity, not just those rich enough to have cushy salary packages and capital gains. To this end, the Government's Budget looks towards growth and development in the long term, while seeing to the present needs of the poor and less well off. It is a Budget which justly honours the commitments and promises which Labor made to the people during the election.

I shall now turn briefly to the Government's intention to proceed with the introduction of the Australia Card, because of its future budgetary implications and because this matter has been raised on quite a number of occasions during this debate by members on both sides of the House. The Australia Card will bring to the Commonwealth additional revenue of at least $1 billion each year following its introduction. This revenue will come from those people who, at the present time, are not paying income tax on earnings or are not declaring interest or dividends or capital gains, and it will do away with double dipping in the welfare area. It is sheer hypocrisy by the Opposition to oppose such a measure, because on the one hand it criticises the Government for not reducing the social welfare allocations, while on the other it opposes the single most efficient method of achieving such a result. By its actions, it is protecting welfare and taxation cheats.

Additional revenue of $1 billion received after the introduction of the Australia Card will assist in further reducing taxation and enable the Government to fund further worthy projects in education, employment, et cetera, and to be in a position to more adequately target welfare assistance to those on the lower end of the income scale. The Opposition is creating fear and confusion in the minds of many people in the community by its nefarious statements in relation to the Australia Card. Honest, law abiding citizens have nothing to fear from the measure and indeed will gain from its introduction. They will realise its benefits, because it will bring fairness and equity to their way of living. I fully support the Government's actions in proceeding to implement the Australia Card. I am proud to be part of a government which has not shirked its responsibilities in taking the hard decisions necessary to take Australia through these difficult economic times and to reverse the disastrous position left to us by the Opposition in 1983. I commend the Budget Bill to the House.
