TALK.START.PARA: —I shall disgress a little from the Appropriation Bill at the start. As I will not have the opportunity of participating in the Address-in-Reply debate, I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to convey to Madam Speaker and the Chairman of Committees my congratulations to them on their appointment to those very high and responsible offices. In a spirit of fairness, I think that both of them did an excellent job in the last Parliament and that, in the week and a half that we have been here, they have indicated that they are going to do an excellent job in this Parliament. To you, personally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I extend my congratulations on the position to which you have again been appointed, that of a Deputy Chairman of Committees. I was most impressed by your tolerance, leadership and ability to calm troubled waters in the last Parliament and I hope that those splendid talents that you possess will rub off on your fellow Deputy Chairmen of Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: I also ask you to convey my congratulations to all the honourable members who have made their maiden speeches. I thought that on each and every occasion they gave thoughtful and courteous maiden speeches. It is not easy to stand up in this Parliament and convey to the people of Australia the reasons why one has offered oneself for selection and what one hopes to achieve here. We have lots of talent, and it will be with a great deal of interest that I trace the progress of the new honourable members on the ladder of fame, from whichever side of Parliament they come. I apologise for transgressing from the Appropriation Bill to what is more fittingly said during the debate on the Address-in-Reply, but I will not have the opportunity to speak in that debate and I think that these things are important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your comments are noted.

—I want to address the Appropriation Bill on several matters. I would like to open this part of my speech by mentioning the Budget brought down by the Federal Government last week. A balanced Budget generally attracts favourable comment. Therefore, in the light of the fact that, in the first analysis, this Budget did indeed appear to be balanced, the vast majority of Australians believed it to be acceptable. Under closer investigation, however, one discovers that there are certain flaws in the ideological structure of the Budget plan. Of paramount important are the questions surrounding the accounting system, such as it is. Informed critics at the time thought that the failure of the Budget was the fact that it did not bite into spending cuts. With reference to this issue, let me echo some of the problems outlined by Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, over the weekend. First, in Monday's Australian Financial Review, Senator Walsh was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I am worried that the Budget has been oversold and it will make the public and the Government complacent.

Senator Walsh is worried, as I am and as I am sure lots of Australians are, that the Budget did no go far enough to cut expenditure, which is needed in order for Australia to be bailed out of what I believe is a precarious economic position. Last week's Budget provided a sterling opportunity for the Government to initiate expenditure restraints necessary to build up savings able to be used to pay off our very high external debt. Alas, and Australia will suffer on account of this, it neglected to take this initiative, preferring merely to take the irresponsible measure of making the picture look brighter than it is without having the foresight to recognise what effect this action might have on the future.

Commentators believe that a feature of the Budget was the receipt side. The prominence given to this issue, however, has taken emphasis away from the far more important issue of our external debt. No steps have been taken actively to reduce the debt. The Government, for its part, has failed to set a pace of economic adjustment to counteract the deficit. Therefore, it has effectively lost a year in which this problem can be addressed and, in turn, rectified. Without attention, in a year's time this debt will have increased and accordingly the problem will be exacerbated. In sum, therefore, our economic situation will be far worse than it is now. In the light of this argument and what has happened in this Parliament and outside since, I believe that, on balance, Senator Walsh's view is correct.

Let me now depart from the issue of the Budget and approach the great debate of socialism versus free enterprise, because of its Budget implications. In recent years, there has been too much expectation of governments doing everything. Increasingly, people are not prepared to make sacrifices to do things themselves or to give displays of what was common in the earlier years of Australia-namely, mateship. There are many records of Australian mateship. Last Saturday I presided at the centenary of German settlement in a village in my electorate. In reading the history of the German settlement-and this applies to Irish, United Kingdom and, I suspect, all settlements in Australia-a strong emphasis on the family emerges as does a willingness to help and to share in times of adversity and of plenty, and the fact that the last thing those people thought of was going to the government for help. It is disappointing to think that we do not have that type of rugged individualism and the mentality of getting on with the job of looking after ourselves. That is now replaced by the fact that the moment someone is in trouble he or she thinks, `What can the Government do to help me?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The handout mentality.
—It is as the honourable members says. I want to take a more philosophical stance on the issue. In the words of Terrence Hawkes, the well-known English cognitive scientist of repute:

SPEECH.PARA: The physics of man reveals that men have created themselves. That is, man reconstructs the myths, the social institutions, virtually the whole world as he perceives it, and in doing so, he constructs himself.

In the light of this pronouncement the issue here is not whether we should be socialists or free enterprising. The point I am trying to make is that we should stand by the ideals that we create for ourselves. Nowadays too many people align themselves with the values of the free enterprise system yet, in times of trouble, they are willing to change their allegiance to be bailed out of trouble.

A genuine free enterpriser should be steadfast in the faith up to the very point where money may be made or lost. If he or she, however, rushes hell for breakfast to the Government, he or she is not honest. Given that, one must have a certain admiration for the honest socialist who lives by the ideals he espouses. I do not agree with his ideals but I acknowledge that he believes in government intervention and he wears that on his sleeve. An instance of a group claiming to be free enterprise is the great Australia company the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I recall that as a member of the Fraser-Anthony Ministry, after a very detailed analysis of that company's position, we injected a huge sum of Commonwealth money into the company for a variety of reasons. But we found that the moment it got the money, instead of getting itself out of trouble, it gave that money-the taxpayers' money-to improved conditions for the working people.

Another instance which is part of the coalition policy is that there should be no payment for inspection services. We believe that this is a waste of taxpayers' money when these things should be self-regulating. An example is the chemical residue in meat passed by the Australian Inspection Service. When the meat arrived overseas, people there found there was a problem and would not buy it. So why the hang should we have an inspection service here? It should be a matter between buyer and seller on the old-fashioned concept that a handshake seals the deal. I do not want to criticise my fellow primary producers. They are free enterprise people. But there should be no inspection services provided by government at cost. It should be done by industry. The moment these people got into trouble with the chemical residue problem, which had nothing to do with the Government, they went crying to the Government, `Bale us out of trouble'. I can understand their doing that. But I say, `If you are a free enterprise person, for God's sake be a free enterprise person. If you are a socialist, be a socialist. You cannot be a bit of both. Be a free enterprise person, not a closet socialist'. I say that as a very firm philosophical comment.

We need to have a greater mechanism for bringing responsibility home to people. I will not be very popular in the States for saying this but I am not in the business of being popular; I am in the business of helping Australia now and in the future. I always get upset when State governments of whatever political faith condemn the central government here in Canberra for levying too much taxation but, on the other hand, are always asking for increased handouts. Again, it is the free enterprise-socialist argument: one must be one or the other. I submit that surely in this day and age it is not an unreasonable attitude to suggest that we copy the Canadian system. It is a simple one in which the provinces indicate what percentage of taxation they want raised and that appears on people's assessment notices. At least it brings a bit of honesty into the system and gets away from politics and a cheap political campaign based on trying to achieve popularity but not worrying about the people or conditions out there or trying to create more employment.

Another issue I want to address primarily concerns the Government's approach to the election campaign. It was merely a response to the polls. I readily admit that the Government was far more sophisticated and refined in its electioneering techniques. In effect the Government is like the person who wins an Olympic gold medal. It was hungry for victory and was prepared to make the sacrifices and the effort. It knew how it could win and it stuck to the job. I do not want to buy into the argument of why my side of politics did not win. The first of the two major faults to which I wish to refer was the Government's pre-occupation with political strategy and tactics as opposed to the real issues. I admit that by doing that it won. Parliament was dissolved under the guise of the Australia Card issue. Yet at no time during the election campaign did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) debate the issue. It is nonsense to say that the Government has a mandate to initiate the Australia Card policy which is a massive invasion of privacy.

The Government should have been obliged to debate the issue on its merits and attempt to sell it to the Australian people. We have only to look at the polls. Those opposite have not sold anything to the people. They have not targeted that problem. Each poll indicates that fewer people want to accept Big Brother looking over their shoulders. As Australian citizens, surely they have the right to decide whether they should have the Australia Card. Instead, the campaign merely became a competition of sorts among political personalities. For my part and for the future of Australia and the voters to follow, I plead for a deeply negative public response to the present preoccupation with electoral tactics and strategy. Let us hear about the issues and be informed when candidates seek to avoid them. Let all political strategists remain far in the background where, I submit, they belong.

The second fault to which I will refer today is the all-pervasive power of the media. A multitude of lenses have been focused on this power with an overwhelming response drawing us to the conclusion that the media have the potential to dictate public opinion. Within the sphere of politics specifically, election campaigns, opinion polls and so on are used by the media as the avenue for influencing public opinion. The media are playing along with the Government in its game of personalities and therefore neglect to report the real issues. Polls also give a persuasive if spurious aspect of neutrality, spurious because they favour the front runner until the day, when in the frequent manner of such phenomena they are proved to be wrong.

Let me now move on to the penultimate issue I wish to address today; that is, the role of the arts in our society. I am disappointed that there has been less funding for the arts in the Appropriation Bill. Too often the arts are looked upon as being vulnerable without a role to play in the effective running of our society. But I suggest that contrary to this popular opinion, the arts play an intrinsic role. As a nation we have always prided ourselves on encouraging and developing fine sportsmen and women as well as producing premium quality primary products and manufactured goods. The arts, however, have always been seen as the poor cousin of these major achievements. This neglect of the arts sadly is characteristic of our own society, as history illustrates clearly.

If we delve into the past we will see how the arts have actually added to the economic product of the nation. Let me cite a few cases of historical significance. Firstly, in the sixteenth century no one contributed so consistently to economic activity as did Shakespeare. Another example, from the seventeenth century, is Moliere. In our modern times are Messrs Gilbert and Sullivan and George Gershwin. I raise the question: what now does the future hold for our artists, painters and poets? What will the future think of the economic input of such people as David Williamson, Sir Sidney Nolan and Bruce Dawe, Australia's foremost poet, who lectures at the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education in Toowoomba? Furthermore, the artist is also vital to ordinary industrial progress in the modern world. The basic point is a simple one-after utility comes design; after things work well, people want them to look well. Design depends not alone on the availability of artists, it invokes depth and quality of the whole artistic tradition. It is on this that modern industrial success has come to depend. In the context of these contributions that the arts make to society, it is imperative that the Government, in return, fulfils its obligations to the arts. The obligations of the Government to the arts is threefold: firstly, it must provide for the education of artists; secondly, it must support the arts, both financially and intellectually; and, thirdly, it must support the cutting edge of innovation to sustain ad interim what only time will make commercially rewarding.

During the final stages of this speech I wish to deal with the issue of mediocrity, specifically as it is displayed by the Government and, more generally, how it is encouraged by our society. Let me return to the point I made earlier in my address regarding the Budget. I noted that the Budget has certain flaws in its ideological construction. This is a direct result of the Government's failure to attempt to achieve economic recovery. This failure on the part of the Government to achieve the best possible results for the country forces its efforts, at best, to be labelled mediocre. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) certainly supports this view. According to the Concise Oxford Dictionary, on page 756 mediocre is defined as `of middling quality, indifferent, neither good nor bad'. What better words could one wish for to describe the Budget of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? The Government's Budget overall continues towards a philosophy of mediocrity. What an example to set for the rest of Australia-if you know you cannot do it, do not even try. Sadly, the rest of Australia seems to be following this example and is adhering to this philosophy of mediocrity.

Let me cite a few examples where this philosophy is in practice. First of all, there is our education system. No longer does it encourage our children to aspire to, let alone achieve, excellence. They are merely encouraged to do their best. I suggest that they do not know what their best is until they are pushed. Therefore, our education system forces our children-the adults and leaders of the future-to pursue mediocrity. Secondly, we have such events as Australia's premier horse event, the Melbourne Cup. This is a race whereby the best horse is penalised with a handicapping weight in order to bring it back to the level of the other horses. The great Australian foot race, the Stawell Gift, is not off scratch. We do not want a Ben Johnson to win, rather we give people a start. We do not look for the best, we always try to give the lightweight the opportunity of beating the champion.

Some other matters are: public interest in the fiasco surrounding the managing directorship of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in September last year. We brought Mr Geoffrey Whitehead out from England via New Zealand. He made a hell of a mess of the ABC. What did we say instead of sacking him? We said, `Well done, fellow, here is a hand out of $200,000'. David Armstrong made a muck of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. We did not sack him. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said, `Err on the side of generosity in paying him out'. We did. The Australian taxpayer paid him $504,000 for making a muck of things. We are not about that; we are about the pursuit of excellence, not mediocrity. We should go over to East Germany to see the great pride it has when its athletes win.

The present Government is guilty. It seeks to penalise those people who have been successful by imposing additional tax burdens. I ask the question: are the rich a dirty secret? What is wrong with the creation of wealth and the creation of jobs adding to Australia's export income and decreasing its overseas debt? Today voters are highly politically literate. They know when someone is talking down to them and they do not like it. It is about time the Prime Minister and the Treasurer stopped talking down to people. In the final analysis, it remains clear that good gardening needs a master gardener. In the Prime Minister and the Treasurer we certainly do not have master gardeners, we have two duds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, firstly, I congratulate you on being re-appointed as a Deputy Chairman of Committees. It is pleasing to see your smiling face in the chair. I ask you to pass on my congratulations to the Speaker and the Chairman of Committees on their re-election.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very reassured that the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) has rejected the Budget on the grounds of ideology. If he had accepted it on the grounds of ideology, I would have been greatly concerned. I was interested in his analogy of the Melbourne Cup and Stawell Gift. I ponder just a little in comparing the Stawell Gift and the Melbourne Cup to the Queensland electoral system and the present gerrymander that exists there. I wonder about the principle of a handicap in that event.

The Government has achieved a Budget outcome unprecedented in recent times. The deficit of $27m is the lowest as a proportion of the total economy in the 35 years for which comparable records are available. This compares with the deficit in prospect for the year 1983-84 of nearly $10 billion when the Government took office. It represents a reduction from 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to virtually zero. This year we will see the first net retirement of Commonwealth overseas debt since 1980-81. It is the first redemption of external and domestic bonds in the same year for over 50 years. All has been accomplished with no increases in taxes and with no new taxes announced in the Budget. For the business community in particular the Budget satisfies all its economic expectations. No longer does the deficit exist as an all purpose cop out for a failure to invest. Accordingly, a 5 per cent increase in business investment is forecast. There is no reason why this should not occur. Also of interest is the announcement in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of a review of the business taxation system. He stated:
The overriding objective of this review is to identify options for financing reductions in the company tax rate through sensible broadening-
I stress the word broadening-
of the company income tax base.
At this stage I refer honourable members to an article in the Australian Financial Review dated Monday, 21 September. It is headed, `Australian taxes low by OECD standards'. It states:
Australia had the fifth-lowest level of taxes of the 23 OECD nations . . .

I think there is a need in the debate about taxes to project these sorts of comparisons with other nations. It galls me just a little when we hear the continual cry from the other side that Australia is a high taxing nation. It is about time that the Australian community is presented with the facts in a genuine debate on this issue. The article continues:
The only OECD nations with a lower tax take are the US . . . Spain . . . Japan . . . and Turkey . . .

But of interest, as this article outlines, is that if we take into account social security levies borne by corporations, Australian companies get off comparatively very lightly. The article continues:
On this basis, the tax burden of Australian companies was the second-lowest in the OECD.
Once social security levies borne by employers are added in, Australian companies enjoyed the second-lowest tax burden in the OECD in 1985-86, paying 2.8 per cent of GDP.

The myths of high tax need to be dispelled. The problem is that in the loose way we compare tax rates we do not account for the various degrees of differences in tax and welfare systems of nations. In many nations corporations pay levies to provide welfare, whereas we pay for our health, community services and other services through general revenue. It is necessary when we compare Australian tax levels with those of other nations to take account of those factors.

One of the more important aspects of the Budget is the family assistance package. As the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech, this is a `landmark' social reform. The family assistance package is one of the aspects of the Government's policy speech, which was delivered before the last election, that gave me the most pleasure. For many of the families living in an electorate such as Scullin the family assistance package will be of great importance. It is necessary to stress that the aim of the family package is to enable the children in low income families to have equal access to and equity in the rich resources that Australia has to offer. Part of the Government's overall strategy is to have, by 1990, a scenario in which no children live in poverty. I think that all honourable members would applaud that ideal and that goal.

The package which we will introduce before Christmas will affect over half a million families in need and give added benefit to more than one million children. The new scheme will provide a family allowance supplement of $22 a week per child. The package recognises the higher costs associated with teenage children. For each child aged 13, 14 or 15 the benefit will be $28 a week. In addition, there will be rental assistance for families renting privately, with an extra allowance of up to $15 a week. The Treasurer stated in his Budget Speech:

This means, for example, that families with incomes up to $324 per week who rent privately and have three children, two aged under 13 and one 14, will receive a supplement of $87 per week free of tax.

That represents $69 a week more than these families would have received under the old family income supplement. This should be compared with the $20.46 that they were offered under the discredited tax policies which the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia presented at the last election.

When we speak of the need to introduce measures such as the family assistance package, it is necessary also to dwell on aspects of wealth distribution in Australian society. In fulfilling a commitment that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty, it gives me, and I am sure many Government members, no pleasure to concede that the level of poverty has continued to increase over the past decade. But we should compare that fact with the recent revelations about the wealth of a privileged few in Australian society. Although I do not wish to dwell in a doctrinaire way on that aspect in this debate, I want to bring to the attention of honourable members an interesting editorial in the Australian Financial Review of Thursday, 10 September 1987. It is an interesting exposition of the need for public interest in wealth distribution and honourable members should read it carefully. It followed revelations in different business journals about those Australians who had become billionaires. The editorial makes this point:
Wealth of this kind has been derived from Australian enterprises which employ hundreds of thousands of people and whose welfare is therefore of national concern.

It develops the point that many of those people who have become, in the editorial's words, the `new rich' have a distinct responsibility to place importance on the welfare of Australia in general. The editorial states:
Rightly or wrongly, attention is being focussed on what is seen as a growing disparity in the distribution of wealth in Australian society.
It makes this point:
It is not good enough to say that the ambitions and activities of someone who owns $1 billion of Australia's wealth is none of the public's business.
The use of that money cannot only change the entire character of a local industry, it is also capable of altering the national economic structure.
The editorial makes a point which is perhaps debatable but which I repeat for the information of honourable members:
Personal wealth is a reflection of the potential opportunities offered by a free society-
I stress the following point-
but it also means that those who acquire it have some obligation to the society which encouraged their success.

As I said previously, I feel that the Government will have to consider the need, as stated via the party platform, at least to have a proper inquiry into Australia's wealth-into its distribution and origins and into how much is owned or controlled by overseas interests. It is in Australia's interest that we have a rational debate on these issues to see ways in which we may address some of the imbalances which are developing between the haves and have nots in Australian society.

Another important aspect of the Budget is the Government's continuing development of its policies and aid in a number of important industries-steel, heavy engineering and textile, clothing and footwear, to name a few. The Government's record since 1983 shows that, in a slow but sure way, it has addressed many of those industries which had perhaps become a bit flabby and needed to be investigated to ensure that they play the most productive part they can in the Australian economy.

I welcome the recent joint announcement by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) of a new policy for the pharmaceuticals industry. Although it is small compared with other Australian industries, it is very important. It is one in which Australians have been to the fore in developing new ideas and which exemplifies the need for Australia to heighten its research and development. Because of the way in which drugs and other factors impinge on our pharmaceutical benefits scheme in terms of drug prices, and so on, it is important that we consider the recently announced measures in the pharmaceutical package. We need to provide the most effective drugs at the least cost to the Australian community to insure Australia's health.

It is also of interest to note that great emphasis has been placed in the Budget on the need to have industry policies which are interleaved with training policies. In Budget related Paper No. 9 under the heading `Skills Formation in Australia' the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has put up for public debate a series of options and points about skills training in Australia.

Another document which is now circulating needs proper debate. It is entitled Australia Reconstructed and is the report of the combined Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and Trade Development Council mission to Western Europe. Whilst I will not dwell on the overall aspects of that in this debate, we might get some opportunity to do so later. All honourable members should embrace this document and look at some of the alternative ways in which Australia can put itself back on a stable road. The Budget's main emphasis on expanding training is to be welcomed. It provides a solid basis for the consolidation of the Labor movement's successes in industry policy and it gives scope for industry development plans as indicated in the ACTU strategy document to be discussed.

I want to make a small observation about our tendency in the education field to place great emphasis on skills training. We should not blind ourselves and think that this is the only role education has in Australia. Simon Marginson, in a document entitled Education System: Public Education and Equality, placed on record four roles of education. The first is the allocation of credentials. The second is the indirect contribution to economic development through the fostering of knowledge, skills, creativity and the experience of working with others; and specific vocational training. The third is culture. The fourth is political development. He said that, although most emphasis is placed on economic aspects, all four dimensions are important. In referring to the contribution to economic development he made this point:

. . . there is debate about whether students should be seen simply as `human capital' without any control over their future economic lives, or as conscious and active people who will themselves shape the future economy.
In our careful way as we develop these training packages we will need to take into consideration the individual's needs as well.

As I said earlier, now more than ever the climate for investment has been created. Unfortunately for some, the pursuit of macroeconomic goals has become an end in itself. Such people have forgotten that government is about people, not statistics. Already some individuals have suggested that we need to proceed further down the road of spending cuts. The ideologue of the New Right, Andrew Hay, stated that the major weakness of the Budget is its failure to cut deeper into spending. Others such as the Executive Director of the Victorian Employers Federation, Ian Spicer, are anticipating a surplus in 1988-89.

One of the most vexatious features of our current political process is that when the expectations of the business and financial community are not only met but exceeded it takes only hours for revised and more extreme demands to emerge. In no time we will hear from the extreme Right calls for further savage cuts lest Australia degenerate into a Third World dictatorship. The Government must ignore this cacophony of self-interest and greed. Surely we have come to the end of that road. Australia is at the crossroads. The Budget is all but balanced. It is now time for us to set off in earnest down a different road where macroeconomics considerations are combined with the vigorous pursuit of social justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) has just said that there is a tendency for the macroeconomic considerations of the Budget to become an end in themselves to the neglect of other considerations. I put to the honourable member that getting the macroeconomic framework right is essential. It is not the only matter that we have to devote our attention to but it is certainly a necessary condition. I want to direct my remarks primarily to that area. Last week was certainly the week of the balanced Budget and of an almost unprecedented Budget euphoria. It looked and sounded good. The money and foreign exchange markets reacted accordingly and very favourably: good for the Government and cheers for the markets. However, at the weekend the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, made his dash for truth. Now it does not sound so churlish to say, as I said on Budget night, that we have a patina of fiscal rectitude, a veneer, with the reality beneath the sheen not nearly so good.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget, as Senator Walsh said, has been `oversold'. For that read that the Australian people have been conned. The gloss given to the reality of this Budget in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) borders on the dishonest and the euphoria, I fear, is unlikely to last in the months ahead. In referring to misleading statements in this Budget I do not refer only to the several references-the first right up front in the speech-to this Hawke Government inheriting a prospective deficit of $10 billion, now `wiped out', as the Treasurer said preening himself. The truth is that, firstly, there never was any reality to such a deficit. I am not interested in letters such as the one the Treasurer read out to the House last week, doubtless from a self-serving public servant. Secondly, the deficit in the Government accounts right now has not been wiped out with this Budget. The actual position is an underlying deficit of the order of at least $1 billion; indeed, as a number of Opposition speakers have set out, it is more likely of the order of $2 billion to $2.5 billion.

The statements, the glosses in this Budget which, as I have said, are bordering on the dishonest, do not end there. Apart from misleading claims about the deficit, there is also the whole central claim that this is a Budget entirely appropriate to Australia's economic circumstances, a `blueprint for the continued national recovery of Australia', as one Government speaker has put it. That is a false claim. The Government has clearly gone soft on the resolve it demonstrated even last year in the wake of the Treasurer's banana republic perception and the characterisation of Australia's situation as `akin to war' by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Government has gone soft on the resolve it demonstrated then to come to grips with Australia's massive current account deficit imbalance and our vast, relentlessly rising overseas debt. We debated this matter yesterday, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will say at this point only that the Budget may be, as many have argued, broadly in the right direction-but, as my Senate colleague John Stone has put it, what is a step in the right direction when what is required is comprehensive and resolute action to stem this country's steady move into international bankruptcy? That is the central, the great issue.

Thirdly, turning to more specific claims of a misleading, indeed dishonest character, the `balanced' Budget has been achieved on the spending side of the equation by `a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending', the `biggest cut in the 35 years for which comparable records are available', a `cut in outlays by $3,500m'. I will examine that distortion of the language in a moment. The fourth dishonest claim to which I refer is on the other side of the Budget, the revenue side. The Treasurer averred, `We have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes'. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) and other members of the Government have dwelt on that point at length in this debate. To that I say, `Oh yes? Maybe there are no rate changes, at least in income tax although there are in indirect tax, but there is a very hefty increase in taxation in a real sense'.

The fifth of these misleading statements I particularly want to refer to is the proposal to repay $1 billion of Commonwealth overseas debt and the same amount of domestic bonds, with the proud boast being made by the Treasurer that `No other Commonwealth Government in more than 50 years has made repayments of both external and domestic debt in the same year'-the clear implication being that our debt situation is coming under control. In fact, that is entirely misleading. It is a cosmetic exercise. The obscure reference in the footnote on page 383 of Budget Paper No. 1, which refers to juggling the figures of major asset sales for `commercial confidence reasons', I believe provides a clue. In reality, the changes do not make an iota of difference to the crippling, perilous overall debt situation of this country.

I refer to the claim about `the biggest cut in Commonwealth spending in the 35 years for which comparable records are available'. I referred in the debate yesterday to pages 66 to 71 of Budget Paper No. 1 where we see set out a comprehensive list of expenditure cuts and two items among hundreds of snippets of spending cuts-cuts from, mind you, forward Estimates of expenditure, not actual expenditure-stand out. They hit us in the eye. The first of those is general purpose payments for the States, which have been cut by $1,000m-a real cut of upwards of 4 per cent, which I do not dispute. But when we work it out, Commonwealth spending in real terms on this Government's own activities will actually increase slightly. It is a case of knock the States; that is the easy way out.

The second point, a point I made yesterday, is that the real gloss, the really misleading point, is that asset sales of about $1 billion are shown as a negative outlay, for goodness sake. A projected $1 billion of asset sales makes up nearly one-third of the vaunted cuts in Commonwealth Government spending. That may be an international convention but when the sales are of that order in relation to the change in spending, it is nothing other than a tortuous usage of the language. It is patently dishonest to trumpet $3 billion-plus of cuts in Commonwealth spending. In plain terms, that is seen by the man in the street as an addition to revenue. In fact, the true place in the Budget for this is as a component in the financing of the deficit, not as a factor conditioning or reducting the deficit. The truth is that the Government has passed up the opportunity, tragically, to undertake some meaningful cutting of excessive government expenditure and thereby the opportunity to push ahead with the absolutely crucial adjustment process to reduce the external deficit and contain our crippling overseas debt. That is what had to be done.
The fourth dishonest claim I want to deal with is the Treasurer's gloss:
. . . we have adhered to our election commitment not to increase taxes . . .

The Budget Papers plainly show that the aggregate of income tax on individuals, including the Medicare levy, is projected to increase by $3.1 billion, or 8.1 per cent which is above the rate of inflation. That is a point I think you, Mr Deputy Speaker, addressed in the House the other day. When we add an income tax on companies, the increase is 9 per cent. That is despite the tax cuts of 1 December and 1 July. A major factor in that is the effect of so-called fiscal drag; that is, the effect of taxpayers moving into higher tax brackets. A person earning up to $19,500 per annum, or $390 a week, pays 29c in the dollar for any extra income earned, but if his income rises to say $22,000 per annum, or $440 a week, the rate on any additional income rises to 40c in the dollar. So his tax goes up very significantly. This has the effect, as we stressed during the election campaign, of making taxpayers, on average, pay substantially more of their income in taxes even after these cuts than when the Hawke Government came to office. As the leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out in his Budget reply, in 1987-88 the Government will collect an average of more than $230 extra from every Australian taxpayer. In no way is that a contribution to the incentive for increased effort and productivity which the precarious situation of this country calls for.

However, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would not be so churlish as not to acknowledge that the top rate of 49c in the dollar, or 50.25c including the Medicare levy, is a welcome improvement on the top rate of 60c, or 61.25c with the levy, of this time a year ago. It certainly is. But it is still too high. It is still an exploitative rate, a rate that invites avoidance and evasion and is inimical to incentive for increased effort and productivity. With the proper restraint of government expenditure marginal rates can be, as they must be, brought down much further. In the United States last year a top rate of 28c in the dollar, or 33c including the five points threshold abatement impost, was implemented by the Congress on a bipartisan Republican and Democrat basis. That was a great achievement. In the election campaign a top rate of 38c in the dollar was proposed by the Liberal and National parties. That rate is achievable and, for my part, I will not give up the advocacy of that or, in time, an even lower rate.

I come back to the Budget predictions. As I have said, there is a total of $3.1 billion in additional direct taxes on individuals and there are additional indirect taxes of nearly $1 billion, which again is up by 9 per cent excluding the crude oil levy. Just let me say this: since the Treasurer failed to win his consumption tax proposal at the 1985 Australian Taxation Summit, indirect taxes other than the crude levy have gone up, without any compensation to low income groups as would have occurred with a properly implemented consumption tax, by nearly $3 billion, or of the order of nearly 33 per cent. I put it to the House, and to the Australian people, that they would have been better off paying a properly structured consumption tax with compensation provisions built in. For my part, I remain an unrepentant advocate of such a tax.

So we have had this increase in the taxation of individuals, and an increase in indirect taxes-and increased rates are built into that automatically, despite the Treasurer's claim that there has been no increase in taxation. Finally, for companies, taxes are projected to increase by over $1 billion-an increase in the order of 13 per cent. This will result particularly from the larger than expected increase in fringe benefits tax. Yet the Government wonders about the continuing hesitancy in business investment. So we have this very large increase in receipts and when we add the very large, and not likely to continue, Reserve Bank of Australia profits, there is a total increase on the revenue side of the order of $6 billion. All in all, that is not a bad outcome, from the point of view of the Treasurer, in the context of his boast that this Government has adhered to its election committment not to increase taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Clayton's balancing of the Budget.

—My colleague is right; it is a Clayton's balancing of the Budget. The fifth point is the proposed reduction of $1 billion in the Commonwealth domestic and overseas debt. To quote the Treasurer's boast: `No other Commonwealth Government in more than 50 years has made repayments of both external and domestic debt in the same year'. So what? The whole exercise makes scarcely an iota of difference to this country's perilous overseas debt situation. The assets sales have been brought in to provide finance for the balancing of the Budget. Next we are told that some $3.7 billion of maturing Commonwealth bonds will come up during the year. We have the happy circumstances of an overfunding, to use the words of the Treasurer, of last year's deficit due to successful raisings and a lesser deficit outcome, and that resulted in a build-up of around $1 billion in the Commonwealth cash balances of the Reserve Bank. In effect, the Government proposes to roll over $2.7 billion of that maturing debt and to retire $1 billion using this last year's outcome. In addition, perhaps stimulated by the prospect of important assets sales overseas in Tokyo and Paris, the Government has decided to retire $1 billion of Commonwealth overseas debt.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the honourable members to note that, as the current account deficit continues very large, so the overseas debt still increases. That retiring of overseas debt only means that someone else has to borrow $1 billion in the Government's place, plus the extra borrowing to fund the currently accruing current account deficit.

Directly, or indirectly, this retiring of overseas debt is to be financed by an anticipated growth in 1987-88 of about $1.2 billion in the stock of treasury notes in non-official hands-in other words, an increase in short debt. So we end up with a balanced Budget; we have $1 billion less of assets abroad but we also have $1 billion less of debt so the net position is unchanged; and, domestically we have $1 billion more of short term debt and $1 billion less of long term debt.

As I have said, the net indebtedness of the Commonwealth is unchanged and the whole cosmetic exercise makes scarcely an iota of difference to this country's perilous overseas debt situation. That central issue has been barely addressed. We are relying on the rest of the world to continue to pick up the tab for our national overspending, our living beyond our means, if the rest of the world will-that is the big risk-and whether we go down the Argentinean road. Growth has been put before a more rapid containment of the current account deficit and the debt problem. The Treasurer and the Government will need sheer good luck, including the continuation of a favourable international environment, to get through this year maintaining the value of the Australian dollar, maintaining the decline in interest rates, plus any progress at all in the deficit and debt problem. As I said yesterday, this amounts to our losing a year in the long haul to contain the current account deficit and the overseas debt-that long haul back from the Argentinean road to a path of sound economic development.

I have to agree with some of the critics who have said that the Government appears concerned only with those areas of scientific research which can be immediately applied to boost export earnings. The spring issue of Ecos, the CSIRO magazine which deals with research findings in relation to the environment, covers a number of research projects, such as land degradation in the Murray-Darling Basin, the economic loss and environmental damage caused by rabbits; and the grave potential dangers for world populations of a warmer earth. Unfortunately, there is a tendency for some of my parliamentary colleagues to be rather scathing about basic research because there is no immediate and obvious return. I can only warn that if we continue to cut funds available for scientific research, whether those cuts are in CSIRO funding or in tertiary educational research funds, Australians as a whole will suffer the loss in the long term. Hopefully, the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) will promote this more positive method of using scarce resources to the best advantage.

Coming back to the Budget in general, I would like to concentrate the remainder of my speech on the proposed sale of public assets by some people both inside and outside our Party. The Budget includes asset sales of $1,000m, but I reject the argument by Opposition members-and that includes the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) who preceded me in this debate-that, as a consequence, the Budget is not truly balanced. Opposition members conveniently forget that the Budget includes repayments of $2,000m of Commonwealth Government internal and external debt. As the Treasurer has commented, and I commend him on this initiative, no other Commonwealth Government in more than 50 years has made repayments of both domestic and overseas debt in the same year. Let us hope that the private sector can be equally responsible, as it is the private sector which is largely responsible for the huge proportions of our overseas debt. The Government has produced a climate of lower interest rates and anticipated lower inflation. How long will it take the private sector to respond to this challenge with new investment? Its record has not been very good to date. It is precisely for this reason that I am concerned at the calls for the sale of public enterprises. I have no objection to the sale of surplus Government assets.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Pipeline Authority?

—But I am concerned when proposals are made to sell such vital enterprises as Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and Telecom Australia. I know that the honourable member for Bradfield is in favour of those proposals. I will explain why I am totally opposed to them. The philosophy of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has always been very clear in its overall public enterprise objective. The platform states:

SPEECH.PARA: The democratic socialisation of industry, production, distribution and exchange to the extent necessary to eliminate exploitation and other anti-social features.

That objective does not mean complete socialisation of industry, as we all recognise the realities of our mixed economy. But it does recognise the need to eliminate exploitation and other anti-social features in our economy. That is why it is so important that public enterprises which provide essential services to the Australian public should be preserved under public ownership.

I can remember the great debate within the Labor Party in 1981 and 1982. It was a debate in which I took some considerable part. Some people considered the socialisation of industry-or the socialist objective, as it was called-as a hindrance to winning government. The supporters of privatisation lost that philosophical argument at that time and they will lose the economic arguments now. It is in this context that I am taking the opportunity in this speech to strongly support one of the main objectives of Labor Party policy, namely:
. . . the establishment and development of public enterprises based upon Federal, State, and other forms of social ownership, in appropriate sectors of the economy.

Let me make it clear that I am not denying that in the economic climate of 1987 there is a grave shortage of capital resources in Australia. Airlines, banks and telecommunications industries are all industries requiring many hundreds of millions of dollars in new capital to provide the resources to compete with private enterprise and to provide services to the public. But the answer to the question, `Should the Commonwealth Government use some of its scarce resources to continue to develop our existing public enterprises' must, in my view, be a resounding yes.

As part of a democratic socialist philosophy there were three underlying practical aims for the adoption of public enterprise policies by the ALP in the 1920s. Those aims are as relevant today as they were when they were adopted in the 1920s. First was the need to supply public services to the people when private enterprise was not prepared to risk its capital because it could not see an immediate capital or profit gain. Second was the aim that public enterprise, by providing good quality products and services, with satisfactory working conditions and wages for its employees, could prevent exploitation by private corporations monopolising the market. Third was the aim that the profits of public enterprises could be used to supplement government revenue and enable a reduction in overall taxation. Yesterday my friend and colleague the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) indicated in a speech the large profits which many public corporations provide and which are used to bolster revenue. Of course, that too can reduce taxes. But what is also possible is that these profits, instead of going into revenue, could be used by those enterprises to invest in more capital. In that sense the Government, and conservative governments before the present Labor Government, have starved those institutions of funds. It took this Labor Government to provide an injection of capital, for example, to the Commonwealth Bank.

If Qantas, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank and Telecom were privatised, the loss to the Australian people would be fourfold. Firstly, all four corporations are profitable and could be made even more profitable if the Commonwealth Government was prepared to provide the necessary capital for their further development. If the corporations are sold to private interests the profits will be lost to public revenue and additional taxes will be required to make up the shortfall. Secondly, when public enterprises have been sold overseas they have been deliberately undervalued by investment analysts and sold at a heavy discount, with stock exchange investors reaping huge capital gains. Thirdly, these four public enterprises, having been developed with the aid of taxes of generations of Australian taxpayers, would be sold as existing profitable corporations to private industry. What a windfall for the new private owners! They are not required to risk their capital on developing the infrastructure costs associated with airlines, banks and the telecommunications industry; it is all to be handed to them on a platter, even if the enterprises are sold at a fair valuation, which, as I have explained, is most doubtful.

Fourthly, it is argued that the Commonwealth Government does not have the capital to continue to develop the four public corporations. In my view, this argument is the most deceptive of all because it is true only in the context of an economic strategy which gives dominance to market forces. This strategy presupposes the deregulation and the free flow of overseas investment into Australia are of long term benefit to all Australians. This argument, in my view, is seriously flawed. The continuous free flow of overseas investment is being used not for productive investment in Australia but for speculative ventures. Deregulation is allowing overseas currency speculators to dictate to Australia how our internal financial affairs are managed by the Government. Overseas financiers can decide that the Government should not be putting money into public enterprises and therefore they can cause a run on the Australian dollar. The value of the dollar would fall, interest rates would rise, business confidence would be eroded and the Government would be forced into an economic crisis.

The Government should accept that the time has come for us to fix the value of our dollar and to regulate exports and imports of capital so that we can have more control of our own financial affairs. In the above context it is a fallacious and self-serving argument to say that because we must balance our Budget we cannot provide the necessary capital to develop our public enterprises. Capital investments made now to produce future profits will be of benefit to all Australians. A Budget deficit used for such purposes is economically sound, despite the political opposition of overseas financiers.

Finally, if the public corporations concerned are to be sold to private investors, the necessary capital for the initial purchase and subsequent additional capital for development of those industries must come from somewhere. Since, on the Government's own analysis, the capital is not available in Australia, it must come from overseas. Thus the new private owners must borrow overseas capital and would, of necessity, also consider a rationalisation and amalgamation of the public enterprises with existing private enterprises.

How will all of this speculative capital affect our balance of payments? After an initial scramble amongst the millionaires, as was witnessed during the recent and continuing media take- overs, we could, for example, find that Ansett Airlines of Australia had swallowed Australian Airlines, Pan American World Airways had swallowed Qantas, L. M. Ericsson Pty Ltd had swallowed Telecom and the Westpac Banking Corporation had swallowed the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to newspaper articles suggesting that the Budget decision to tighten income test rules on friendly society bonds and other deferred income investments purchased on or after 1 January 1988 represents a 3 1/2-month postponement of income test action by the Department of Social Security. Is there any real basis to this statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the articles in question. Such reports show a lack of understanding of the way that the current income test applies to deferred income. Pensioners who are influenced by such articles or by financial advisers to place their funds in such investments before 1 January could regret that decision. They should be aware of the full facts. After 1 January the return accruing in each year will be treated as income received in that year in the same way as most capital guaranteed investments. The present income test allows the return in each year to accrue without effect on pension, but the entire return on the investment is treated as income when the investment matures or a withdrawal is made.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, a married pensioner couple who invest $10,000 in a 10-year bond producing an annual average return of 15 per cent would receive, on maturity of the bond, some $30,000 more than they had invested. That $30,000 would be regarded as income for pension purposes and would preclude the payment of any pension to the couple for a full period of 12 months. In other words short term gains can be more than offset in the longer term and institutions and advisers should ensure that this is fully understood by their clients when they are presenting a list of possible investments to pensioners and potential pensioners. The new approach will promote greater equity for clients and should be seen as a step towards further consistency in the treatment of investment income.

—Can the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support indicate to the House whether he has any intentions to further investigate the uniformity of road vehicle regulations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The lack of uniformity between States of road vehicle regulations still presents significant barriers to efficient transport within Australia. Certainly this is a major difficulty, as was referred to earlier this week by the Chief Justice of Western Australia. There are no less than 16 different authorities administering transport laws in different States and Territories in this nation. In fact, the Inter-State Commission has been investigating statutory provisions, regulations, rules and orders, by-laws, policies, practices, et cetera which adversely affect the efficiency of land and sea transport of goods and passengers between the States and quite recently published an information paper on road vehicle regulations as part of this investigation to increase efficiency. That paper shows the complex maze of regulations that impede road transport operators from understanding their responsibilities when they operate interstate.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a bewildering range of rules and regulations which apply and I am sure that every person in this House is aware of them. It is important-and it is one of the Government's high priorities-that we should seek to have a much more efficient transport infrastructure in this nation. The Inter-State Commission will be holding public hearings, starting in Canberra on 19 October, as part of the investigation into the uniformity of road vehicle regulations. I wish to stress again that increased efficiency in the nation's transport system is quite critical to our future economic development and security. We must get out of the mentality that we are simply administering complex systems of transport and into the business of transporting people and goods as efficiently, safely and quickly as we possibly can. I see increased uniformity in road transport regulations as a high priority and as a step in the right direction. I will be pursuing the appropriate industry forums and mechanisms to achieve this goal as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I have no advice as to whether the Government would want in this term to make a further attempt to amend those sections. My answer is that at this stage I have no knowledge of the matter. The carriage of amendments would be a matter within another portfolio. I think that I can give the assurance that there is no indication at this stage that we will try to do the impossible and convince the Opposition to change its mind. I would not be able to prevent normal legal action under sections 45d and 45e. If people feel that there is justification for taking action, they will take it. They do not need my consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for La Trobe for his question. He is a very keen member. He has been jumping up for several days trying to catch your attention, Madam Speaker. ANSWER.PARA: During the last Parliament the former Minister for Health, now the Minister for Community Services and Health, asked the Australian Consumers Association to investigate the issue. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition making a statement forthwith concerning the regulatory requirements of essential elements of the Australia Card legislation.

The Opposition believes that the Australia Card legislation is effectively dead and that it is incumbent on this Parliament today to give it a decent burial. The legislation is effectively dead for two reasons. The first is that it has been the subject of incompetent and slothful drafting and administration by the Minister responsible. The second, and more important, reason is that day by day what public support there was for the identity card legislation ebbs away from the Government. The evidence which we bring to the House today demonstrates beyond refutation that the legislation has serious technical flaws.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't beat that! Is he one of your mates?
—Order! That was certainly dramatic.

—The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will do anything to upstage me. The reason why the Opposition believes that the ID card legislation is effectively dead is to be found in a very careful reading of the Australia Card Bill 1986 [No. 3]. The operational clauses-40 to 54-specify the circumstances in which the card is to be produced and for what purposes. The clauses cover deposits and accounts with financial institutions, investments, the operation of trusts, primary production and rental income and foreign--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the House to come to order. It is very difficult for the Leader of the Opposition to be heard. He has to strain his voice because honourable members on both sides of the chamber are all talking. A little hush, please.

—Madam Speaker, the key and absolutely fatal weakness of the Government's Australia Card legislation is to be found in the very simple fact that the operational clauses of the Bill-that is, clauses 40 to 54-will not come into operation until what are classified in the legislation as the `relevant days'. Very crucially, those relevant days are not fixed by the legislation; they are not fixed by proclamation; they are not fixed by Executive decision or Executive announcement. Those two relevant days which are absolutely crucial to the coming in of the principal operational clauses of the Bill can be fixed only by regulation made under the legislation when it is passed by this Parliament. As every member of this House knows and as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) should have known, any regulations made under a Bill or an Act of this Parliament can be the subject of a disallowance motion by either the House of Representatives or the Senate of the Parliament of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Opposition I say that in the event of this legislation passing, in the event of its going through a joint sitting and becoming a law of this country, the Liberal and National Party senators in another place would vote to disallow any regulations which appointed relevant days under the legislation. I anticipate that on this issue the Australian Democrats would join the Liberal and National Party senators in voting to disallow those regulations. The House should be aware that if those regulations are disallowed major operational provisions of the Act cannot come into force. Although the Australia Card can be established, although the Register can be established, although all the elaborate apparatus related to the database can be established, although the Government can recruit the required 2,000 or more public servants and although the potential invasion of privacy will still be there, for all operational and practical purposes the Australia Card legislation will be dead. It will be absolutely stone dead unless those relevant days can be fixed.

I say to the House, Madam Speaker, that because of the way in which the Bill has been drafted there is no way on earth the present legislation can bring to fruition the Government's dream of having a national numbering system for every Australian. Let us remember that we have now had over 12 months of debate and argument in this country about this piece of legislation. It was last October when the Opposition parties said that they were against this legislation. In those 12 months we have had mounting opposition. What we have analysed and what we present to this Parliament is what we believe to be an irrefutable argument against the coming into operation, for practical purposes, of the legislation.

I repeat on behalf of the Opposition, Madam Speaker, that the Australia Card Bill is absolutely stone dead. What it deserves from this Parliament, what it deserves from the Government and what it ought to get from the Government is a decent burial. The Government ought not to have the effrontery ever to bring this legislation to this Parliament again. I repeat: If the Government brings forward regulations in the event of the Australia Card Bill being passed into law, the Liberal and National parties will vote in the Senate to disallow those regulations. If we are joined by the Democrats in the Senate those regulations will be disallowed and the Government's Bill will be worthless. The Australia Card legislation will not, for practical purposes, ever see the light of day and the Australian public can rest content in the knowledge that the Government of this country is in the hands of people who would allow such a tactical flaw and imperfection in this legislation with all the vast resources of the Attorney-General's Department at his disposal.

Have the Minister, with all the vast resources and the apparatus of all the Government funded servants of the Labor Party at his disposal, and the Attorney-General been able to discover this flaw? No. The Australian public has been deceived. People have been worried out of their wits about the Australia Card. They have been frightened. The Government has allowed a costly debate to go on in this country, yet it is revealed as having legislative feet of clay. The Government is revealed as not knowing the most elementary principles of how legislation should operate in this country. It is revealed as having misled the Australian public for months and months. I say to the Government: cut your losses, realise that you are beaten. You are beaten not only by the tactical flaws in your own legislation but most importantly, you have been beaten before the bar of public opinion in Australia. That is the most important and telling defeat that you have suffered on this legislation because this Bill will ultimately never become the effective law of this country, not so much because of its technical imperfections but because the Australian people are revulsed by it. The Australian people do not want it. If you try to ram it down the throats of the Australian people you will pay very dearly in political and other terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, Madam Speaker. I think that what everybody needs to understand is that there has been an increasing ground swell of public opinion around Australia about the implications of this draconian identity card legislation. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said, it is a piece of legislation that has not just emerged before the Parliament; we have expressed our concerns around Australia. In every town, village, city and suburb there are demonstrations about the implications of this piece of legislation as it effects the numbering and identification of ordinary Australians. We seek to ensure that the Australian people now know that as a result of the way in which this legislation has been drafted it never will come into place. If it is introduced and passed and if a great deal of money is spent by the Government in setting into place the computers, in putting into place the public servants, in documenting and photographing every Australian, the key element of this legislation that requires that before there can be any requirement to produce that identification card there shall be a nomination of a relevant day will be disallowed within the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague the Leader of the Opposition has said, the purport of the document which we seek to bring to the attention of the Parliament and which is the substance of this motion to suspend Standing Orders is that under clause 32 (1) of the Australia Card Bill there is reference to the first relevant day as follows:
``first relevant day'' means a day declared by the regulations to be the first relevant day for the purposes of this Part, not being a day that is earlier than 1 March 1989;

The second relevant day is the second relevant day for the purpose of that part. Individuals around Australia are concerned at the implications of the Bill. People will be called on to produce the card. Wherever the requirement to produce the identification card is set down in the legislation there is specific provision that refers to the relevant day. For example, clause 40 refers to financial institutions. It states that they shall not `on or after the first relevant day . . .'. In the clause dealing with investments it states that a `prescribed borrower-shall not on or after the first relevant day . . .' In the clause that deals with primary production and rental income it states that a marketing authority, produce agent, and real estate agent are all required `on or after the first relevant day . . .' The substance of this whole de- bacle into which the Government has led the Australian people is that it has produced a piece of legislation which can have effect only if a regulation declaring those relevant days is not disallowed by the Parliament of the Commonwealth or by either House of the Parliament.

It is important that everybody know that the paper tabled by the Leader of the Opposition today has fundamentally flawed the identity card proposal. We all know that the Government cannot amend the identity card proposal if it has a joint sitting. We have voted against the legislation in this place and we all know that in the Senate the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party, together with the Australian Democrats, will oppose the legislation subject to the consideration, by a committee, of clauses that have not yet had an opportunity to be examined-clauses containing amendments that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has referred to, that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has referred to and that Senator Ryan has referred to but that nobody in this place has seen. What we have said is that the legislation itself is draconian in its implications because no individual should properly be required in a democratic society to produce identification in the way that this legislation purports to do, and on that basis the relevant day regulations will be disallowed, and as they are disallowed so the whole of this sad and sorry escapade by the Government to try in some way to regulate and numerate individual Australians will come to an end.

It is important that Australians comprehend what the document tabled by the Leader of the Opposition this afternoon has done and why it is essential that we suspend Standing Orders. Everybody must recognise that the Leader of the Opposition today has produced a paper which says that unless the regulations can be passed to require those relevant days to be declared, the identity card legislation is finito. Might I say well may it rest; it will never rest in peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make this first point about the alleged defect in the Australia Card legislation: if there be an alleged defect in the legislation, it has arisen from this Government's determination to give the Parliament a full say in these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The two previous speakers were heard in silence. Honourable members will give the same courtesy to the Minister for Community Services and Health.

—Indeed, in a piece of legislation which was obviously going to receive considerable debate within this Parliament it was not possible to put down a specific date without allowing some flexibility, and of course that flexibility relates to the regulations passed by this Parliament. If proper debate was to be provided on the Australia Card issue, the legislation had to be framed in that way. So the alleged defect in the legislation relates to the decision of this Government to provide the fullest possible opportunities for debate on the Australia Card Bill in this society. That is why the particular clauses referred to by honourable members opposite were written in the way they were.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be quite clear that the Opposition parties have now decided that no matter whether the Government observes all the constitutional provisions-that is, takes the Bill through all the requirements of the Constitution-they will not accept that constitutionally made decision but will use this particular technical point to throw out the Bill.

Let me say what the Government has done. This Government has followed all the requirements of the Constitution in relation to the Australia Card Bill. It introduced the Bill into this House and received the support of the House, and of course the Bill was then rejected by the Senate for the first time. The Government again introduced the Bill into the House of Representatives; again it was supported by the House and then for the second time it was rejected by the Senate. The result is that the double dissolution provisions of the Constitution were brought into play. The Bill was taken to the electorate, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made it quite clear that when the Parliament returned there would be a joint session on the Australia Card Bill. We have again, under the proper provisions of the Constitution, introduced the Australia Card Bill and passed it through the House, and we will now take it to the Senate. If it should be rejected by the Senate, we will introduce the proper constitutional provision-that is, a joint session. If the Bill is passed by the joint session it will have observed all of the requirements of the Constitution. So it will be simply a political decision made by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats to deny the Government a Bill which has passed through all the constitutional provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should resign. You have maladministered the legislation.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence; the Minister should be heard in silence.

—That is what the Opposition is saying. I do not know what the attitude of the Democrats is, but the Opposition is saying it does not care whether we have observed every requirement provided for under the Australian Constitution; even if the Bill goes through all the processes laid down by the Constitution, including the joint session, it still will continue with a policy of negativism and obstruction, and it will deny the ability of the Government to enact a Bill which has passed through all the constitutional processes.
—Have a double dissolution on the regulations.
—Order! If the honourable member for Barker interjects again I will warn him.

—Let us not talk about a flaw in the legislation; let us talk about the constant commitment of the Opposition to deny the effectiveness of this measure, a major measure of our tax policy, by saying that even if we pass the Bill through all the proper constitutional provisions it will still try to throw it out or deny the effectiveness of the Bill. That is to deny all the constitutional processes under which this country has operated for 87 years.
