PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes a number of amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Act 1967 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Cash Bidding) Amendment Act 1985 which will improve the administration of petroleum exploration and development activities in Australian off-shore waters, correct some anomalies in the legislation and ensure that the option is available to the Joint Authority in the future to use cash bidding as a means of awarding exploration permits over highly prospective acreage.

In late 1985, the Government announced the outcome of its review of the 1979 off-shore constitutional settlement (OCS). The outcome was that the Government considered that the arrangements entered into by the Commonwealth with the States and the Northern Territory to administer activities in Australia's off-shore waters were working satisfactorily, and the Government therefore decided not to take action to regain title over the territorial sea and coastal waters. The review of the OCS did, however, identify certain administrative functions in the Commonwealth's off-shore petroleum legislation which required change. These changes are to repeal the special arrangement with Western Australia whereby disagreements in the Joint Authority-the Commonwealth and relevant State Minister-are resolved on a Premier-Prime Minister basis; and to allow those matters which were previously dealt with by the Joint Authority at the discretion of the Commonwealth Minister, to become automatically matters for Joint Authority decision.

The Government's decision to abolish the special arrangement for resolving disagreements within the Western Australia Joint Authority reflects the Government's view that the treatment of the States and Northern Territory under the off-shore petroleum legislation should be uniform. This Government rejects the claim upon which this special Western Australian arrangement is based-that is, that the economic importance of petroleum and related activity to Western Australia places that State in a unique position. Rather, the Government considers that the importance of off-shore petroleum operations to Western Australia is no greater than that of other States or the Northern Territory.

Our experience has been that, where a Joint Authority has been involved in decisions, the consultative provisions of the off-shore petroleum legislation which are generally applicable have proved entirely satisfactory. Under these general provisions, which are to be retained in the legislation, Joint Authority decisions are made after consultation between senior Ministers of the respective Governments, and the consultative process provides ample scope for full consideration of all factors relevant to the interests of the Commonwealth and to the States and the Northern Territory, and the resolution of any differences of view. If, after consultation, disagreement remains within the Joint Authority, then, consistent with the Commonwealth's responsibilities, the Commonwealth Minister may decide the matter.

The second issue arising from the Government's OCS review also relates to Joint Authority decision making. Under present arrangements some matters, for example, the award of exploration permits, must be referred by the designated authority-the State or Northern Territory Minister-to the Joint Authority, while other matters, for example, inviting applications for the award of exploration permits, may be referred to the Joint Authority at the discretion of the Commonwealth Minister. Because decisions of the designated authority in the latter category have the potential to be referred to the Joint Authority, it has become practice for these matters to be dealt with administratively as if they must be decided by the Joint Authority. This practice has evolved in order to avoid the significant administrative delays which would otherwise occur if the Commonwealth Minister were to decide that a matter should be referred to the Joint Authority. The amendments contained principally in clauses 5 and 13 and in the schedule of the Bill will formally make the Joint Authority automatically responsible for these matters. A further consideration in the Government's decision to refer all these matters to the Joint Authority has been the apparent confusion, particularly for new companies wishing to undertake off-shore petroleum operations, about which authority is responsible for the decisions on such matters.

A number of other amendments contained in the Bill are, like those relating to the OCS arrangements, being introduced to improve administration of off-shore petroleum activities and to remove some anomalies in the legislation. Under the current legislation, a location can be declared over a petroleum discovery in an exploration permit only if the location contains a block in which an exploratory well has been drilled and from which petroleum has been recovered. This has led to the situation where a discovery which straddles a permit boundary, and for which only one exploratory well has been drilled, cannot be fully developed. This arises because a location can be declared only in the permit in which the exploratory well has been drilled and, hence, subsequent production licences or retention leases cannot be granted over the whole discovery. While the problem could be overcome by drilling a second exploratory well in the other permit, this practice may not be justified economically or technically.

A further difficulty with the current legislation is that the size of a location is generally set at nine blocks. In many instances, this size is much larger than necessary to cover the discovery, though, on occasions the nine block location has been too small to cover some very large gas discoveries. To overcome these difficulties, clause 9 of the Bill amends the current legislation to allow the Joint Authority to declare a location over any block from which the Joint Authority is satisfied petroleum can be recovered. The Joint Authority will also be able to declare a location over as many blocks as is necessary to cover the discovery. The Bill also provides for the expansion or reduction of a location area if further information indicates a change in the extent of the petroleum discovery.

Clauses 6, 8 and 10 of the Bill will repeal what are known as `over-the-counter' awards of permits and production licences. If, following the advertising of invitations for the grant of an exploration permit or production licence over an area, the Joint Authority decides not to grant a title or grants a title over part of the area then, under existing legislation, there is provision for the Joint Authority to accept applications for the award of a title over the area or any remaining part of the area. The Government believes that the most efficient approach to the award of off-shore titles is by competitive tendering. Given this principle and the regular release of off-shore petroleum acreage, the Government sees no need for `over-the-counter' awards of titles.

The amendments contained in clause 11 of the Bill follow representations from petroleum companies. Under existing legislation, applications to register a dealing affecting the interests in a title under section 81 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act must be accompanied by an instrument evidencing the dealing and an instrument prescribed in regulations, if any. The instrument evidencing the dealing is available for public inspection and, as these instruments can contain sensitive contractual information, a number of companies have sought protection for this confidential information.

The Government shares the industry's concerns and the amendments seek to provide adequate protection for confidential information while safeguarding the public interest. This is achieved by providing companies with an option of submitting the prescribed instrument mentioned above. Where the prescribed instrument is lodged with a registration application then this instrument, rather than the instrument evidencing the dealing, will be available for public inspection. In the case where companies elect not to lodge a prescribed instrument, the existing legislative approach applies-that is, the instrument evidencing the dealing will be available for public inspection. In this way, it will be open to the companies to decide what documents should remain confidential, but it is expected that companies will take advantage of the new arrangements only where it is clear that the release of any confidential information contained in the document would be detrimental to the company.

The regulation which sets out the particulars of the prescribed instrument will ensure that, in the public interest, all necessary details are included. These details of the dealing include the parties to it, the title affected by it, the nature of the transaction and the value of the consideration upon which registration fees are based. Industry has objected to the inclusion of the value of the consideration of the dealing in the prescribed instrument, arguing that this information is commercially sensitive. However, given that the registration fee is based on the value of the consideration of the dealing, the Government believes, in the interests of public accountability, that the consideration should remain a requirement of the prescribed instrument.

Industry has also argued that these amendments should be applied retrospectively to instruments evidencing dealings which have already been approved. This would have the effect of removing documents from public inspection. Because these documents have already been available for public inspection, the Government's view is that they no longer have a confidential status. In addition, a retrospective application of the amendments could impose a significant administrative burden on some designated authorities.

Clause 14 of the Bill relates to the 1985 amendments to section 118 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act which provided for the early release of basic data and interpretive information supplied by title holders to government, subject to appeals provisions relating to the release of interpretive information after five years. It was the Government's intention that these amendments to section 118 should apply to data and information supplied both before and after the amendments were proclaimed on 22 July 1985. The amending legislation was, however, defective in that the new section 118 provisions do not apply to data and information supplied before the date of proclamation. As the early release of information facilitates a better understanding of the petroleum potential of off-shore areas and, consequently, encourages further exploration activity, the Government wishes to rectify the situation and clause 14 amends the Act appropriately. Release of commercially sensitive information would of course be subject to the usual appeals provisions set out in the Act.

Following a recent review of procedures relating to the verification of royalty collections by the Australian Auditor-General's Office, it has become necessary for the Commonwealth to clarify its rights to obtain documents related to off-shore petroleum operations. Under the current legislation the Commonwealth Minister is able to acquire copies of documents received by the designated authority, but is unable to direct the designated authority as to what documents and records the producers should be required to keep and make available. The proposed amendment at clause 15 will correct this deficiency and thus ensure that the Commonwealth is able to obtain all documentation necessary to ensure that its responsibility in relation to the collection of royalties on petroleum production are met.

Prior to the proclamation of the 1985 amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Act, fees payable upon the registration of a transfer under section 78 or a dealing under section 81 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act were calculated on the basis of 1.5 per cent of the consideration or value of the title affected by the transaction or, if the transaction was related to a previous dealing for which the 1.5 per cent fee had already been paid, a flat $300 fee. An unintended transitional consequence of the 1985 amendments to the Fees Act has been that a dealing registered under the principal Act prior to the proclamation of the above amendments on 22 July 1985 may not be recognised as a related prior dealing for the purposes of reducing the fee payable. The clause 18 amendment will rectify this situation and will ensure that, where appropriate, the flat $300 fee will be charged.

The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Cash Bidding) Amendment Act 1985, which came into force on 22 November 1985, is currently subject to a two-year sunset clause. If the Act is to continue in force, Parliament needs to re-endorse its support for the cash bidding system. The Government has completed a review of the effectiveness of cash bidding and proposes in clause 19 of this Bill to remove the sunset clause.

The cash bidding system provides an alternative to the work program system as a means of awarding petroleum exploration permits in highly prospective areas. The Government's aim by introducing cash bidding was to provide an efficient and equitable system of permit award-an objective which on past experience was not being met by the work program system in circumstances where competition was intense. For the two-year trial period, the use of cash bidding has been confined to the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent areas, consistent with the Government's agreement with the State and Northern Territory governments that the use of cash bidding in other off-shore adjacent areas would await the review of the operation of the system in the Territory of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent area. In this way, it would be possible for an assessment to be made of the concerns that had been expressed by sections of the exploration industry and certain State governments and the Northern Territory about the impact of the cash bidding system.

These particular concerns were that the cash bidding system: would decrease exploration activity because of reduced funds and increased risks and costs; would disadvantage small to medium size Australian companies; and was inconsistent with the resource rent tax (RRT). The review has assessed these concerns in the light of experience of the first and, to date, only cash bidding release of off-shore petroleum exploration acreage in the Timor Sea region of the Territory of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent area. Applications for five highly prospective areas in this region were invited on 25 November 1985 and closed on 28 February 1986.

A total of six eligible bids, from consortia involving 16 companies, for four of the five areas were received. Three consortia were successful. Offers of permit award were made by the Joint Authority to these three successful consortia on 3 March 1986, with all three consortia accepting the offers within the allowable 30 days. The permits, AC/P5, AC/P6 and AC/P7, were formally granted on 4 April 1986 for a single six-year term. The successful bids totalled over $31.5m with all successful bids being at least $10m.

Given that applications for the above areas were invited just prior to the collapse in world oil prices, the results of this cash bid round were particularly pleasing. The size and number of bids clearly showed that companies saw good prospects for satisfactory commercial returns from the areas offered despite considerable uncertainty surrounding the world crude oil market outlook. In addition, the award process represented a considerable streamlining of administrative effort. Applications were able to be assessed and permits awarded in a little over one month. This compares with the three to four months needed to process applications and award permits under the work program system.

The criticism concerning the impact on exploration activity suggested that cash bids would adversely affect exploration activity either in other areas held by the companies or in the cash bid permits themselves. While the impact on the former cannot be assessed, the evidence suggests that the level of exploration activity in the cash bid permits is not significantly different from that in work program permits awarded in late 1985 and in 1986. The three cash bid permits have been in force for nearly 18 months, and in that time seismic surveys have been completed in AC/P5, 385 line kilometres; AC/P6, 550 line kilometres; and AC/P7, 1,387 line kilometres. This work is expected to lead to drilling activity in the second year of the permits, activity which no doubt has been deferred because of the collapse in oil prices-a fact which has affected exploration activity world wide.

Another claim made at the time the legislation was introduced into Parliament was that cash bidding would increase the risks and costs of exploration. At the time, the Government argued that in assessing whether to lodge a cash bid, companies would take into account the expected risks and costs involved in exploring in a permit, and the size of their bid would reflect that calculation. The cash bid, in itself, would not affect the risks or the costs involved; rather, it is the risks and costs which would influence the size of the bid.

Further, the Government argued that it could be expected that the cash bidding system would reduce the risks and cost facing companies compared with the work program system. Under the cash bidding system, companies are free to undertake the most commercially viable exploration program consistent with the prevailing economic conditions and prospectivity assessments. Under the work program system, however, companies are committed to an exploration program designed up to three years in advance and must face the considerable risk that changing circumstances will make that exploration program uneconomic.

The Government's arguments have been vindicated. The evidence is that companies involved in over 39 per cent of active work program permits have sought deferments of commitments following the collapse in oil prices at the beginning of 1986. This has involved considerable administrative effort on the part of governments and companies. The companies in the cash bid permits have, on the other hand, been free to assess their position in the light of the dramatically changed world oil market.

Cash bidding was also criticised because it was expected that large foreign companies would dominate the bidding. The Government has always acknowledged that it would be difficult for smaller companies to participate in off-shore exploration because of the costs and risks involved. Regardless of the award system for exploration permits the stronger companies could be expected to dominate. The Government did note, however, that it expected no change to the existing practice in the industry-namely, that consortia including Australian companies would be formed to bid for permits.

The first cash bid release has confirmed the Government's judgment. Of the three successful consortia, each has Australian interests of 40 per cent or more-the average Australian ownership over the three permits being 62.7 per cent. Of the 11 companies involved in the successful consortia, six are Australian including some small to medium-sized firms. Over the total bidding round, there were 16 companies of which nine were Australian. The evidence, therefore, suggests that Australian companies are not being discriminated against in their attempts to explore in highly prospective areas because of the introduction of the cash bidding system.

The claim that cash bidding is inconsistent with RRT cannot be established objectively but, rather, is a philosophical question. The Government views the RRT and cash bidding system of awarding exploration rights as complementary measures-namely, together they collect for the community a share of the economic rent resulting from the exploration for, and the exploitation of, Australia's petroleum resources. This is a view shared by a number of other countries.

The review has, therefore, concluded that: the cash bidding system has met the Government's objective of providing a more efficient and less regulatory system of award and administration of exploration permits than the work program system; there is no evidence available to suggest that exploration activity has declined because of the use of cash bidding; there is sufficient evidence to suggest that Australian companies are not disadvantaged by the cash bidding system; and there is no justification for the claim that cash bidding is inconsistent with RRT.

Despite the conclusions of this review and the demonstrated willingness of the industry to participate in the cash bidding system, the industry remains opposed to the system. Further, some States and the Northern Territory are not yet convinced of its merits although all are concerned that they should receive a share of any cash bids. The Government, however, is convinced that cash bidding is superior to the work program system as a means of permit award in circumstances where competition is expected to be intense because of the high prospectivity of the areas on offer. The Government supports the continued use of the cash bidding system and will maintain its commitment to the States and the Northern Territory to consult them before permits in their adjacent areas are proposed for release under the system.

All of the amendments, except for the repeal of the cash bidding sunset clause, are not expected to have any financial impact nor will any of the amendments increase regulation in the petroleum exploration and development industry. In the case of the cash bidding amendment, the level of revenue that might be raised by the award of permits under the cash bidding system cannot be estimated as it will depend on the number of areas released during each financial year and the industry's appraisal of and response to the acreage released.

The proposed amendments contained in this Bill have been the subject of consultation with the States, the Northern Territory, and the industry, and with a few exceptions the amendments have general support. The amendments are essential to the effective and efficient administration of the Commonwealth's offshore petroleum legislation and I commend the Bill to the House. I also present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend several sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1984 to implement, in relation to the Australian Wheat Board, certain provisions of the Government's policy on the reform of statutory marketing authorities and to incorporate in the Act provisions consistent with the Government's policy on equal employment opportunity.

The majority of the Government's proposals outlined in the White Paper, `Reform of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities', which was released in January 1986, were incorporated in an amendment to the wheat marketing legislation last year. One area of that policy which was not fully addressed at that time was the funding of industry organisations by the Board. The Government's position is that where there is a requirement for consultations between a statutory marketing authority and its industry, decisions on payments to the industry for those consultations should be left to the authority concerned. However, because the funds of statutory marketing authorities are derived from either grower levies or from the sale of a compulsorily-acquired product, it has been considered desirable that guidelines be issued to ensure that any moneys paid to industry organisations will be for consultations consistent with the statutory objectives and functions of the authority. In particular, such moneys should not be available for agro-political purposes. The Bill provides for the issue of such guidelines to the Board and subject to those guidelines for it to meet expenses additional to travel incurred by the Grains Council of Australia in relation to consultations with the Board. The Board is already accountable to growers through a statutory requirement for members to consult at least annually with the Grains Council to present the Board's annual report.

The proposed guidelines would restrict the level of funding to 50 per cent of the Grains Council's operational expenditure in any one year. Details will need to be included in the Board's annual operational plan and financial statements. The Board will also be able, if it wishes, to meet the travel expenses only of any person or body with whom it consults for the purpose of carrying out its functions.
Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2)

The Bill provides that the composition of the Australian Wheat Board Selection Committee will be consistent with the policy in the White Paper that such committees comprise only an independent chairperson and representatives of the relevant industry who have been nominated by the nationally recognised industry body. The current provisions of the Act, which were put in place prior to the development of that policy, allow for the Chairman of the Board and two representatives of the National Farmers Federation to also be members of the Committee. This approach was adopted in the belief that a broad-based committee would be better able to select the most capable and effective persons to be members of the Board. While that Committee fulfilled its responsibilities in a highly satisfactory manner, it is nevertheless considered desirable that the situation for the Board should be consistent with the guidelines established in the White Paper on statutory marketing authorities, that those who finance an authority should be represented on the Committee which determines who will be recommended to the Minister for appointment. To further ensure the objectivity of the selection process, it is essential that membership of the Committee is independent from the membership of the Board. It is therefore proposed that the representatives of the National Farmers Federation and the Chairman of the Board will no longer be members of the Committee. The National Farmers Federation and the Grains Council are agreeable to this change.

Should it be considered desirable for the Chairperson of the Australian Wheat Board to continue to be consulted in order for the Committee to have a better understanding of the qualities necessary for a person to be an effective Board member, then such a requirement could be incorporated in the selection criteria issued to the Committee or in the terms and conditions of appointment of the presiding member.

Finally, the Bill provides for the Board to develop and implement an equal employment opportunity program which is consistent with the Government's policies being progressively introduced for other Commonwealth authorities. Details of such programs will need to be included in the Board's corporate and annual operational plans and in its annual report to Parliament. I would point out that the Board already has recognised the need to be a progressive employer and has reflected this in its corporate objectives. Part of its strategies to meet this objective is the development and implementation of an equal employment opportunity program.

The proposed amendments should not involve any additional Commonwealth costs or revenue. They are being put forward as part of the program of implementing the reform of statutory marketing authorities. The benefits of these reforms are already evident in the operations of other major authorities. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the income tax law to give effect to a number of earlier announcements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), some of which were foreshadowed in a draft exposure Bill released on 4 June 1987, and to some Budget initiatives. They include measures designed primarily to prevent abuses of the new imputation system of company tax, and changes to the capital gains, superannuation deductions and gift provisions of the income tax law and the taxing arrangements for certain educational allowances. Two Budget announcements to be given effect by the Bill vary the level of the rebates of tax available to recipients of certain Commonwealth benefits or allowances, and provide for the calculation of 1987-88 provisional tax. The Bill will also amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to make it clear that certain earlier amending action modifying State and Territory limitation laws applied to additional tax for late payment. Finally, the Bill will remove the existing requirement to impose annually provisional tax or instalments of company tax. I will now outline in more detail the significant measures in the Bill.
Franked Dividends Paid as Part of a Dividend Stripping Operation

This Bill will introduce anti-avoidance provisions to combat dividend stripping operations that seek to exploit benefits provided under the imputation system. The Government's intention to introduce such measures was made clear in the Treasurer's announcement of 10 December 1986 which outlined the imputation system now in operation, and the measures were contained in the draft Bill released by the Treasurer on 4 June 1987. Under imputation, the franking rebate will mean that resident individuals and certain trustees will effectively receive franked dividends tax free. The potential double benefit for such taxpayers of both a tax deduction for the cost of shares purchased in a dividend strip, and a rebate on the dividends distributed on the shares, is similar to that which was available to companies prior to the introduction of legislation to limit or deny the intercorporate dividend rebate in cases involving dividend stripping.

To prevent such abuse of the imputation system this Bill will deny the entitlement of resident individuals and certain trustees to a franking rebate where dividends are paid as part of a dividend stripping operation. To deter companies from engaging in dividend stripping schemes to gain the benefit of franking credits, and to prevent individuals and trustees who otherwise would be denied a franking rebate under the measure proposed from achieving the same end by interposing a corporate structure, the Bill will also deny franking credits to companies where dividends are paid in the course of a dividend stripping operation.
Dividend Stripping Schemes

Another measure contained in the draft Bill released on 4 June 1987, and now included in this Bill, will extend the present rules relating to dividend stripping operations that give rise to an income gain or loss, by limiting or denying the entitlement of a resident company to the intercorporate dividend rebate in respect of a dividend paid after 4 June 1987 as part of a dividend stripping operation which gives rise to a capital gain or loss. The measures proposed will ensure that the cost base of shares or other relevant property acquired as part of a dividend stripping operation is offset against dividend income in determining entitlement to a rebate. A rebate will be denied in such cases where they involve the payment of a dividend to an associate of the dividend stripper.
Asset Revaluation Dividend Schemes

The Treasurer's announcement on 4 June 1987 also foreshadowed the introduction of legislation to counter certain schemes which seek to avoid income tax properly payable on the disposal of assets by means of the payment of rebatable dividends out of profits arising from the revaluation of the assets concerned.

This Bill will deny the intercorporate dividend rebate in respect of a dividend paid, after 4 June 1987, out of profits arising from the revaluation of an asset which is disposed of, or an interest in which is disposed of, either by the sale of shares in the company holding the asset or by the sale of an interest in an entity which has a beneficial shareholding in that company. The proposed measures will apply only where the company that revalues an asset is not listed on a stock exchange, and its revalued assets are not less than 75 per cent of the net worth of the company at the time of disposal of the shares or other relevant property. These measures will also apply to corporate unit trusts and public trading trusts that are taxed as companies under the income tax law.
Tax Avoidance by Private Companies

Sections 108 and 109 of the Income Tax Assessment Act are designed to prevent avoidance of tax by private companies and their shareholders at the shareholder level by disguising dividends as non-taxable loans or advances, and at the corporate level by disguising dividends as tax deductible remuneration. Although the scope for avoidance in this area has been diminished under the imputation system, the need for these provisions remains. Accordingly, as foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 4 June 1987, these provisions will be amended by this Bill so that, while preserving their originally intended purpose, technical deficiencies that have prevented their proper application will be remedied.
Capital Gains Tax: Change of Residence

The Bill will give effect to the announcement on 23 December 1986 that two changes would be made to the capital gains and capital losses provisions of the income tax law in relation to taxpayers who cease to be Australian residents. First, the existing law will be modified where a taxpayer has been an Australian resident for a total period of less than five years in the 10 years preceding the time he or she ceases to be a resident. In these cases the rules which deem certain assets to have been disposed of on change of residence will not apply to assets owned at the time the taxpayer last became a resident or to assets acquired by the taxpayer since that time as a result of the death of a person. The second change will enable a taxpayer to elect that the deemed disposal rules not apply to the assets that otherwise would be taken to have been disposed of.
Capital Gains Tax: Distributions by a Trustee

The Bill will also implement the change announced on 17 December 1986 where a taxpayer receives a distribution of certain tax-free income as a beneficiary or unit holder of a trust. This amendment ensures that, in calculating capital gains, the cost base of the interest or units in the trust will no longer be reduced by that part of a tax free distribution which represents income freed from tax by the allowance of certain building depreciation deductions. By this measure, trusts will be able to pass on the benefits of depreciation allowances on income producing buildings to beneficiaries or unit holders.
Capital Gains Tax: Bonus Shares and Bonus Units

Another amendment gives effect to the announcement made on 10 December 1986 to change the capital gains tax treatment of partly paid bonus shares and bonus units issued after 1 p.m. on that day. The existing law treats bonus shares and most bonus units as having been acquired when the original shares or units were acquired. Under the existing law, where original shares or units were acquired before 20 September 1985, the issue of partly paid bonus shares or units can potentially confer capital gains tax exempt status on new investments made after 19 September 1985-for example, through the payment of calls of capital in respect of the partly paid shares or units. In such cases, the date of acquisition of the bonus shares or bonus units will now be taken to be the date on which the liability to make the first such payment arose.

This Bill will also implement changes announced on 10 December 1986 in relation to bonus shares issued after 30 June 1987 where some or all of their paid-up value is a dividend. The effect will be that such bonus shares issued after 30 June 1987 will be subject to the capital gains tax provisions irrespective of the date of acquisition of the original shares in respect of which the bonus shares were issued. A reliable estimate of the revenue effect of these capital gains tax related amendments cannot be ascertained.
Deductions for contributions to superannuation funds for certain gainfully employed persons

The Bill will give effect to the Treasurer's announcement of 22 December 1986 that employees would not lose the deduction available-which is set at a maximum of $1,500 per year-for their contributions to private superannuation funds by reason only that they are the subject of superannuation benefits provided by an employer as a result of an agreement of the kind referred to by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in its national wage case decision of 26 June 1986.

The amendments made by this Bill will apply to cases where the employer-provided superannuation cover is under an agreement made or ratified by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, or a State industrial tribunal, in accordance with the Commission's decision of 26 June 1986, or any subsequent modification of that decision in a national wage case. The Bill will apply also to cases where the contributions are made under an agreement that has not been so ratified but is substantially identical to a ratified agreement applying to employees in the same industry. The amendments will apply for the 1986-87 and subsequent income years.
Educational Allowances

Over the last two years the Government has made a number of changes to deliver more educational opportunities for young people by continuing to improve and rationalise student allowances. As part of this process, the Government changed the assistance for the isolated children scheme and the veteran's children education scheme to make them more consistent with the mainstream provisions of the Austudy scheme. The Austudy scheme replaced the former tertiary education assistance scheme, the adult secondary education assistance scheme and the secondary allowances scheme. Consistent with the taxing arrangements for Austudy, payments from 1 January 1987 under the veterans' children education scheme and the assistance for isolated children scheme, to students aged 16 years or over, are to be made taxable by this Bill.

The Bill will also extend, from 1 July 1987, the availability of the beneficiary rebates to recipients of the education allowances that are to be made taxable by this Bill. The beneficiary rebates ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on certain Commonwealth benefits or allowances do not have to pay income tax. The revenue effects of these changes is estimated to be negligible.
Beneficiary Rebates

As part of the 1987-88 Budget measures, the maximum rebates of tax for taxpayers in receipt of the beneficiary rebates I have just referred to and the levels at which the rebates begin to shade-out are to be varied for the 1987-88 income year. For married persons the maximum rebate will be increased from $280 to $430 and no tax will be payable in 1987-88 on taxable incomes up to $10,350. For other persons the maximum rebate is to be decreased from $190 to $180 reflecting in combination the Government's decision in the May statement to align the level of the single sickness benefit with single unemployment benefit, the reduction in tax rates and the increase in the tax free threshold.

The new rebate of $180 means that no tax will be payable in 1987-88 by single beneficiaries on taxable incomes up to $5,850. The rebates will shade out where taxable incomes exceed the threshold levels and will shade out completely where a married persons's taxable income is $13,790 or more, or $7,290 or more for other persons. These measures are estimated to have no cost in 1987-88 and will cost $8m in 1988-89.
Provisional Tax for 1987-88

Provisional tax is that part of the pay as you earn system designed to collect tax on non salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived. As such, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year. This Bill provides for 1987-88 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1986-87 taxable income increased by 11 per cent, and by applying the 1987-88 rates of tax and Medicare levy. The increased low income thresholds to apply for Medicare levy purposes in 1987-88 will be taken into account.

Generally, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1986-87 assessments. Taxpayers who estimate that their taxable income for 1987-88 will increase by less than 11 per cent, or who consider that their rebates or credits will be at a higher level, will continue to have the right to `self-assess' and have the provisional tax for 1987-88 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
Gifts

This Bill will also amend the gift provisions so the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts to the Lionel Murphy Foundation and to the Australian-Hellenic Memorial Trust Fund. The estimated cost of admitting the Lionel Murphy Foundation is $80,000 in 1987-88 rising to $400,000 in 1988-89 and subsequent years, and of admitting the Australian-Hellenic Memorial Trust Fund is $60,000 in 1987-88 and $70,000 in both 1988-89 and 1989-90.
Application of statutes of limitations to tax debts

Honourable members will recall that legislation introduced in this House during the Budget sittings of last year, and subsequently enacted as the Taxation Administration Amendment (Recovery of Tax Debts) Act 1986, modified the application of State and Territory limitation laws in those cases where an objection or appeal has been lodged against an assessment or decision of the Commissioner of Taxation. The effect of the modification in such cases was simply to continue the relevant State or Territory limitation period so that it would be taken to have ended on a later date measured by reference to the date on which the objection and appeal process is finalised. The modification was necessary to counter abuses of the objection and appeal processes by those persons who sought to defer payment of taxes for as long as possible, and then to rely on the limitation laws to avoid payment of the taxes altogether.

The persons concerned-generally participants in the tax avoidance schemes of the late 1970s-have failed to take heed of the warning underlying the 1986 amendments-that is, that this Government will do all in its power to ensure that payment of taxes that are rightly due to the people of Australia cannot be avoided on the basis of a legal technicality. Despite this warning, a technical argument has now been raised to the effect that the modification does not apply, as intended, to additional tax for late payment of the tax that is the subject of an objection or appeal. The Government does not accept this argument but, against the background that a significant loss to revenue would arise if the argument were upheld by the courts, has decided to make a clarifying amendment of the relevant provisions of the law. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Income Tax Act 1986 to formally impose the rates of income tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for the 1987-88 and all subsequent financial years. It will also impose the rates for 1987-88 and subsequent years payable by companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies on incomes for 1986-87 and subsequent years. In addition, it will impose rates of tax on superannuation funds, ineligible approved deposit funds and certain other trusts. The rates to be imposed by the measures in this Bill are those declared in the Income Tax Rates Act 1986.

The personal rates for 1987-88 reflect the significant cuts in income tax from the second and final phase of the reform of the rate scales which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in the September 1985 tax reform package to apply from 1 July 1987. A four step tax scale now applies. At the lower end of the scale for resident taxpayers, no tax is payable on taxable incomes up to $5,100, an increase in the tax-free threshold from the 1986-87 level of $4,890. On taxable incomes in the range $5,101 to $12,600 the rate is 24 per cent. In the range of $12,601 to $19,500 the rate is 29 per cent.

From 1 July 1987 the marginal rates applying to income in the ranges $19,501 to $28,000 and $28,001 to $35,000 are both reduced from 43 per cent and 46 per cent respectively to 40 per cent, and the top marginal rate has dropped from 55 per cent to 49 per cent. Those general rates also apply to non-residents who receive Australian social security and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia, or who were residents at any time during the income year. For all other non-resident taxpayers, the rate of 29 per cent applies to incomes up to $19,500 and the general rates apply to income above that level. For 1987-88 and subsequent years a rate of 49 per cent applies to all unearned income of resident minors, subject to shading in arrangements for such income just over $416.

The rate of tax on trustees assessed under section 99a of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and on other categories of income subject to anti-avoidance provisions of that Act, is 49 per cent in 1987-88 and subsequent years. The company tax rate will be 49 per cent. This increased rate was announced in the September 1985 tax reform statement to help defray the cost of the new imputation system which commenced on 1 July 1987. The 49 per cent rate also applies for unit trusts treated as companies. Registered organisations are to continue to pay at a rate of 20 per cent.

Finally, the opportunity is being taken to impose income tax as a standing measure, under the Income Tax Act 1986 as proposed to be amended by this Bill, rather than by means of an annual imposition Bill. Of course, if there are changes in tax rates, legislation amending the Income Tax Rates Act 1986, which declares the various income tax rates that I have just outlined for 1987-88 and subsequent years, will be put before the Parliament. As part of this process of reducing the volume of legislation brought before the Parliament, and as there is no legal requirement for the practice, the Bill will also repeal the provisions of the Income Tax Act 1986 that impose a liability to pay provisional tax or instalments of company tax. The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum that accompanied the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 which I have just introduced. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to declare and impose the basic rate of Medicare Levy for 1987-88 and all subsequent income years. As announced in the 1986-87 Budget, the basic rate of the levy will be 1.25 per cent of taxable income. That rate has been effective since 1 December 1986. The Bill also contains increases in the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy.

For 1987-88 and subsequent income years, individuals with taxable incomes of $8,980 or less, and married couples and sole parents with family incomes of $15,090 or less, will not be required to pay the levy. The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. For example, a married couple with two dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $19,290.

The gain to revenue from the December 1986 increase in the rate of levy is $370m in 1987-88. The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $10m in 1987-88, $70m in 1988-89 and $40m in a full year. The new low income thresholds will not be reflected in tax instalment schedules until 1 July 1988.

Until this year, a Medicare Levy Bill has been introduced into the Parliament each year declaring and imposing the levy for the particular year of income. The opportunity is being taken to declare and impose the Medicare levy as a standing measure, so that in future years amending legislation will be required only if the rate of levy or the low income thresholds are to be changed.
The explanatory memorandum on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 about which I have just spoken contains an explanation of the provision of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will make a number of amendments to the sales tax law. One of these will exempt from sales tax certain ultra-high frequency (UHF) television transmitters purchased after 30 April 1987 and before 1 January 1993 for use in regional areas. Exemption from sales tax is to be granted for certain tourist publicity and tourist promotional materials acquired by foreign national tourist organisations. Other exemptions are to be authorised complementary to the proposed agreement between Australia and Singapore governing the status of Singaporean forces training in Australia. The Bill will also bring the sales tax law into line with the customs and excise laws in relation to vice-regal exemptions and make other minor technical changes.
UHF transmitters

The exemption for the UHF transmitters covers transmitters purchased by commercial television licensees to implement the Government's policy of equalisation of regional commercial television services. It also covers transmitters purchased for what is known as band II clearance-the clearance of existing very high frequency (VHF) television channels 3, 4 and 5 to alternate UHF frequencies-and is an important step in introducing new commercial FM radio services in regional areas. In addition the exemption extends to the small number of transmitters which are expected to be purchased for the remote commercial television services and for community self-help rebroadcasting facilities.

Since the exemption does not run for the full period of the implementation of equalisation and band II clearance, it will act as an incentive to licensees to fulfil the Government's policy objectives sooner than prescribed, while recognising that the Government should not gain sales tax revenue from commercial purchases which it has itself dictated. The exemption applies to transmitters, not including ancillary equipment, purchased for use in non-metropolitan areas and the metropolitan areas of Hobart, Canberra and Darwin, but will not generally cover replacement transmitters. It is estimated that total revenue of around $14.5m in June 1987 prices will be forgone in the period to 1 January 1993-of this total, the cost to revenue for the 1987-88 financial year is expected to be $400,000. No additional administrative resources will be required to implement the exemption. This measure provides important assistance to regional commercial television licensees and reinforces the Government's policies on introducing new commercial television and radio services to country audiences.
Tourist publicity and promotional materials

The exemption for certain tourist publicity and promotional material will apply to the goods, or classes of goods, specified in the Bill where they are for use by, or in some cases free distribution by, a national tourist organisation of a foreign country or an appointed representative of such an organisation. Goods that will qualify for exemption include scale models, showcases, timetables, audio-visual works such as promotional films, cultural items such as national costumes, and printed matter such as books, magazines and pamphlets. The exemption arises from Australia's obligations under an instrument of international tourism policy adopted by the Council of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in November 1985.

A requirement of that instrument is that member countries admit from other member countries, free of import duties and taxes, certain tourist publicity and tourism promotional materials. It has been suggested by some member countries and national tourist organisations that Australia is not complying with the requirements of the instrument because wholesale sales tax is payable in Australia on the importation of goods including tourist publicity and tourism promotional materials. However, the Australian Government does not accept that the wholesale sales tax is an import tax. Sales tax applies in a non-discriminatory manner to all goods whether they are imported or locally manufactured. The Government considers, therefore, that there is no inconsistency between the imposition of sales tax on materials imported for the purpose of promoting tourism to countries overseas and Australia's obligations under the OECD instrument on tourism.

Nevertheless, in a spirit of co-operation the Government has decided to introduce the sales tax exemption that is now before honourable members. It will cover an organisation that is an official `arm' of government, or any non-government organisation appointed by a foreign country to be that country's official representative in Australia in matters relating to the promotion of tourism to that country. Because sales tax is applied in a non-discriminatory manner both to domestically produced and imported goods, and in line with the Government's policy that local industry should not be disadvantaged by taxation laws that favour imported goods, the exemption will apply to both imported and locally manufactured goods with effect from 1 July 1987. The cost to revenue of the proposed exemption is estimated to be in the order of between $50,000 and $100,000 in a full year.
Status of Forces Agreement with Singapore

The exemptions to be provided in terms of the proposed agreement with Singapore match those extended under Australia's status of forces agreements with the United States and Papua New Guinea and will operate from a date to be proclaimed following the signing into force of the agreement. The cost to revenue is estimated to be less than $500,000 in a full year.
Amendment of Vice-Regal Exemptions

The proposed amendments to the vice-regal sales tax exemptions are identical to those introduced by my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) when he presented to the House the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986. That Bill had not been passed by the last Parliament when it was dissolved in June of this year; the amendments to the vice-regal sales tax exemptions are now incorporated into this Bill. As outlined by my colleague, the proposed amendments will limit vice-regal sales tax exemptions to articles for the official use of the Governor-General, the Governor of a State or a member of the family of the Governor-General or of a State Governor. Personal use articles purchased by such persons will no longer be exempt from sales tax, nor will articles for the personal or official use of non-Australian members of the staff of the Governor-General or of a State Governor. This will place Australian and foreign staff members on an equal footing for sales tax purposes.
Minor Consequential Amendments

Other amendments will make minor technical corrections to references in the sales tax law to provisions of the customs law consequent on changes to the customs law. I commend the Bill to honourable members and, in doing so, I present the explanatory memorandum on this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to amend the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to ensure that certain exports of coal to steaming coal markets, at the lower prices operating in those markets, do not attract the coal export duty, which is currently set at $3.50 per tonne.

The coal export duty was introduced in August 1975, at a time of high industry profitability as a way of distributing to the wider community windfall profits accruing to coal exporting companies. Over the years, the duty has been modified to recognise changed economic circumstances in the industry. The present policy objective of the Act is to make dutiable only high quality coking coal destined for world steel industry markets. These coals attract a price premium relative to steaming coal, which is exempt from export duty.

As a result of changing demand in the international market-place, some Australian mines producing coking grade coal are presently unable to sell all their production into coking coal markets, but they are able to sell a less highly refined or washed version of the coal into steaming coal markets at the lower prices applying for this product. However, the existing parameters defining the characteristics of the coal on which duty under the Act is based is having the unintended effect of rendering this lower quality product liable for duty. In view of this, the Government has decided to change the param- eters on which the duty is based by reducing the prescribed ash content of the coals from 12 per cent or less to 10.5 per cent or less and raising the crucible swelling number-a measure of the coal's coking characteristics-from over 3 to over 5. These changes will ensure that the policy objective of the Act, which is to make only high quality coking coal subject to duty, is continued.
Financial Impact

The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications, as the Bill seeks to continue existing coal export duty arrangements in operation since 16 May 1987. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly welcome the opportunity of speaking in this House about the current Budget because I think it is one of the greatest hoaxes that this country has ever had foisted on it.
—Well put.

—As the honourable member for Flinders has said, that was well put because it states the basic situation in a most succinct fashion. This Budget is a hoax; it is a con. As has been pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and many other speakers on this side of the House, the real deficit in this Budget is $2 1/2 billion-not an innocuous $27m but $2 1/2 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad thing about this Budget is that the Government has not had the strength to take the hard decisions that should have been taken. Traditional political wisdom would say that the first Budget of a government returned was the time to be tough, to take the hard decisions, to do what needed to be done for the benefit of the country, and to do what was necessary for the salvation of the people of Australia. Take the hard decisions now then there will be time for those decisions to take effect and by the time the next election comes-this is the traditional wisdom-the Government will be able to soften its decisions.

It has not even had the common sense to do that. All it has said is that things will go on as they are. It is living in a fool's paradise. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is living in a fool's paradise. He has all the fringe benefits tax money and the other tax money dropping like manna from heaven. He is saying, `Whoopee, let's go on spending the way we have been doing'. There have been no cuts in Government spending. Any sensible person in this country knows that there must be cuts.

Some of us were fortunate enough to hear the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer speak at the National Press Club today. He quoted from a secret International Monetary Fund (IMF) report, which had fallen off the back of a semi-trailer. It made the point very strongly that the Government is on very shaky ground. It has brought forward this Budget on the basis of assumptions, and if those assumptions move aside ever so slightly it will be in very great trouble. There should have been a decrease in Government expenditure. There should have been a decrease in Government taxes.

It is interesting to look at the Budget Papers. I have with me the Commonwealth Public Account 1987-88. If one looks at table 3 relating to the Consolidated Revenue Fund, in 1986-87 expenditure and revenue was $73,782,794,295-that is, $4,585.70 per head for every Australian. This year that figure has increased to $80,663,140,000 or $4,937.40 per head. It is an increase of $6.88 billion. It is an increase on a per capita basis, for every man, woman and child, of $351.70 in just one year. The Treasurer comes in here time after time, smiles-which is a rarity for him-and says, `No new taxes, no increase in taxation'. But if there are no new taxes and no increase in taxation, how is it that we are taking in an extra $5 1/2 billion in taxation? Is that not a con? Is that not a hoax?

It is only in the last few days that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has spoken of the danger of complacency about this Budget. I think that a most unfortunate thing has happened since the Budget was presented. We often accuse Australia of being the great country of apathy. The word `complacency', used by Senator Walsh, is certainly a significant one. Unfortunately, the great majority of our fellow Australians are saying, `It is a good Budget. He has balanced the Budget; that is all right'. They do not realise the ramifications and the real problems.

There is a delicatessen owner in Coffs Harbour with whom I am friendly. Last Saturday morning, when I walked through the arcade in which his delicatessen is situated, he said, `Garry, you can't complain about this Budget, can you?'

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have been upset by that.

—I certainly was because the re- ality is that we should complain. We should not be hoodwinked. We should not have the blinkers put on us by the bland presentation, `She's okay, mate'. That is what they said on the Titanic before the iceberg hit.
—Small business has the most to lose.
—The honourable member for Gippsland is right.
—Did you tell him?

—I did. He is a small businessman. The point is that the present Labor Government has no political courage. It could not bring itself to take the tough steps and introduce the hard measures that should have been taken. It took no hard decisions. There were no cuts in spending. It just took another $5 1/2 billion in taxes. There has been absolutely no action in this Budget to solve the foreign debt problem. Our foreign debt is increasing at the rate of $1 billion a month. This has been going on for years. It has been increasing by $1 billion a month since Labor took office. That is the rate by which our foreign debt is increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is taking no steps to improve productivity. Heaven knows, we will not get out of the disastrous financial situation that we are in unless we can increase productivity; no country could do so. We are trading in a world market. We are living in a time of great competition. There is no way that we will become competitive unless we can control costs and improve productivity. This Budget takes no action to decrease the high unemployment rate which has bedevilled this wonderful country for so many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The forgotten people.

—Yes, as the honourable member for Gippsland says, the unemployed are forgotten. Time after time since I was elected to this Parliament I have drawn the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and of the responsible Minister to the fact that within the electorate of Cowper unemployment has reached the level of 25 per cent.

—As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling says, it is a great shame. SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister is a frequent visitor to my electorate. He enjoys visiting it. He loves the avocadoes, bananas, kiwifruit and all the other marvellous tropical fruits that we have. They should be fair dinkum and prepared to care about all Australians. That is what we in the National Party and the Liberal Party are about. We care for all Australians. Ever since the Hawke Government came to power in 1983 we have had the perpetuation of the greatest lie in Australian politics and the greatest deceit since Federation-that is, that the Fraser-Anthony Government left a Budget deficit of $9 billion. —For future generations especially.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, and as was revealed by the honourable member for Kooyong at a National Press Club luncheon today when he quoted from a secret IMF report to the Government, there is no room for accidents. Since Labor has been in office there has been a marginal improvement in productivity, but in this Budget weekly earnings are forecast to rise by 6 per cent, the same rise that has occurred in the last two years. How can we be competitive if our productivity remains at almost the same level and our weekly earnings go up by 6 per cent? It does not compute.

SPEECH.PARA: Continued pay rises without increased productivity is a simple recipe for sending Australia broke. At the same time, the Budget contains absolutely no provision to ease unemployment. As I mentioned earlier, there is a forecast of 8.3 per cent unemployment and 23 per cent youth unemployment in 1987-88. The unfortunate reality is that the trade unions control this Government. This Government does the bidding of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That is why no action is being taken to deregulate the labour market so business can create jobs. That is what we need for our young people and family people-men and women in their thirties and forties, with a couple of kids and a mortgage, who are out of work and have no chance of ever getting a job. The problem is too serious not to give it attention. However, there is nothing in the Budget to provide employment opportunities. What we need to do is to free up small business. Small business and the farming community are the biggest employers in this country. We need to deregulate and take away the crippling taxes which are stopping them from going ahead.

The Hawke-Keating Government is the highest taxing government we have ever had. The Government said that there were no new taxes in the Budget. But, as I have already said, this Budget collects an additional $5.5 billion in taxation. The fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are still there. Those taxes are hitting small business. I am not ashamed to say in this place once again that pensioners are still being hurt by the assets test. The assets test is still a despicable tax which is hitting the older generation-people who survived the Depression and were in great trouble then and those who fought in World War II. Those are the people, many of whom reside in my electorate, who are being hurt. We still maintain that the assets test must go.

The Government is taking 24 per cent of gross domestic product in taxation just to balance the Budget. This Budget is a Budget of high taxes and high expenditure. Small business is being crippled by taxes and strangled by red tape. The country electorate-people in regional Australia-will be harshly affected by what has been done to the fuel freight subsidy. According to the Budget Statements, total outlays for that subsidy will be cut by $8.5m, or over 52 per cent, this year. This will involve increasing the consumer paid contribution by 4c a litre to 10.2c a litre. The Australian motorist is paying far too much taxation on fuel. For country consumers of petrol and diesel to be hit by another 4c a litre is a disgrace.

Those are the things in this bland Budget of pap that should be made clear to the people of Australia. The Budget will not help anyone in Australia. What we need to do to help Australia and Australians is to take the hard decisions, to cut expenditure and taxation and to restore incentive so that people can go out to work and keep a fair share of what they earn without having it ripped off by the Government. We must restore incentive for workers, small businessmen and farmers to work harder. This Budget does not tackle the real problems. Inflation is still too high and productivity is still too low. Unemployment is still far too high; taxation is still far too high, and interest rates are still too high. It will be a long road to the next election but at that time the Hawke-Keating Labor Government must be tossed out for the salvation of Australia.

This will make it easier for them to supplement their social security payments by taking casual jobs when they are available.
