I am sure that other honourable members have had visits from elderly people when they have a problem with their overseas pensions, particularly the United Kingdom pensions when the dollar was going up and down and the value of the pension was changing week to week and month to month. This will help to alleviate that situation. It will be of particular benefit to people receiving income such as superannuation or an overseas pension which might be subject to changing exchange rates. It will stop pensioners from having to worry about small movements in the level of their private income, and it may relieve the work load of some members of parliament. I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your appointment to office. I am sorry that I did not mention it earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—In the Budget the Government has, quite rightly, accepted its responsibility to uphold the undertakings made recently during the election campaign, one of which was that the major program deductions have already been made in the May economic statement. Compare that honest approach to the dishonesty and hypocrisy of the Opposition, which preaches economic rationalism and offers the electorate tax cuts which it could not afford from expenditure reductions which it would not identify. We on this side of the House can be forgiven for thinking that those opposite were proposing to resume office and once again pursue the irresponsible and ad hoc policies which originally led to the outrageous Budget deficit of almost $10,000m which was inherited by the Labor Government when it came to office in 1983. That is what I was trying to say earlier to the honourable member for Cowper when he was claiming that this Budget is a hoax and that we had caused the deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: That legacy has now been wiped out as a consequence of the single-minded attention of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Expenditure Review Committee in the last five Budgets. Needless to say, Senator Walsh is a member of that Committee. The 1983 $10,000m prospective Budget deficit is the measure of the Opposition's economic vandalism and will not be forgotten either by the Government or the people of Australia. Together with the unbelievable performance of the Opposition in the recent Federal election, this has condemned it once more to the political wilderness where it can wallow in the luxury of hindsight and never have to make the up front decisions that matter.

This Budget incorporates a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending-the biggest cut in 35 years. The dampening effects desired of cuts in government expenditure of this magnitude must always be weighed against the possibility of triggering a recession. As a consequence, the Government has been careful to ensure that economic growth is maintained, even if only at a low level, and that the stimulus for additional growth is concentrated on the export sector in an effort to reduce our balance of trade problem. Of this recent export growth no less than half has come from the sale of manufactured goods. The dramatic pick-up in this area is a direct result of the Government's economic policies together with the devaluation of the Australian dollar which has rendered our exports more competitive in the world market. It is obvious that an increase in the number of products manufactured in Australia means an increase in the number of jobs available for Australians. That is good news for those unfortunate enough to be unemployed.

In recent years the trade union movement has developed an understanding of the importance of the social wage to the people of the nation. Its mature attitude to wage restraint has contributed substantially to the improvement in export growth and allowed the reduction in unit labour costs necessary for our competitiveness overseas. To compete successfully in the international market-place Australia must raise its educational and training standards. We must lift the skill level in our work force. I take the point made earlier by the honourable member for Cowper about the percentage of young people who are unemployed. To a large degree their unemployment relates almost directly to their lack of skills or qualifications. That is certainly an area that the Government will be looking at in terms of traineeships and so on.

The current restructuring of our economy has cast employment and training systems in a crucial role and the Government has moved to streamline and co-ordinate action in this area by forming the new Department of Employment, Education and Training. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) recently presented the Government's plan for achieving skills formation goals as part of the Budget Papers. I recommend that all honourable members read it if they have the opportunity. The Minister points out that it will be necessary to increase the level of participation in education and training and to improve the flexibility and quality of our education and training systems.

By way of comparison, it is worth pointing out that the Fraser Government starved the education system during its term of office and reduced participation rates. This Government has been working since it was elected to improve those participation rates. In Western Australia we are currently fortunate enough to have a 50 per cent participation rate of people in year 12. However, I realise that in some other States the rate is not quite that high. The Budget builds on recent changes to student allowances by amending the student assistance schemes for Aboriginal children, isolated children and the children of veterans to bring those schemes more into line with mainstream income support programs. If young people are to stay in the education system more student places must be provided. An extra 5,800 higher education places have been approved in this Budget for young school leavers.

It is especially important to note that funding for the Australian traineeship system is to increase from $14m to $45m, providing 13,000 places for new trainees. The traineeship program has great potential for assisting young people into employment in areas where apprenticeships are non-existent or not feasible. Furthermore, a new program to provide short term vocational training opportunities for unemployed young people will be introduced at a cost of $31m. The traineeship system in my electorate unfortunately has not been able to get off the ground because of the number of small business people there, many of whom would like to be involved in the traineeship system but are unable to. The group traineeship system is the one that I will be looking at to see whether we can get it going in the Cowan electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be better, will it?

—I am sure that there are quite a few people in that area who are prepared to get involved in discussion with governments and unions to get one of those schemes off the ground. As mentioned earlier, the Government's skills formation strategy will complement these programs. We have made the tax system fairer with this Budget. Because of the earlier innovations of the Government in terms of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax we have received more money than was originally anticipated. Those funds have made the difference when it comes to balancing this Budget. I suggest that the members of the Opposition who underestimate the cost to the Government of coming up with a balanced Budget look at this again. In the long term future when they may eventually achieve government again I would like to see whether they could come up with the same feat.
—Twenty years at least.

—I thank the honourable member for Isaacs. That is correct. It will be a long time. Hopefully some honourable members opposite have long memories. By the time they get to government perhaps they will have started thinking about how difficult it is to come down with a balanced Budget. To my recollection the Howard-Fraser Government never achieved that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had the Treasurer (Mr Keating) genuinely managed to deliver a balanced Budget, media euphoria would have turned to an hysteria boarding on the religious with the media no doubt demanding his beatification. St Francis of Assisi would have had nothing on St Paul of the Treasury. But there is not sainthood yet, not with the Treasurer's sleight of hand in nearly balancing the Budget. His claims are a myth. If we remove the $1 billion realised from one-off asset sales and the $2.6 billion windfall from the currency dealings of the Reserve Bank of Australia we have a Budget deficit of $3.5 billion. This brings the Treasurer's balancing act down to earth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Government's second most senior economic spokesman, has confirmed the Opposition view that the Budget was not hard enough and that government spending in welfare in particular should have been and could have been slashed. This Budget is based on several assumptions, including assumptions that inflation will fall from 9 per cent to 6 per cent-which is nearly 50 per cent higher than that of our trading partners-and assumptions that overseas investment will remain at today's levels, or higher. But what happens if United States interest rates rise? Funds will pour out of Australia as people take advantage of the more attractive rates offered in the United States. Another assumption is that there will be no world recession. Australia has little influence internationally. We follow world trends; we do not lead them.

We have a foreign debt of $110 billion. When the Hawke Government came to office in 1983 our foreign debt was $36 billion. In just four years of this big spending Hawke Government our foreign debt has blown out by $74 billion. At the moment we have a frightening trade deficit. This year we are trading in the red to the tune of $13.6 billion. Last year the trading deficit was $14.3 billion. Australia has been trading in deficit since 1981-82. Even during the world trade recession in 1982-83 and 1983-84 the trade deficit was in the area of $6 billion and $7 billion respectively, which is considerably lower than our present circumstances.

The Treasurer has admitted that the magnitude of our trading problem is that we still have a long way to go. If Australia is to sell more overseas we must ensure our goods are competitively priced. The Treasurer stated:
In particular, we must make sure labour costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners.

Does the Treasurer propose measures to ensure that labour costs are competitive? Of course not. What he does foreshadow is a review of the business sector over the next year. This Budget does nothing to help the private sector and stimulate investment by reducing company tax. He is assuming the unions will support wage restraint; he is assuming inflation will not rise; he is assuming interest rates will not increase; and he is assuming there will be something of a revolution in the work place to improve productivity.

This is the second biggest spending and highest taxing Budget since the Second World War. The Treasurer has relied on revenue increases rather than spending restraint. By failing to cut Government spending, Australia's debt spiral will continue, and we will indeed be heading down Senator Walsh's Argentinean road.

The Budget shows an increase of 8.2 per cent in revenue. The ratio of tax to gross domestic product is up, despite the promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the contrary. The percentage of personal to total tax has risen to 57.8 per cent which takes Australia from twelfth to seventh on the list of countries with the highest personal tax. Individual tax is now at an historically high level. In the early 1950s a person needed to earn 15 times average weekly earnings to reach the top tax scale. Twenty years later it had fallen to five times average weekly earnings. Today it is around 1 1/2 times earnings as inflation pushes more and more wage earners into higher tax brackets.

In the current year pay as you earn tax receipts will rise by nearly $2 billion. Next year it could rise as high as $5 billion, for the simple reason that over 1986-87 and 1987-88 more than one million taxpayers will move into the 40c tax bracket, and a further half a million will move into the 49c in the dollar bracket. This bracket creep which fills the Government coffers will, no doubt, allow for further tax cuts before the next election, at a time when it is most electorally expedient.

When the Hawke Government came to office in 1983, an average wage earner with a wife and child living in suburban Australia-in Belmont in Geelong, in Newcastle in New South Wales or Eltham in Melbourne-brought home $338 per week. He was taxed at the marginal rate of 30 per cent and paid $58, or 17 per cent of his weekly wage in tax. In 1987, the same taxpayer earned $445 per week. His tax increased to $91, or just over 20 per cent of his wages. In just four years of Hawke-keep, a clerk, handyman, labourer or shop assistant has seen his average weekly earnings increase by 31 per cent, but the increase in his tax has risen by 56 per cent. Tax increases have outstripped wage increases by almost 25 per cent. Is it any wonder that middle Australia sees little point in working longer and harder hours when it is the Government, not the individual wage earner, who reaps the benefit?

This Budget has done nothing to stimulate and encourage business investment. It is true that there is the promise of a review of the structure of the business taxation system, but that seems more ominous than encouraging. Unless the review advocates positive incentives for business investment and encouragement for the creators of wealth, the economy will at best stagnate, at worst suffer a sharp decline. Business leaders will follow the example of John Elliott's Elders-IXL and move off-shore to centres more conducive to higher productivity, flexibility and profitability. More and punitive taxes will restrict business investment, prune productivity and curb competitiveness. With a corporate tax rate of 49c in the dollar what hope have we of being more competitive when our major trading partners have a corporate rate of 35c or less?

The family package, the Treasurer's Christmas present to low income earners, will do nothing to encourage the recipients to help themselves. A tax free payment of $87 per week to a family with two children, earning $324 a week and renting privately will encourage the welfare mentality. It removes incentive for the family to seek further earnings. Already 28.9 per cent of our Federal Budget is spent on social security and welfare. We cannot continue to bleed those contributors of wealth to support the consumers of wealth who neither make, nor are expected to make, any contribution. As a rule of thumb we can see from these figures about a third of the Budget is spent on social security and welfare.

The theoretical view of the Hawke socialist Government that the state will care for everyone who does not want to care for himself, breeds a handout mentality. It is possible in this country for a person to be born, educated and supported throughout his life by the social welfare system. Middle Australia cannot be expected to keep on supporting these wealth consumers and non-contributors. Senator Walsh has nominated 200 government projects in the social welfare area which he believes should be cut. Yet in Senator Walsh's own words, the Government lacked the political courage to curb welfare spending. It has, in fact, expanded welfare handouts to those it considers in, or near, poverty.

Just as the Treasurer assumes his Budget outlook is correct, let me foreshadow two of the things which could go wrong. Wage restraint will not last. Factional alliances will crumble; indeed they have already crumbled, as we see in the reports of the meeting in the Government party room only yesterday. The employer paid fringe benefits tax has reaped much more than the Government expected in 1986-87. The Government estimated it at $325m. It proved to be a bonanza that brought in $535m, and estimates for this year are $750m from that tax. The fringe benefits tax has certainly raised government revenue but at a great cost in overheads to the private sector, particularly to small business.

The Budget Papers estimate revenue gains from capital gains tax to be in the order of $50m to $100m. This is a far cry from the National Taxation Summit estimates of the Treasurer of $25m. The unintended consequences of capital gains tax have yet to be understood by accountants, lawyers, small businessmen and investors. The coalition is totally opposed to a capital gains tax. The Budget brings into question Australia's ability to remain self-sufficient in crude oil production beyond the next decade. Reserves in the Bass Strait fields are already two-thirds depleted and current estimates point to production running low by 1997. This poses a grave problem in the very near future. We cannot allow wells to run low before obtaining sufficient supplies to satisfy consumption. Currently revenue earned from crude oil excise exceeds $2 billion. Not only would that revenue be lost to the Government, but also the import of crude oil would present Australia with crippling balance of payments problems. Current Bass Strait production is around 450,000 barrels a day.

The Government cannot be accused of encouraging the oil industry to further exploration. The introduction of the resource rent tax has been a positive disincentive for further investment. In 1983 exploration began to fall back due to the fall in world oil prices and the lack of incentives. At one period during 1986, 38 of the 45 drilling rigs in Australia were idle. Currently about 20 out of 40 are in use and five are being sold or moved overseas. According to the Budget Papers, in five years production is estimated to fall to 250,000 barrels a day. This means that in five years, unless other reserves both on and off shore are brought on line, we will need to import around 300,000 barrels a day. This would add about $3 billion to our foreign trade debt. Not only would $1 billion in revenue be lost but our balance of payments would bear the further burden of a $3 billion per annum debt.

What will happen if oil prices rise to, say, $40 a barrel? Argentina-here we come! Senator Walsh is the only Government economic spokesman to give any indication of the true state of our economy and to expose the sham of the Treasurer's so-called balanced Budget. Like the Opposition, he has no wish to be chased down the `Argentinean road' by International Monetary Fund creditors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills constitute Australia's first balanced Budget in more than a decade. This remarkable Budget has vindicated the decision of the Australian people who on 11 July returned the Hawke Government for a third term, with an increased majority. They opted for a continuation of the sound stable growth that the Australian Labor Party has delivered since 1983, and has again delivered in this Budget. The people of Australia strongly repudiated the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia with their discredited and ill-conceived tax policy. The Opposition's economic policy is now only a wreckage, a ruin of its own creation.

SPEECH.PARA: The deficit forecast for 1987-88 of a mere $27m stands as an important milestone in Australia's economic recovery. By bringing into the tax system those who had previously shirked their responsibilities and by targeting increased government assistance towards those in need, this Government has, in a domestic sense, balanced the books. In 4 1/2 years it has erased the stain on our national ledgers left by the Fraser-Howard team with its shameful projected deficit of $10 billion. This Budget, perhaps more than any other in recent memory, has been resoundingly endorsed by the financial markets and the business community. Home buyers have also heralded the resulting drop in home interest rates. Across Australia leading economic experts have commended the Government-save, of course, for our new resident swami, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock).

Out there in the electorate the good news about the Government's new family assistance package is spreading, giving a welcome and much needed boost to hundreds of thousands of families. This Budget does much more than square the domestic ledgers. The $500m family assistance package will mean real increases in the standard of living for more than a million children. By Christmas, this Government will have more than doubled income support levels for children-a practical demonstration of Labor's commitment to social reform.

The family allowance supplement is a major step towards the elimination of child poverty. This Budget, within a sound and responsible economic framework, brought in the largest increase ever made to child payments. The thousands of families in my electorate-in Chelsea and Mordialloc, to name just two areas-who will benefit from this package need no reminding. The starkness of the choice offered to them on 11 July could not be better demonstrated than by the following example: a family earning about $320 a week, with three children and renting privately, as many are in my electorate, will receive an additional $81 a week free of tax under the recently announced family supplement package. The best that the Liberal Party could offer those families, with its `grab bag for the rich' policies, was a paltry $20.46.

The Government's family assistance package, however, goes further and sets benchmarks which will see child payments linked to an indexed pension, so that their real value will be maintained. The extra cost of older children and the costs facing families renting privately have been recognised. The family allowance supplement will be paid at a rate of $22 a week for each eligible child under 13 and $28 a week for each child between 13 and 15, after which most students will go on to Austudy. It is interesting to note also that families with a combined income of up to $600 a week can be eligible for assistance. I urge all families who believe that they may be eligible to contact the Social Security office in their local area in the near future to ascertain their eligibility.

All present pensioners and beneficiaries and families receiving the family income supplement will automatically go on to this new family allowance supplement, but all other families who are not in that system but who may be eligible should receive advice as to their eligibility. As I have said, families earning up to $600 a week may be eligible for some assistance under the Government's family assistance package. In short, the family package provided for in this Budget takes direct action to help wage and salary earners and their families.
The scale of assistance provided to families on lower and middle incomes is probably best stated by the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bill Kelty, when he recently said:
. . . left to our own bargaining capacity it would take at least 50 to 60 years to increase the real wage rates of the lowest wage earners (to rates) represented in the family package.

This Budget provides for a new and dynamic direction in education and training in Australia. Since 1983, this Government has substantially increased funding and programs and places in secondary and tertiary education. It has significantly improved the quality and accessibility of the education system. It will have dramatically increased the retention rate of students in year 12 from a dismal 36 per cent, or about half that of our major Western allies, to over 50 per cent by the end of 1987. That magnificent increase is a remarkable and proud achievement of the Hawke Government which was not missed in the recent election by the people. The projected retention rate of 65 per cent by 1990-by the end of this Parliament-will be another step down the road to a better education for our children.

The `Skills Formation in Australia' paper, incorporated as an integral part of this Budget, and the statement yesterday in the House by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) seek to build on these achievements in education and to ensure that education and training mechanisms are properly tuned to the needs of Australia's economic recovery. Significantly, this important Budget initiative will see the restructuring of technical and further education funding to reflect our national priorities and skill formation objectives and to encourage greater industry participation. It will fund an extra 4,000 higher education places and increase by 12,000 the number of young people eligible for Austudy payments. It will introduce a new skills training program in conjunction with industry. It will substantially increase the number of trainees under the Australian traineeship system. It will expand the adult training program to assist an estimated 13,000 adults this year. This move will further employment, education and training initiatives under the Aboriginal employment development policy. There will be a significant 12.3 per cent boost in funding for apprenticeship programs.

I am particularly pleased that the Government has continued support for community based support programs for young people and will move towards a single program to maximise assistance to the most disadvantaged. I can testify to the valuable contribution made by the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) projects in our community. The Mentone CYSS and BAYCYSS in Chelsea in my electorate of Isaacs would have to be among the best run programs in Victoria.

This Government has demonstrated, right from the start of its historic third term, that it is meeting the challenges that Australia faces. With this Budget and the `Skills Formation in Australia' strategy, we will see an increase in the level of participation, quality and flexibility and the responsiveness of our education and training system. The new Department of Employment, Education and Training, in partnership with industry, will provide Australia with rational, co-ordinated and relevant education and training programs-the sort of innovative policy so glaringly absent from the Opposition's Budget response.

In the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is a projection of another tremendous growth in employment. By the end of next year one million jobs will have been created since this Government won office in 1983. There will have been the creation of a tremendous growth in employment with one million jobs being created in 5 1/2 years. This is in contrast to the loss of a quarter of a million jobs in the last 12 months alone of the previous Fraser Government. That growth has exceeded all expectations. Indeed, I believe it is unsurpassed anywhere in the Western world: we have seen economic growth and economic upturn, but we have not seen them combined with a tremendous upturn in employment, as we have seen in Australia under the Hawke Government.

I should like to touch on just a few of the social security matters we have introduced and given notice of introducing. One that I am particularly close to is the child disability allowance. It will be introduced from 15 November to replace the existing handicapped child's allowance, which is paid under two categories-for the severely disabled it is income test free; and for the substantially disabled it is subject to a financial hardship test. The child disability allowance will make no distinction between severely and substantially disabled children. It will be paid income test free to all disabled children covered under the current categories of handicapped child's allowance. Child disability allowance will be $112 a month, which is an increase of $20 over the present allowance. As I said, that will be introduced from 15 November.

Previous speakers have spoken of the earnings credits being introduced for pensioners. A pensioner who gets a job, say, as a Father Christmas, may earn $250 a week for four weeks and maintain his full pension right across the 52 weeks of the year because he is able to earn the $1,000 maximum earning credit which can be proportioned over the entire 12 months.

We have seen flexibility in pensioner fringe benefits levels whereby someone can earn up to 25 per cent more than the allowable fringe benefit level for three months before losing the fringe benefits. That flexibility in the system should be applauded by everyone. We should also remember that this Government brought in the indexation of fringe benefit levels. Under the previous Fraser Government tens of thousands of pensioners lost their fringe benefits because of the failure to index fringe benefit levels. Under the present arrangements pensioners are protected from loss of fringe benefits because of that indexation. I remind pensioners that the levels are now $75 for a single person and $126 for a couple.

I go back to taxation. During this debate and over the last 4 1/2 years of this Government we have heard the doomsday people. When this Government brought in the taxation reform package, which we have implemented slowly but surely over the last couple of years, we heard screams that this would not work, that business would go downhill and that people would be bankrupted. There were all sorts of cries about draconian measures. Yet the stock-market boom is continuing, property values are starting to sky-rocket, business is moving ahead very quickly and the entire economy is booming. At the same time the taxation policies of this Government have been very successful. To name just two areas, in the past 12 months the fringe benefits tax, which was going to ruin everybody, has brought in for the Government $535m; and the prescribed payments system, a new system that was gong to cause all sorts of people in the building industry, for example, rack and ruin, has brought in $765m. That is a total of $1.3 billion. We do not see too many builders going out of business. Business is still booming but the Government has been very successful in making people across the entire spectrum of our society pay their fair share of tax.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), talked about the capital gains tax. It is projected to earn this year between $50m and $100m for the Government. Again, people were screaming about that but it has not stopped people investing. It has not stopped business and the share market from booming and it has not stopped the economy from growing. All we are seeing is a fair share of taxation being paid by people across the board.

The new initiatives for families and young people provided for in this Budget are tremendous. These vital new programs have been funded without increasing the deficit because this Government has had the will to restore fairness and equity to the taxation system. As I said, the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the crack down on tax avoidance have ensured that all Australians pay their fair share of tax. This broadening of the revenue base has enabled the Government to provide tax cuts for wage and salary earners and to pay for vital new policy measures for families and young people. The alternative Budget outcome reflects the stark choice the Australian people faced in July. The Australian Labor Party, led by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the tradition in which it has governed since 1983, offered responsible tax cuts and programs paid for through tax reform and steady economic growth. The result: significant new programs and the deficit now a negligible $27m. In contrast is an inevitable $6 billion deficit which would have flowed from the irresponsible taxation policy of the Opposition. Its alternative would have been `optional taxation for the wealthy' and its massive `tax cut now-pay later' policy would have produced a deficit blowout second only to the shameful legacy of the Fraser-Howard years.

Alternatively, of course, the Opposition would have had to have massive cuts in programs and services, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is now suggesting. He, of course, is not telling anyone what those massive cuts would be, as he did not throughout the Federal election campaign. If he were to balance the books, the cuts would be in the vicinity of $6 billion. What would those cuts be? It is anybody's guess. All Opposition members call for more money for various things, including the Opposition spokesman for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who is sitting at the table. They would not be getting it if about $6 billion were to be taken out of the economy.

This Budget virtually erases the $10 billion legacy inherited by this Government. It has confirmed the correctness of the Government's economic direction and paved the way for continued progress towards economic recovery. I congratulate the Government on this Budget. The new initiatives for families and young people are well targeted and will give many hundreds of families in my electorate a fair go. Honourable members opposite who are now so piously sounding off with their fresh demands for program cuts and reductions should direct their energies to getting their own house in order. In their case they have to start with the stumps. Only when they can rid themselves of the intellectual baggage of the New Right and jettison the discredited Howard tax policy can they credibly respond to a Budget such as this. Mr Deputy Speaker, we have seen a responsible government bring in a responsible Budget for the future of Australia. I congratulate the Government and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see I am speaking not to a large audience, but a very distinguished one, including the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) who had some words to say last week on the ANZUS alliance and the importance of divorcing the joint bases in Australia from any trade negotiations-a point of view with which I thoroughly agree. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) is also in the audience. He had a few words to say this morning on factions in the Australian Labor Party-again a point of view with which I thoroughly agree. I thought he spoke very well; he very articulately indicated the position in the Australian Labor Party and spoke of the great brawl that took place in the Caucus room a day or so ago. So it is a distinguished audience.
—Don't forget the rest of us, although there are not a lot here.

—I am getting support from behind, as well. I welcome the opportunity to continue the remarks that I commenced last night on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88. Last night I was talking in particular about the defence service home loans scheme, which the Government threatened in the Budget. That was causing a great deal of unrest in service establishments throughout Australia, and also amongst the veteran community. Since then the Government has backed down and has agreed not to pursue the proposal as outlined in the Budget Papers. I have no doubt that the powerful speech that I made on the subject last night had something to do with that. What is of interest, of course, is that the Government clearly said in the Budget Papers that the loans system would change. I quote the Budget Papers:

SPEECH.PARA: Persons currently waiting for a DSH loan will have the option of accepting the cash grant instead of a loan. New applicants after 15 September 1987 will be offered the cash grant only.

It is clearly written, in black and white, in the Budget Papers. The intention of the Government was clear: as of last Tuesday, it was going to change the system. Then the pressure started to mount. The honourable member for Herbert would be only too well aware, coming from Townsville where Lavarack Barracks is situated, of the pressures that were mounting all around Australia, and no doubt in Lavarack Barracks as well. In the end, good sense dictated that changes should be made, and the Government backed down.

I am pleased to see that changes were made. I do not want to harp on it, but I note with some amusement the way the Government now says that the proposals-which I have just read out from the Budget Papers; the Government was going to change it as from 15 September to cash grants only-have been changed. A joint Press release from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) says:
In the Budget the Government put forward a proposal for discussion with the RSL and other interested bodies.
There is no mention of discussion. The proposal was clear-cash grants after 15 September. The Press release goes on:
These discussions are now underway and in order to allow them to proceed at the least inconvenience to potential applicants-
they did not mind inconveniencing them a week ago; it is a bit different now-
it has been decided to offer the option of either the present loan or the new grant arrangements to applicants who lodge their applications before 1 January 1988.

That is good. I very much hope that after 1 January we see a sensible scheme in place. I can assure the Government that there will be a flood of applications now because people will be very concerned that the changes proposed in the Budget Papers a week ago will come into effect after 1 January, and servicemen will be particularly disadvantaged. I hope that the Government will now set about putting a proper scheme in place. If it is determined to make changes, it should carry out its promise of two years ago to privatise the scheme. It should make an option available: either the loan or a cash grant at a reasonable figure-not $10,000, which bears no relationship to the value of the $25,000 loan. It should make sure that the waiting times for applications are brought down, and it should increase the value of the loan or the grant so that it is meaningful to a person buying a house today. After 20, 30 or more years of service $25,000 does not go far for a serviceman establishing himself in his own home when he has been moving around the country all those years.

I am pleased to see these changes and I hope the Government takes note of the sensitivity of this scheme to service men and women in the Australian Defence Force. The worst thing about the scheme is that it indicates the Government's approach to service men and women in Australia. Despite promises from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs over the last few years that no one would be disadvantaged if there were any changes and that everyone would be consulted, in the end no one was consulted-not the service chiefs, the Returned Services League or any other interested body. It is the degree of discourtesy and lack of concern shown by the Government towards service personnel in Australia that is causing the current problems. The service men and women out there are saying to themselves, as well as to me and anyone who cares to listen, that the Government does not given a damn that their conditions of service are gradually being eroded day after day. If honourable members want a good example, take the case of the defence service homes fiasco, which hopefully has now to some extent been straightened out.

I turn to the Budget, Appropriation Bill (No. 1). The defence budget for the year 1987-88 totals $7,404m. It is interesting to note that last year the Government proposed spending $7,415m on defence; in fact, it spent some $200m less. It is interesting to note that despite all the hype about funding in the Defence White Paper, the proposal in this year's Budget is actually $11m less than the Government proposed to spend last year. The Government says it is minus one per cent, by means of clever, creative accounting. The fact is it is spending $11m less than it proposed to spend last year, and if we take inflation into account by any sensible arithmetic that must mean a real negative growth of something between 6 and 7 per cent if the Government's inflation predictions are correct. It has serious implications for the White Paper, with which the Opposition generally agrees, because the original report of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and then the White Paper were predicated on a real increase of something like 4 per cent a year. Then it came down, it could be done on 3 per cent a year; last year it was zero growth and in 1987-88 it is minus one per cent. That is a very generous figure; I think it is nearer to minus 6 or 7 per cent.

So it is with a degree of scepticism that I and many others who are interested in defence greet the remarks of the Minister for Defence when he says that the White Paper is on track. The White Paper clearly is not on track. There are considerable changes to the proposals that originally came forward, and it will be with great difficulty that the Minister will keep it on track. I hope he can, because the general thrust of the White Paper is good.

One of the biggest problems with the funding of the defence vote in Australia is the imbalance between capital expenditure on defence and expenditure on improving or maintaining conditions of service. The biggest single problem we have in the defence field in this country is the enormous wastage rate in the Services. The Government says it is concerned but I have yet to see it express that concern in practical terms. The Budget contained nothing that would alleviate the deteriorating conditions of service. The biggest problem that the Services have is this wastage. The conditions of service which are causing it have been shuffled off by the Minister for Defence. If we talk to service chiefs, any senior officer, any non-commissioned officer, (NCO) or private soldier in the Army, the Royal Australian Navy, or the Royal Australian Air Force, they will say that things are crook and that conditions of service are deteriorating. What does the Minister do? He shoves the biggest single problem he has off to the new Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) and says, `Listen, this is a bit tough for me. You had better look after it'. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel is a very pleasant woman and I have no doubt that she will be an able Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —She is preoccupied with the Canberra Raiders at the moment.

—The honourable member is quite right. She has a fairly parochial view for maintaining her seat in Canberra, but with the best will in the world she does not understand what is happening in the Services. Why would the Minister for Defence hand over the most difficult problem he has to the most inexperienced member in the House? The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, who is confronted with this problem, says, `We will fix this. What I will do is hire an adviser who will point me in the right direction'-to use her words. So she goes around and finds Mrs Mayer, the former Labor member for Chisholm, who was defeated at the last election and she sets up Mrs Mayer with an office and staff in Melbourne, which is reported to have cost a total of half a million dollars, and she says, `Mrs Mayer will fix the biggest problem we have in the defence forces. We will give her the problem. She can do another survey and another investigation'. It is no wonder that there are great guffaws amongst defence personnel if that is the way the Government is going to tackle their conditions of service.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to spend a few minutes on the question of why people are leaving the Services. In a general sense, they feel that the Government has neglected them; that it has not paid sufficient attention to their conditions of service; and that they have become second class citizens. Largely, I agree with those general attitudes. Of course, there is the old question of posting turbulence, which is a management problem rather than a political problem. The Services are doing their very best to overcome this problem but it cannot be overcome completely if ambitious and experienced officers and NCOs are working their way to the top. They have to have a range of experience and that means that they have to move around. But when they move around one of the important things for them is to get a reasonable education for their children, particularly in the competitive world that we are in in 1987. There are 70,000 uniformed men and women in the Services. How many do honourable members think would be a reasonable number who should get some education allowance for their children to remain at school when they are posted off? Of course, not all of them are married but the base figure is 70,000. Honourable members might think that some hundreds of people would get this allowance. In fact, the number of people who are serving in Australia and who are getting some form of educational allowance for their children to stay at school is 59 out of 70,000. It is no wonder that they are finding it difficult to maintain a home and to educate their children if that is the sort of approach that the Government takes to an education allowance. It is not that the allowance is so bad; the problem is that people cannot get it because of the maze of regulations and restrictions that surround it.

On the question of pay, let me deal briefly with why people are leaving the Services. Until recently the Remuneration Tribunal was left in the Department of Defence where it should never have been. I think it is on the move, or it has moved out and that is a good thing. While the Remuneration Tribunal was in the Department of Defence all the resources of the Department of Defence were used to support the Government's case in opposing the Services. It was a nonsense and it was recognised as a nonsense and the Government has at last decided to move it out. One of the problems we saw in the last service allowance case a few weeks ago was that $700 was given when people were expecting between $2,000 and $3,000 and that became a joke in the Services. People are saying, `If that is what the Government thinks of us, we are off'.

This has given rise to other anomalies. In some cases, because of that service allowance and the Government's failure to adjust some of the pay for lieutenant colonels and above, or their equivalent, majors are sometimes earning more than their lieutenant colonels who are superior officers. I instance a ridiculous case in an infantry battalion which I visited recently where the second in command, who has extensive responsibilities but not as many as his commanding officer, is taking home more pay than his commanding officer. How can the Government allow those anomalies to continue and still say-as the Minister for Defence says frequently, `We are concerned about the wastage and about the conditions of service'. It is a nonsense.

Flying pay has not yet been addressed by the Tribunal. When we are talking about manpower, if there is one area of the forces where there is a big, black, gaping hole which is getting worse day by day, it is in trying to find pilots to man our operational squadrons in the Air Force or to man the flying instructor positions where people are supposed to be training all the new pilots who are required to replace those who are going. It is an enormous and worrying problem for all of us. About two-thirds of the flying instructors, who should be in establishment positions training pilots, are missing. Only one-third of the flying instructors are there trying to train the pilots who are required because of the massive resignation rate.

I turn now to the question of housing. About 22,000 houses are owned or controlled by the Defence Force. On the admission of the Defence Force, 12,000 of those houses-over half of them-are below its own scales and standards. The Government has been saying for some time, `We will fix this'. It is not just this Government that has caused the problem; it has been caused by a succession of neglectful governments over the years. This Government is going to spend $75m fixing service housing. The service men and women say, `Good. At last something is being done'. But when we look at the figures we find that over half that amount will be spent on new base housing at Tindal, and in Rockingham in Western Australia. Certainly it is going on housing, but when the Government talks about spending $75m on improving housing, people expect that some of that $12,000 will be spent on improving the houses they are living in. But half of that $75m is going on new bases. I say to the Government that it should not use that sleight of hand trick. It is not spending $75m in upgrading existing housing; it is spending less than that.

I turn now to the Hamilton report. A few cosmetic changes have been made. I see that Senator Newman is in the gallery and I welcome her presence because I think she knows better than anyone just how superficial the Government's approach has been to the Hamilton report. The Government keeps saying, `We will implement the Hamilton report'. The Government announced in this House that another 40 people or so would be appointed. The Hamilton report is old and almost dead and people have given up hope that any part of it will be implemented. Establishment loans for people leaving the Services have been withdrawn. We have a 2 per cent reduction in Defence Force retirement and death benefits pensions. A recent survey shows that the long hours that service men and women are expected to work are calculated at between 52 and 55 hours and it is likely to get worse because the Government has now lopped nearly 1,000 uniformed positions off the Defence Force units in this country. The Government will expect the same sorts of returns from less people, so the people who are there will have to work much harder.
I am trying to point out the problems that exist. If the Government does not address them this problem of the wastage of manpower will get much worse.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making my contribution this evening to the Budget debate I will not dwell at any great length on the Budget in its macro sense, but I do wish to make certain comments on and speak about certain areas of the Budget that affect all Australians, particularly Australians in the northern part of our continent. This, the fifth Budget of the Hawke Government, in conjunction with the May economic statement, is a Budget for the benefit of all Australians. It is a Budget that has been endorsed by the overwhelming majority of Australians. I refer to the editorial of the Australian of 16 September 1987, the day after the Budget was announced:

SPEECH.PARA: By balancing the Budget, the Government has thrown down the gauntlet to the private sector and the States. It has done all that could be reasonably expected of it. The pressing economic problems facing Australia-a chronic current account deficit on the balance of payments and declining business investment-can only be resolved by the private sector.

For the first time in more than 50 years a Government will be paying back some of the public sector's overseas debt. The cut in spending in real terms is the largest in 35 years. Moreover, the Government has insulated low-income earners and the deserving from the brunt of its spending cuts. It has been faithful to its traditional supporters and is entitled to expect restraint from the unions in second-tier wage negotiations.

That was part of the editorial of the Australian of 16 September. But it was not the only editorial or the only favourable comment that was accorded the fifth Hawke Government Budget, not only by members of the media but also by those in the private sector and financial analysts and experts throughout the country.

In far north Queensland many areas have been directly affected by the 1987-88 Budget. None is more important than the large rural sector in far north Queensland. I refer first to the sugar industry, an industry that over the last few years-in fact, during the time that the Australia Labor Party has been in government-has suffered as a result of flagging overseas international prices for its product and other factors, including economic and weather factors. The Sugar Mill Adjustment Committee (SMAC), which is involved in mill rationalisation within the sugar industry, has recently made recommendations to both the State and Federal governments for additional financial assistance for the Babinda and Mourilyan sugar mills in far north Queensland.

In recent times a mill in that area, namely, the Goondi sugar mill, was purchased and closed down, and the sugar cane that was formerly crushed by that mill is now being crushed by both the Mourilyan and Babinda mills. It is a rationalisation that will be a success in the long term. But the industry has had its difficulties in that region. It has only been the far-sighted efforts of the Federal Government, and particularly of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), that have made this rationalisation a reality. The money was supplied on a two to one basis by the Federal and State governments. I am very pleased to note that SMAC, in its most recent recommendations to the Government, has indicated that additional funding should be made available to the Babinda and Mourilyan mills.

There is, of course, one area in which I believe the State Government has failed in its efforts to assist the mills-that is, State government stamp duties and other incidentals and costs involved in this mill rationalisation have not been written off. Almost one-third of a million dollars is being sought by the State Government. Its only answer to the sugar industry in that part of Queensland is that the Queensland Government would be kind enough to give them a loan; therefore, further interest would be incurred as far as the repayments of that money are concerned. I believe the State Government could play a fair and equitable role by writing off such incidental costs.

The 1987-88 Federal Budget demonstrates, I believe, the Government's commitment to non-metropolitan Australians and the development of their industries, such as the sugar industry. In particular, the Government's economic strategy, directed at improving industry competitiveness and so laying the basis for a return to growth in living standards, will be welcomed by all of those associated with the primary production sector. Highlights of the Budget which affect this portfolio are a new national afforestation program, costing $15m nationwide in the first three years of its implementation, and outlays of up to $8m to help retrenched coal miners find new employment.

I turn to the national afforestation program. As I have indicated, $15m has been allocated for its implementation over the next three years. The program will commence in this financial year with an allocation of $2.5m. The objective of the program will be to stimulate a sustained increase in the level of investment by States, individual landholders and industrial forestry companies in the development of hardwood-I emphasise `hardwood'-plantations and in the rehabilitation of degraded land through reafforestation. Everyone will be aware that through the neglect of a number of State governments timber resources have dwindled to an almost negligible proportion. Once again through the shortsightedness of a number of State governments, there has been no reafforestation as far as hardwood plantations are concerned, more concentration having been directed towards the area of softwood plantations.

The Government's commitment to establish a broad acre afforestation program with emphasis on native hardwoods was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his rural policy speech during the election campaign. The program will complement the objectives of the national soil conservation program, the national tree program and the national rainforest conservation program which, although effective individually, do not meet the need for large-scale afforestation. Details of the national afforestation program are being resolved with the States. It is necessary that they, as well as industry, play a role in this program. It is expected to include three components: broad acre plantations, land rehabilitation, and research and development.

I now make specific reference in the primary industry field to the Federal water resources assistance program. Queensland has received almost 60 per cent of the funds allocated for this program in the 1987-88 Budget. Of the $66m allocated for the Federal water resources assistance program, $34.5m will be made available to Queensland. Very importantly-I note that the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) is in the chamber-$29m will be made available for the Burdekin Dam program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Burdekin Dam.

—I am not sure whether it should be called the Hawke Burdekin Dam. I have heard it referred to in north Queensland as the Lindsay Dam. It is important that that program continue. It is also important that $4m has been made available for the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. The country towns water supply improvement program (COWSIP), which plays a very important role in the more remote areas of Australia, will receive an injection of $1.14m.

SPEECH.PARA: During 1986-87 a similar amount was made available for COWSIP in Queensland and included just over $1m for the Karumba water supply and some $113,000 for the Cooktown water supply. Those were important programs. Because of the growth in the areas their existing water supplies had become insufficient and the upgrading was a total necessity. In fact, Karumba did not have a reticulated water supply. Despite a number of promises made by the then Minister responsible for water supplies in Queensland, Mr Hinze, on his number of visits to the area, nothing was done until Federal Government funding was made available as a result of a 1983 election campaign promise by the then Leader of the Opposition, Bob Hawke.

The Government has allocated $6m to the national soil conservation program for the financial year 1987-88, an increase of 9 per cent over 1986-87 expenditure. Of that allocation, $4.8m will be provided for projects by State government soil conservation agencies and $1.2m for projects by other organisations that can contribute by way of research, demonstration, community involvement or publicity. The national soil conservation program was established in 1983-84 to stimulate national efforts to control land degradation. The 1987-88 allocation brings the total expenditure under the program to some $21.15m. Some 150 projects are being funded throughout Australia to control one of the most important, if not the most important, long term problems for agriculture and the environment.

I now turn to rural industry research funding, which is very important to people in northern Australia. The allocation for rural industry research has been increased from $42.1m in the financial year 1986-87 to $48.9m in the financial year 1987-88. Commonwealth policy is to support matching funding, dollar for dollar, with industry contributions up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of the industry-for example, one per cent for fisheries. The increased allocation reflects increased research activity and funding by industry. I welcome the Commonwealth Government's decision to establish a Sugar Industry Research Council. The Government will provide $52,000 from the 1987-88 Budget for the Council's first year of operation. The Research Council, which will be established under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985, will monitor and evaluate the research requirements of the sugar industry and will determine the allocation of funds to research projects beneficial to the industry. It is interesting to note that, until this year, all research within the sugar industry was funded by the industry itself. I also welcome the Government's decision to allocate $42m to the rural adjustment scheme. That compares very favourably with the expenditure of $34m in 1986-87. Having regard to the parlous economic state of some of our primary industries, it has been welcomed by the primary industry sector.

I refer briefly to the programs that have been funded in the 1987-88 Budget for pensioners and the family. This Government has an unchallenged record in those areas of welfare. Sixty-five per cent of the social security budget is paid to pensioners-aged, invalid or widowed. The May statement and this Budget reinforce this Government's commitment to protecting indexation for pensioners and to help beat poverty traps by giving pensioners room to increase their income. There will be a relaxing of the fringe benefits income test. If income does not drop below the 125 per cent level within the three-month period, eligibility will cease. These levels have been carefully considered by the Government and, as such, encourage those who are still able to partake in the work force.

In the election campaign the Government promised another step forward in the improvement of the social wage-the new family allowance supplement. The Prime Minister has said that, by 1990, no Australian child need live in poverty. In December 1987 the Hawke Labor Government will introduce a family package which promises real increases in the standard of living of more than half a million families with more than a million children. In the last 10 years the number of children Australia's poorest families has more than doubled. Today more than one in five children-more than 800,000 of them-in families have to depend on income support from the Government. Most of them are in families which have suffered from the impact of unemployment, around 220,000 children, or marriage breakdown, around 440,000 children. The Budget provides major assistance to Australian families, especially those on low incomes. A new integrated approach to providing family assistance payments is being introduced. In December of this year the benefits will start to flow to those needy families. As a result of the May economic statement, supplemented now by the 1987-88 Budget-the fifth Hawke Government Budget-it is impossible not to commend without any equivocation the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget may seem attractive at first glance, but it has really turned out to be of limited real strategy. It is not an effective cure for the long ailing economy of this country. The deficit is to be reduced by selling off public assets-selling off part of the farm or, to put it in another context, selling part of the shelf stock. This has never worked in any effective economic situation and it will not work in the long term for this Government. It will not work because there have not been the counterbalancing decisions that needed to be taken and they are certainly not part of this Budget. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) quoted from a newspaper editorial. I am afraid that it would take more than quotes from some single editorial to effectively put forward a case in support of the Budget. His contribution, while worthy in many respects, certainly did not give any hope or heart to believe that this Budget will be successful in the present economic dilemma that confronts us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's move to sell off-in many directions which have yet to emerge in reality-perhaps the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, Telecom Australia and other bodies is turning out to be privatisation for the wrong reasons and for very dubious motives. It appears that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is desperately looking for a one-off revenue windfall from selling off these assets. He wants to use privatisation to gain sufficient revenue so that the Government can continue its big spending programs without having to face up to the difficult problems of cutting spending. But once that one-off revenue gain has been and gone, the nation's economy will be in an even greater mess than it is currently in. All that the Hawke Government is doing is delaying the evil day when it will have to face up to the fact that its economic policies are on a destructive course.

Privatisation of some government owned services, properly and carefully implemented, could have a beneficial impact on our future economic development. This afternoon, we heard honourable members speak rather fiercely against privatisation, but there are many questions that have to be closely considered. For example, there is little point in privatising a government service if that action leads to a reduction in the overall service provided, especially in country areas, or to the creation of a private monopoly whose actions would continue to dominate by the power play of the unions or for other reasons. The Prime Minister, in his obviously long term plan-a headlong grab for revenue-seems to be ignoring important implications such as these.

The Prime Minister and his colleagues are guilty of gross hypocrisy on this whole issue because it was only a couple of years ago that they were trying to crucify people on this side of the House in both the National and Liberal parties for promoting any form of privatisation. The national account figures for 1986-87 make it obvious that we needed a Budget to stimulate private investment. Unfortunately, this did not occur, and what we have seen in the private sector for too long is merely a process involving paper money and not genuine investment. We have seen the stock exchange move in a particular way. Much of this is merely shuffling paper from one place to another, without real investment and without consideration of what the needs of this nation are. I refer to the vital requirements that there should be investment in plant and equipment, and that manufacturing industry should be brought up to the highest point of proficiency when we have to compete in a very competitive overseas market and a competitive situation in our own market. We have too many imports because they are cheaper and because we do not have the competition in this country.

There is no doubt that we are on a disaster course unless some change can be brought to bear. We needed a Budget that would stimulate the private economy and private enterprise and get us on some course of real growth, but we did not get it. The Budget suggests a 2 per cent growth rate. All the predictions in the previous several Budgets on growth rates have never been attained. If the prediction is not attained on this occasion, the consequences will be even worse than those experienced on those previous occasions. No one should be fooled by the Budget announcement that the Government will repay $1 billion of government-in other words Commonwealth-overseas debt during 1987-88. What we need to remember is that Australia's gross foreign debt currently stands at $110 billion. Despite the rather fictitious claims about the deficit when the present Government took over-referring, of course, to the internal deficit-what Government members have failed to acknowledge in the debate on the Budget thus far is that, when this Government came to office in March 1983, our gross foreign debt was only $30 billion, compared with the $110 billion that we face today.

To pay off this enormous debt would be equal to a contribution by every man, woman and child in Australia of about $6,500. That is bad enough, but the real snag in all this is that the interest bill alone on our foreign debt is running at about $7 billion. It is equal to what we spend each year on health, education or defence, and that figure is far too high. We have had the flamboyant announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that we are beginning to reduce our foreign debt, but when the fine print of the Budget is taken into account, the claim is without foundation or proof.

Likewise, the Government has been somewhat dishonest, if that is not too strong a word, in its claims about taxation. Let us take some of the real figures in this respect. In the Budget Speech, the Treasurer made much of saying that the Government was adhering to its election commitment not to increase taxes or introduce new taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not.

—The honourable member should just listen to some of the figures which relate to this matter. The total tax revenue in 1987-88 is forecast to increase by 8.5 per cent to a massive $71.2 billion. This follows a 12.5 per cent increase for the previous year. The consequence of that is that ordinary taxpayers will pay an additional $3 billion this year; yet we have the claim made that taxation is being reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: It is taxation by stealth that is the real issue. I refer to the indexation, particularly, of excise. Let us take the figures on excise. Five years ago beer, for example, was at 60c a litre, and that brought in $1,123m. That excise has now risen to 83.3c per litre for high alcohol content and 73.2c per litre for lower alcohol content. That pushes up the revenue for this year to $1,462m, an increase of $339m in that space of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Less than the CPI.

—Of course. It is very easy. This Government has introduced indexation but did not say a word about it in the Budget. It does not come out and honestly say, `We are increasing excise on beer and cigarettes'.

SPEECH.PARA: Worst of all is the increase on petrol and diesel. Five years ago, there was 7.15c per litre on that, and now it is 20.09c per litre. The Prime Minister said that the Government would try to keep it down to an increase of not more than 6 per cent, but this means another increase of at least 2.5 per cent by the beginning of next year. What has that done? It is good on the revenue side because the yield has increased from $6,816m five years ago to a massive $9,646m for the current financial year. That is an increase of $2,830m on just this one item of excise on fuel.

The users, whether it be the ordinary motorist, transport operators, or the air services of this country, are being taken to the cleaners by this enormous charge, which is then passed on to the unfortunate people who have to pay for freight or fares, or to get themselves to and from work, let alone their usage of fuel for other purposes. Petroleum product excises have accumulated an increasing share of total Commonwealth revenue from taxes specifically for this purpose from a level that was perhaps reasonable a few years ago to now accounting for 70 per cent of revenue in this field of excise. That is far too high. It is intolerable and, of course, it is kept hidden as so many other things are hidden in this Budget and in the Government's attitude to taxation. The forecast was that inflation would fall. How can it fall when prices keep rising? Supermarket prices, the cost of motor vehicles, homes, furnishings and whatever keep rising. That is the real burden that is falling on the community, a burden that is getting heavier and heavier month by month and year by year and this Budget does nothing to reduce it.

There are supposed to be some goodies in the Budget such as the allocation of additional funds for technical colleges, training schemes, short term vocational training for the unemployed and for the development of Aboriginal employment. These are fairly extensive allocations. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, no doubt knows all about the allocation for the development of Aboriginal employment. That allocation is increased by $49m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support it?

—I do support it but we do not have the details of how it will work and what will be done. This is the history of the whole matter. The Prime Minister headed that famous promotion of youth. He was on television and an enormous amount of money was spent on advertising. But then the Priority One program was withdrawn because it failed. Will we see the same thing happen again?
—My program won't be withdrawn.

—I wish the Minister good luck. We will support him if he can put forward a scheme that is practical and that will work. The consequences of this Budget for families, for the people of Australia, are really horrendous. As I said a moment ago, cost escalation is the real bugbear. Let us take just one item that was introduced in legislation in the last few months: taxation hitting the kids of this country who go into their first job having spent part of the year completing their education and job training. Perhaps they have been under the Austudy scheme or the earlier tertiary education allowance scheme. They then have to account for the income received from those schemes, add that to their income for the part of the financial year that has just ended and, for the first time, under these tax changes they are obliged to pay tax on the lot. Instead of facing the prospect of refund on their tax return-on an average wage, around $600 or $800-the very reverse will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer who sits on the front bench when he is ever in the House never has time to apply himself to the simple, ordinary things that affect people at the grass roots level. This problem has been raised but there has not been an answer as to why kids are being hit with massive tax bills for the financial year ended 30 June last, in sharp contradiction to the way tax has been imposed for many years on people in their first job for part of the financial year. All of us are getting queries and inquiries in our electorate offices about this. This Government has no sympathy at all for the youngsters of this country who deserve some help when they are triers and are prepared to go out and get a job. When they get a job they are in a desperate situation if they have to face this tax bill, their first rent and first on-cost in being employed, including travel costs and so on. It is the sort of thing for which this Government is totally without sympathy and never recognises such cases when they are put to it.

There seems to be a far greater interest by this Government in the corporate sector of the community. It is now going to investigate company tax. Can honourable members imagine the Government getting down to the detail of the sort of tax that is hitting the individual that I just mentioned? It will not do it-not on your life. Those opposite will not hurt their friends in the corporate sector no matter what recommendations come out of any report that is submitted, no matter how honest that report may be. That is the real history of what we have been seeing on the part of this Government for so long.

Let us think what the Treasurer said about negative gearing. When he found that his facts were wrong after the advocacy of the Premier of New South Wales and many others who could see the disaster that had begun to occur, he reversed the policy. What did the Government do next? It took away the depreciation allowance on buildings. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who is at the table is nodding his head which means that he is totally in agreement with this. The consequence again is that that sector of the community that is prepared to invest, create employment and try to do something constructive for the progress of this country and to provide employment, accommodation and all that goes with it has its incentive taken away.

We are told that this Government is doing a great job. The Budget is so bereft of the real things of worth that it really is a tough Budget and will turn out to be tougher as this financial year goes on. We are told about recruiting for Commonwealth departments under the new structures of the Minister for this and that-it is a bit hard to sort out which Minister is for what-and that this will save $107m in a full year and reduce staff levels by 3,100 by the end of 1988-89. But the same Budget Papers did not tell us what it was going to cost to bring in the Australia Card, the great identity card, and what the extra requirement would be to staff the service that would operate it. The detail is not there so all we can hope is that this afternoon's procedure in this House in which the truth of what is really in that legislation has been brought to light by this side of the House will mean that the Government will not get the chance to do a double flip again by saying what the reduction in Public Service numbers will be, what savings in government administration will be and yet, on the other hand, failing to really own up to what it intends to do under the provisions of the Australia Card.

In this Budget we find that every section of the community is left with a degree of uncertainty, but no more uncertainty than is found in rural Australia. Despite all the dilemma of the past three years, with the serious drought problems and difficulties on the export market-which the Government says is the reason for its financial problems-there is no recognition of a worthwhile nature of that section of the community that produces the bulk of our export income. The Government has no sympathy at all for the real needs of rural Australia. I believe that we will not see this financial year end without another mini-Budget to drag this Government out of the hole that it has got itself into in so many ways.

We have increased funding to a huge range of areas which, for many years under conservative governments, were neglected. This Budget incorporates a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending. The areas in which we have cut the spending have hurt some of our traditional Labor people-not too many-in some areas where people were getting away with abuse of Commonwealth funding. We have tightened up all the way round. We have tightened up in the social security area. This has been important and has saved many hundreds of millions of dollars. For years the general public were telling us that there were too many people cheating on the system. This Government has tightened all that up. We have made certain that the tax dollar goes to those who need it, those who are worthy recipients of it, and not to those who abuse the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending is the largest cut in 35 years. This is a long time. I was only 11 years old at the time of the last large cut. To improve our balance of trade our export growth is coming not from the traditional areas of mining and farms, although a lot of it still does, but from a huge increase in manufactured goods. There is a huge resurgence in the manufacturing industry. As a fitter and turner, I keep an eye on the trade and one only has to look at the job vacancies for skilled tradesmen. TALK.START.PARA: —TCF?

—Exactly; textiles, clothing and footwear is another area in which restructuring has come about through discussions with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and, of course, the all powerful industry committee of the last Government, of which I am pleased to say I was a member. SPEECH.PARA: In the employment, education and training area this Budget has created about 5,800 new places for young school leavers. We have also saved $100m in unemployment benefits.
