These people did not pay tax before. One could say that they were tax cheats. However, one could say that it is in the Australian psyche to try not to pay tax if one can get away with it. These people are not white collar criminals. They are mainly average people who, through working in a particular industry, could get away with not paying their fair share of the tax for many years. TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get an increase?

SPEECH.PARA: Many of our children at school are doing projects on endangered species, et cetera. All we have to do for the next 10 years is to hang on to what we have and our kids will look after the future. There is no way that the conservative parties can chop down and destroy beautiful areas of Tasmania, mine Kakadu or rip out the guts of the rainforests in Queensland. Our children will look after those areas. All we have to do is save them for the next 10 years. I advocate putting aside huge areas of Australia, fighting battles with the State governments and delaying their measures until our kids take power. Then those areas will be safe for future generations.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card-Adelaide Hills-Army Reserve-Canberra Raiders-Women in Parliament-South Australian National Football League Preliminary Final-Poverty in Australia-Supporting Parent's Benefit-National Flag-Mr Jim Robertson-Christo's Restaurant, Darwin

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 pm., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is an historic day in this Parliament because the will of the people has triumphed with the assistance of the Opposition skill. We have been able to demonstrate that the Government, notwithstanding the huge resources of public servants, has not been able to put together a piece of legislation in such a way that it can effectively be passed. Today, in my State of Western Australia, 25,000 people, on a conservative estimate, marched along St Georges Terrace, protesting about the introduction of the Australia Card.
—It makes you feel good, doesn't it, Wilson?

—It makes me feel very good because it is clearly an indication that some people-including, I believe, 32 members of the Government-have already discovered that the Australian people do not want this mechanism. Indeed, they never really wanted it, once they understood what it meant to them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to the Opposition's credit that it set about in a calmer period of politics to explain to people what the system meant. I, in particular, will take some credit for my efforts in explaining exactly what the Australia Card meant to people in a way they could understand. I did so by speaking on the Ray Martin show and other programs, identifying the problems. I pointed out the inconvenience in respect of people's bank accounts. I referred to the intrusiveness involved. Questions were asked in this Parliament, which the Government eventually answered honestly. We raised the problem of ensuring the security of those mythical landlines. I thought that the landline argument was one of the more glorious arguments. Both my elder children are deeply involved in the computer business. I thought when the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) told us that we had this `you beaut' landline that we were missing the opportunity of a lifetime. There was no need for the Government to pursue the baby-sitters of Australia for a little more tax. It should have sold the technology of the landline to the governments of the world, because they all want secure data transmission services. None has one yet.

Equally interesting was the Minister's statement that we had some `you beaut' unforgeable identity card. Today I have taken up the challenge. I shall be $100 richer because a New South Wales Labor member of parliament offered $100 to anybody who can produce evidence of someone being affected by a forged Bankcard. My late mother had a card belonging to her forged. She used her card only in Asia, but $6,000 of credit was obtained in Italy with a forgery of the card while my mother still held the original.

TALK.START.PARA: —That person must have plenty of money.
—I have taken up the challenge. I am probably in a long queue, which might be as big as the group of 25,000 protesters in St Georges Terrace.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that the ID system was not going to work. It would not deliver what the Government claimed it would do, but it would intrude on people's privacy and be highly inconvenient to them. Unfortunately, the Government refused to recognise that there were better ways of making the system work and that the Australian Taxation Office is practising some of them. Although the Opposition has been critical of the Taxation Office in the past, we congratulate it on its efforts.

I should like to point out where the Government made its great mistake. Having got the legislation through Parliament, having established a huge bureaucracy and having got all the Australian people to queue up and apply for a card, the Government needed to declare that a certain day would be the day on which people needed to use the card. All the obligations were contained in clauses 40 to 54 of the Australia Card Bill. The Government said that the system would not function until the first relevant day. The Government decided to define the first relevant day as a day to be declared by the regulations. The Government did not have to do that. It could have used a power of proclamation or power of gazetting, but it decided on regulations because the Health Insurance Commission believed that they gave it more flexibility. It was a matter of running an extra couple of lines in when nobody was watching. It did that and it has been hoist by its own petard because it can go through all the functions but to make the thing work it has to bring a regulation into this House and into the Senate and it has to suffer the 15 days during which a motion can be put to disallow it, which will be simply carried in the Senate by the majority of the Opposition parties, which are opposed to this thing. That is what will destroy it. The Government can have its Bill, it can have its card, it can have people queueing up but it cannot force anybody to use clauses 40 to 54.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to criticise some of the comments made by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) last night which he addressed to you. I quote from the Hansard record of last night. In talking about the Adelaide Hills, he said:

Is he so parochial that he has become myopic? Has his time in the doll's house limited his vision to things domestic? Has his preoccupation with State matters denied him a national perspective? All States, Madam Chair, have their particular beauty. Take the State of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear). It has Perth, the Swan River and Fremantle Harbour. Sydney has the most wonderful harbour in the world and the Blue Mountains to the west. Adelaide, of course, has its Lofty Ranges. I have a soft spot for the Lofty Ranges. They established the township of Bethany, now Nuriootpa. Those same great grandparents are buried at Nairne.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not been to the blue Dandenongs.

—But his greatest sin of all, as the honourable member for La Trobe reminds me, is that he has not been to the blue Dandenongs and he has not been to the Upper Yarra Valley. This is one of the greatest and most beautiful regions in Australia, with the tallest trees in Australia, that vie with the Douglas fir as the tallest trees in the world-400 feet is not unusual-Eucalyptus regnans, the mountain ash. We also see the mountain greys and we have some magnificent fern gullies throughout the Dandenong Ranges. These regions embrace the electorate of the honourable member for La Trobe, my electorate and the electorate of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), although I have not heard him speak up for the area. Madam Chair, it is an insult to the residents of the Dandenongs for the honourable member for Mayo to make such remarks. They have produced the most beautiful gardens combining European trees and flowers with our native vegetation. We have public gardens such as the Kawarra Gardens which are famous for their collection of native plants. It is an insult to the farmers of my electorate who have turned the Silvan Valley into the most wonderful and beautiful patchwork of farming communities. It is an insult to the Dutch community which has established some of the greatest tulip farms in this country. The horticulture in the Dandenongs and the Upper Yarra Valley is second to none in the rest of Australia. Wines produced in the Yarra Valley are winning prizes all over Australia. Yet the honourable member for Mayo is ignorant of all this.

SPEECH.PARA: If people wanted inspiration for creativity where better could they go than the Dandenong Ranges, where such great painters as Tom Roberts and Arthur Streeton went for their declining years and to produce their last great paintings. Great writers such as Vance and Nettie Palmer were inspired by the area of Emerald. I could go on and on. It is no wonder that this is an area to which thousands of visitors travel to share this wondrous beauty. The honourable member's remarks are an insult to the people who live in this area and who take their guests to see this area. I advise the honourable member to come to see for himself what I can describe only as God's own acre. I invite all honourable members when they have time to come to the Dandenongs and the Yarra Valley. When they have feasted upon this magnificent area they may then educate the honourable member for Mayo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, it is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise in this adjournment debate because--

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs should be careful; he might get more than he asked for.

—Madam Speaker, I will indeed. I rise to make a point about the future of 8 Platoon of C Company, 41 Battalion, Royal New South Wales Regiment of the Army Reserve. I know that he is a great supporter of the Army Reserve and the tremendous job that our fellow citizens who are involved in the Army Reserve perform. SPEECH.PARA: The lease for the present depot at the Macksville showground will not expire until 30 June 1988. Even though the rent is a nominal $240 a month and the rent will be paid until the end of June next year, nonetheless the Reserve unit is being closed down. This is going to create a great deal of inconvenience for a number of enthusiastic young Australians who are prepared to serve their country. The whole of the Nambucca valley community is deeply disturbed that the Department's decision to direct unit members to train at Coffs Harbour, some 60 kilometres distant, is discriminatory against members of the unit including high school students, meat workers who work at the Mid Coast Co-Operative Meat Society Ltd abattoir at Macksville and others who will probably be forced to resign from the Reserve because of the inconvenience caused by the closure.

Madam Speaker, I wish to take this opportunity to tell the House that it is so very important that the Army Reserve should be supported and in particular to ask the Minister for Defence to continue to give his support to the Reserve and to support me in my moves and the arguments I am putting forward to try to preserve the depot at Macksville. I know the Senate has a somewhat better record than this House, but I hope that over time the record here will continue to improve.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought yesterday when this statement was made-certainly it was made in the first instance; it was only as a result of an interjection that the Minister, herself a woman, made the correction-that it is a pity that any of us, but perhaps particularly a woman, should make a mistake such as that, albeit in the circumstance that it was the first occasion she had answered a question in the House as a Minister. TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to talk about football tonight but so many of my colleagues have spoken about their local teams this week that I would feel remiss if I did not mention that my local Aussie rules team, Glenelg, will be playing Norwood in the South Australia National Football League preliminary final on Sunday and I feel I should wish them all the best for that match. I really want to refer to the speech made in this House last night by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who spoke on the subject of poverty in Australia. The honourable member blamed poverty on this Government, the late Mr Justice Murphy, the Family Law Act, radical feminism, humanists and working mothers. He said in his speech that this Government has created 700,000 poor people. I do not know exactly where he got that figure but the 700,000 which sticks in my mind is the 700,000 jobs this Government has created. I understand that, by this time, almost one million jobs have been created since this Government came to power. This represents 700,000 new incomes, and there is no better thing that we can give to these needy families than extra income. But when it comes to families, many members of the Opposition do not deal in concrete matters like dollars and cents. They are more concerned with abstract notions of family values, by which of course they mean their values. The honourable member for Braddon later in his speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the poverty can be traced back to the change in attitudes to family life. Those changes received a hefty kick along by the late Justice Murphy, who promoted the disastrous Family Law Act, radical feminism and humanism. Since that time, the number of children living in proverty has increased dramatically as people avail themselves of easy legal options for divorce to run away from the fundamental adult responsibility of parenting. Family life has been trivialised by the Family Law Act, till today we have advocates in our industrial relations area saying that child care provisions should not be such so as to retard a career.

So his speech goes on. Justice Murphy and others behind the Family Law Act did not, as the honourable member claims, trivialise or create easy options. The Family Law Act dragged the whole matter of family and divorce law out of the Victorian era and gave it a civilised, realistic and just form. Is the honourable member for Braddon advocating that we should return to the bad old days of culpability, with sordid trumped-up adultery and cruelty charges or years of legal separation?

The honourable member also talked about parental responsibility. Has it ever occurred to him that perhaps sometimes the responsible thing might be for the woman to take her children and leave the marriage? That woman may then have to get a job to support her children and, if she gets a job, she will need child care facilities. Is the honourable member suggesting that she go on to the supporting parents' benefit at the taxpayers' expense?

The honourable member for Braddon also referred to radical feminism. I must confess that I am never quite sure what radical feminism is as distinct from non-radical feminism. Perhaps the honourable member for Braddon can explain that to me one day. It is true that feminists do not encourage women to leave their husbands. They say to women, `You do not have to stay in an intolerable marriage situation if you do not want to. You can get out and, if you choose to get out, we will see to it that the law does not stand in your way and that reasonable support systems exist so that you and your children can live decently'. If we are to talk about poverty in Australia and what this Government is doing about it, let us not resort to conservative cliches about family life and working mothers. Let us talk about the million new jobs and the million new incomes which this Government has given to Australian families and about the family assistance package which provides real material support for a million Australian children.

SPEECH.PARA: To initiate and support moves to establish with popular acceptance an Australian flag which will more distinctively reflect our national independence and identity.

Implicit in this policy are the following assumptions: firstly, the present flag does not reflect our national independence and identity. I urge all members of the House from New South Wales, and all people of New South Wales, to make sure that they vote in that election for the people whom they wish to represent them at the local government level. Councillor Jim Robertson was born at Running Stream, which is between Mudgee and Lithgow. As a young child he moved to Springwood. He attended Katoomba High School and was a school captain. His first job was as a cadet with AWA Ltd. He left AWA and went to Howard Motors in Parramatta, where he was the chief design engineer. He is an associate in mechanical engineering at the Sydney Technical College. The big change came when in 1950 he threw in his job at Howard Motors, went to Ivanhoe, which is in the far west of New South Wales, and bought and operated the General Motors-Holden's dealership there. He, his brother-in-law and a friend took over the electricity generating operation at Ivanhoe. One can imagine the big diesel generators pounding out electricity in both the summer and winter. Anyone who has been to Ivanhoe knows that in the summer it is a pretty hot operation to look after those motors. The company was known as Colling, Watkins and Robertson, or CWR.

On 1 May 1951 he was appointed to the provincial council of the Central Darling Shire. In 1952 he faced his first council election, was elected and has contested every council election since. In 1964 he was elected as Deputy Shire President. In 1968 CWR took over the electricity generating operation in Wilcannia and Jim and his wife, Betty, moved to Wilcannia from Ivanhoe. In 1974 Jim was elected Shire President and will be until midnight on Saturday. He is a past president of the Western Division Shires Association. For the past four years he has been on the executive of the New South Wales Shires Association. In 1981 he was awarded the Order of Australia Medal for his contribution to the community and local government. He was the Shire President when the water filtration system was recently installed, the sewerage scheme was installed in Wilcannia, a water supply scheme was introduced in Ivanhoe and White Cliffs, and the Wilcannia and Ivanhoe ovals were upgraded. Many other local government improvements were carried out in the Central Darling Shire.
I do not know what Councillor Jim Robertson's politics are. All I know is that he is a friend and confidant of many people-Prime Ministers, Ministers, Premiers and other shire councillors.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What guarantees can the Government give that, once an employer has filled in the reason for cessation of employment on the new Employment Separation Certificate, the former employee will not be able to sue the employer for libel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The new Employment Separation certificate is used by the Department of Social security to
(1) verify the date when a person claiming unemployment benefit became unemployed; and

(2) determine the reason for unemployment. This is important since under the Social Security Act dismissal from employment for misconduct and voluntary cessation of employment without adequate reasons can result in a period of non-payment of benefit.

The question of libel does not arise provided the information supplied by the employer is accurate. In addition, since the employer separation certificate is given directly to the employee it would appear that there could be no defamation on the part of the employer.

I emphasise that detailed reasons for termination of employment are not required. For example, where an employee was dismissed for ``misconduct'' a simple reference to this fact is sufficient for departmental purposes.
